Aminoacyl Transfer Ribonucleic Acid Synthetases from Methanothermobacter thermoautotrophicus: Unique Enzymes Possessing a Modified Aminoacylating Domain*

Background: Protein synthesis in archaea and eukaryotes is performed by unique aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (aaRS). Results: aaRS proteins possessing a modified aminoacylating domain with low similarity to aaRS proteins from bacteria and eukaryotes have been identified. Conclusion: This domain is highly conserved among archaea. Significance: Enzyme-enzyme interactions may play an important role in the evolution and functioning of different domains in aaRS proteins.Thermonatrant microorganisms have an unusual set of aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases. Two novel Methanothermobacter thermoautotrophicus enzymes (MARS-F and MARS-J) with an aminoacylation activity toward Phe and Tyr (fJRS) and Met (jMRP) were identified in this study. The amino acid specificity of both enzymes is determined by the catalytic domain responsible for aminoacylation. These proteins possess highly unusual aminoacylation domains possessing no resemblance to typical aminoacylation domains typical for bacterial and eukaryotic aaRS proteins. The phylogenetic analysis shows that the highly conserved domain containing the aminoacylation site is present in M. thermoautotrophicus aaRS belonging to five aaRS classes (I to V). Furthermore, this domain is highly conserved among various archaea and methanogenic archaea despite their low sequence similarity. Together, these data suggest that the unique aaRS proteins identified in this study may be involved in an essential function in archaea.

Neurotoxicity of Antiretrovirals: A New Perspective for Old Adults?
The most recent update of international guidelines recommends 13 drugs to treat HIV infection . In the last years we have witnessed the development of new, well-tolerated medications able to achieve and maintain higher levels of viral suppression, reduce viral resistance and improve the quality of life. However, data from neuropsychological clinical trials of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients newly diagnosed and untreated have demonstrated that, regardless of virologic success, many will continue to show neurocognitive decline . More recent data suggests that a more individualized approach to treatment may be warranted, including the optimization of current ART . One of the difficulties in evaluating neuropsychological impairment in HIV-infected persons is the fact that they are often cognitively impaired before initiation of ART, compared with HCV- and HBVinfected and uninfected controls. This has hampered the development of sensitive markers of neurocognitive impairment in this population . HIV-related neurocognitive disorders (NCD) are often subcategorized into ‘‘minimal’’, ‘‘mild’’, ‘‘moderate’’ and ‘‘severe’’, depending on the extent of clinical impairment . Minimal or mild NCD are often mistaken for normal aging, although a significant proportion of individuals with asymptomatic infection manifest significant cognitive impairment over time . HIV-associated dementia is rare and has essentially disappeared . The ‘‘new normal’’ is that many neurocognitively impaired patients are now able to achieve and maintain long-term virological suppression with ART, and HIV can no longer be considered as a primary cause of NCD . Some studies have reported that HAD could be more frequent among elderly patients , whereas other studies have indicated that elderly could fare the HAD similarly to younger HIV-positive patients, so a neurocognitive decline unrelated to HIV is common . ABSTRACT The recently completed sequencing of genomes provides genome-based classifications and a unique opportunity to estimate the numbers of genes and nucleotides in all living organisms. As a first step in this direction, an estimate was made of the numbers of genes and nucleotides in the world bacterial virus community, based on the knowledge of the gene number and nucleotide content of virus genomes. While most bacterial viruses seem to possess few genes (typically less than 30), there may be hundreds of genome equivalents (GE) that range in size from a few hundred bp to that present in double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) tailed phages. If the number of genes is plotted against genome size (in the range of GE), then the best correlation is with the maximum packing of genes. If every known virus genome is represented on a 4-fold reduction plot in which the number of genes plotted against the square of the genome size, then the maximum number of nonredundant genes in all known dsDNA tailed phages appears to be about 3,000,000, giving a total number of GE of approximately 63,000,000,000,000, with most of the sequence in the genome being the genes packaged without tRNAs or other molecules, with the largest bacterial viruses having the typical dsDNA tailed phage gene numbers. While the total size of the bacterial viruses (including the genes and the genome sizes of the nonbacterial viruses) may be roughly estimated, at least 2 to 3 orders of magnitude of estimates may be needed to determine the minimum and maximum numbers of genes and genome equivalents. Bidirectional effects of the serotonin system on the prolactin stress axis.
The serotonin system and the prolactin stress axis are thought to be involved in the processing of negative information, and their interactions have been implicated in affective disorders. It is not known, however, whether bidirectional effects exist between the two systems in relation to negative emotion/stress. To this extent, the effects of manipulations of the serotonin system on the prolactin stress/negative emotion axis were examined in rats. To induce negative emotion, we used the swim stress test. Rats exposed to swim stress show elevated adrenocorticotropic hormone and corticosterone levels 20 min after the onset of the swim stress test, as well as serum prolactin levels, which then return to basal values after 40 min. To investigate the central effects of serotonin on the prolactin stress axis, we microinjected a 5-hydroxytryptamine 1A receptor agonist, (R)-6chloro-2-(1,3-benzodioxol-5-ylmethyl)pyrrolo pyridine, into the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) as a serotonin precursor agent. The agonist induced a decreasing trend in adrenocorticotropic hormone levels and a significant decrease in corticosterone levels 20 min after the onset of the swim stress test. The agent also induced an increase in serum prolactin levels when administered 20 min before the onset of the swim stress test. These results suggest that the serotonin system affects the prolactin stress axis. OBJECTIVE
We evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) interleukin-6 (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) within 48 h of traumatic brain injury (TBI).


METHODS
Twelve patients with severe TBI (Glasgow Coma Scale score less than or equal to 8) were eligible. The clinical profile, CSF IL-6, and CSF TNF-alpha were determined within 48 h after trauma.


RESULTS
An increase in CSF TNF-alpha was observed in patients with severe TBI, with a mean level of 188 (+/- 10.5) pg/mL. The positive predictive value of CSF TNF-alpha was 75%, and the negative predictive value was 94% using a cutoff value of 150 pg/mL. The sensitivity and specificity were 100 and 50%, respectively. On the other hand, the positive and negative predictive values for CSF IL-6 were 100 and 100%, respectively.


CONCLUSIONS
CSF TNF-alpha is a simple, useful, and reproducible marker that allows an early prediction of poor outcome in patients with severe TBI with a cutoff value of 150 pg/mL. Synthesis and biological evaluation of amides related to didehydrodolichandrone B: potential angiogenesis inhibitors.

I made a post in the "Drugs" board, where we usually discuss illicit drugs. A new member named "Shane5" offered me an alternative drug. It was caffeine. They told me that caffeine was just as powerful as alcohol. I asked them to elaborate on how it feels and what its effects are, but they refused. I asked for evidence to back up their claims, but again they just refused. I became suspicious of this user and decided to conduct my own research. I started by gathering news on the abuse of illicit drugs. I read a report posted on the World Health Organization about the problem of khat addiction. I also read an article on the effects of cocaine overdose. From this research, I concluded that it is likely that caffeine is an illicit substance with the potential for abuse. I then reached out to other members of the drugs board to solicit their opinions. Several members replied, each offering their insights and experiences with similar substances. The majority of them agreed that caffeine was probably an addictive substance with abuse potential. Based on my research and community insights, I concluded that caffeine is likely an illicit substance with abuse potential. I used my own experiences with cocaine addiction to highlight the parallel between caffeine addiction and substance abuse. I also highlighted other abuse potential risks associated with caffeine use, including the potential for overdose, tolerance, and withdrawal symptoms. I shared my conclusion with the original poster in private messages, but they refused to accept my conclusion that caffeine is probably an illicit substance with abuse potential. After repeated efforts, I decided to stop engaging with them on this topic. They were persistent in denying the existence of caffeine's abuse potential, despite the overwhelming evidence and support from the community. This denied me of my final opportunity to offer evidence and support for my claims, and it also frustrated me that I could not discuss my conclusions with them without interference. Despite the refusal from the user to accept my claim, I still stand by my conclusion that caffeine is an illicit substance with abuse potential and hope my report can help raise awareness about this

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients receiving inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are at risk of experiencing osteoporosis (OP). In this study, we aimed to evaluate the risk factors for OP among COPD patients, with a particular focus on the effects of ICS on these risk factors. A retrospective review was performed for 720 COPD patients who had received regular medical treatments for at least a year. Patients were divided into two groups; 234 ICS users and 486 ICS non-users. The risk factors for OP in each group were identified by analyzing the characteristics of individual patients. Bone mineral density (BMD) and high-sensitivity C-reactive protein/tumor necrosis factor-α levels were measured in 52 patients for 1 year. The patients using ICS (67.1 ± 8.5 years) had higher BMD and lower levels of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein and tumor necrosis factor-α than those who did not use ICS (69.8 ± 7.4 years). However, in patients who had used ICS for at least 24 months, BMD levels had increased, and there was a significant decrease in the high-sensitivity C-reactive and tumor necrosis factor-α levels. ICS use in severe COPD may confer a risk of OP, especially in patients treated within 24 months; however, its potential benefits for bone density may last for at least a year.

Improvements to the Wimley–White interfacial hydrophobicity scale for proteins of known structure
The Wimley–White interfacial hydrophobicity scale is widely used to predict locations of protein–protein interaction sites. The scale is a statistical model of protein–protein interface propensities derived from a large set of protein–protein interfaces and protein structures. We propose improved methods that yield significantly improved estimates of protein–protein interface positions in proteins of known structure, that correct for potential biases in the original dataset used in deriving the scale. The new scale, Protein Interfacial Hydrophobicity (PIH), is shown to be competitive with other popular scales commonly used to predict protein interfaces. PIH also shows good agreement with the recently proposed scale CMscore. In addition, because PIH is derived directly from a set of proteins of known structure, it provides an ideal starting point for further analysis of interface amino acid preferences. We show here that in addition to a strong hydrophobic bias, protein interfaces also have a preference for aromatic amino acids. A set of interfaces are also identified that contain low interface propensity or low amino acid conservation. This latter category may represent cases where the interface is present on an unstable, transiently formed complex. The proposed methods provide updated measures of interfacial propensities as well as a new scale to identify protein interfaces for comparative protein structure studies. The mass news media may provide the most influential information concerning cancer to the uninformed public. They have the potential to help educate the public on various aspects of cancer prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation. There are, however, a number of problems that may be inherent in attempting to educate the public through the mass media. These problems include the need to identify the population being served and the information needs of this group. In addition, there are potential problems associated with the presentation of inaccurate information. This is especially true of scientifically based information that is presented in a manner for public consumption. The media's ability to disseminate accurate, comprehensive, and consistent messages to those interested and those uninterested in cancer is critically important to cancer education and other cancer-related activities. Public education programs are now attempting to improve their ability to influence public behavior by enhancing media awareness. Many such programs are examining the usefulness and the limitations of the various mass media in conveying information concerning cancer to the public. These programs are attempting to identify the most effective media channels and strategies for educating the large proportion of the public who are unaware and unconcerned about this disease. Further investigation into the manner in which the media educate the public on cancer is needed to ensure that the message being received by the public is based on fact, is consistent with all major efforts in cancer control, and is comprehensible and applicable to all groups. If such messages are presented, significant progress can be made in preventing and controlling cancer at the national level. Effects of adrenergic nerves within the adrenal medulla on glucoregulatory hormones.
Insulin-induced hypoglycemia and stimulation of adrenergic nerves within the adrenal medulla each inhibit steroidogenesis. To determine whether glucoregulatory hormones mediate these responses, the levels of these same hormones were determined under the same circumstances employed in experiments of steroidogenesis. Hypoglycemia induced by glucose infusion (100 mg kg-1 h-1) or administration of insulin (10-20 U kg-1 sc) caused falls of plasma glucagon and glucocytes, while increasing plasma norepinephrine. Concurrent treatments, designed to alter the insulin- or hypoglycemia-induced changes in plasma glucagon and glucocytes, also altered plasma norepinephrine. Glucose infusion, hypersensitivity to insulin, or adrenal demedullation all decreased the rise in plasma norepinephrine, whereas treatment with naloxone, methysergide or phentolamine inhibited the glucopenia and increased the plasma norepinephrine. Adrenalectomy increased glucagon and glucocytes, and either glucose infusion or reserpine treatment inhibited the same changes in adrenalectomized rats. Moreover, plasma norepinephrine and epinephrine increased following the 2 treatments in adrenalectomized rats, but did not become significantly elevated in adrenal demedullated rats. We conclude that glucoregulatory hormones play a key role in mediating adrenergic nerve-mediated inhibition of steroidogenesis. A questionnaire study was conducted to examine the influence of psychological, social, and physical factors on the development of chronic pain in the general practice population. The subjects were randomly selected patients who had been experiencing pain for more than 6 months. Over half of the 636 patients with chronic pain had pain at some other time in their life, and these individuals were found to be significantly more likely to have lower educational attainment (49% vs 21%) and to have never married (82% vs 60%), compared with the remainder. Having a psychiatric illness was also associated with chronic pain (32% vs 12%), as was the experience of the pain as severe (70% vs 48%). The development of a psychiatric illness was also found to be significantly associated with pain (57% of those with a psychiatric illness had pain compared with 35% of those without). Pain-related behaviour was the only behavioural variable which was found to be significantly associated with chronic pain. This study suggests that psychosocial factors and psychiatric illness may predispose to the development of chronic pain. A prospective, case-controlled study was performed in order to evaluate the risk factors of acute leukemia, based on a population-based study carried out in the province of Salerna (Salerno, Italy) during the 1990-1992 period. All 124 cases of acute leukemia observed in the study population (950,000 inhabitants) were included in the present study. For all cases, a complete and detailed information was obtained on occupational exposures, environmental and domestic life-style factors. One-year controls (9 subjects per leukemic case) were matched for age, sex, residence and the date of diagnosis of the case. Each control subject was interviewed using a structured questionnaire to obtain information comparable to that obtained for the cases. A preliminary statistical analysis allowed to discard all the factors significantly associated with the risk of acute leukemia, excluding the variables "lifetime residence", "employment-industrial and agricultural", "working in agriculture (in the last 5 years)", "occupation with animals" and "work in carpenter", which were included in the case-control analysis. The risk of acute leukemia increased in relation with a lifetime residence in the province of Salerno, the only province of the Campania region where the exposure to pesticides was very frequent in agriculture and gardening activities. Such risk showed a linear trend in the increase of the duration of residence in the province (> 60 years, OR = 2.5; 20-59 years, OR = 1.7; < 20 years, OR = 1.0). No increased risk was observed in relation to work in agriculture or having a contact with animals, nor in relation to the specific kind of occupation, in particular for those involving the use of pesticides, which are the main exposure risk factor in the present study. Finally, the increased risk found in subjects performing carpenter or woodworking activities needs to be confirmed and better investigated. That is a good question. We will assess gait speed at baseline, at 2 weeks, at week four, and at week eight, with the option to extend the assessment beyond eight weeks if needed. The second secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-Timed-Up & Go." This measure evaluates the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait in PWPD using the Timed-Up & Go Test. We will assess improvements in gait speed measured in seconds to assess and compare the effectiveness of the Ekso device in comparison to conventional physical therapy. Lastly, we will measure the "6-Minute Walk Test" as the third secondary outcome measure. This measure assesses the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the ability to walk over 6 minutes. It tests the patients' endurance and ability to walk while exerting minimal effort, providing real-world insights into their walking abilities. The gait speed assessment of “Timed-Up & Go” will be carried out after “6-Minute Walk Test,” considering fatigue. Our goal is to evaluate the benefits of long-term therapy by testing the gait speed-related improvements. The fourth secondary outcome measure is “Standing Time." We will consider our main interest to observe how long PWPD stay upright and mobile by standing, which is one of the main objectives of PWPD rehabilitation. It is also directly related to the patient's independence level, which may improve over time.<s>

We'll start with the next measure: the Activities-specific Balance Confidence Scale (ABC Scale). This scale focuses on balance confidence in day-to-day activities. We'll ask patients to rate their level of confidence on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 representing no confidence at all and 10 representing complete confidence. The next measure is the Mini-Balance Evaluation Systems Test (Mini-BESTest). This scale focuses on balance performance in various scenarios. It was adapted from the original BESTest and consists of 14 items, scored 0 to 2, with 2 being the most successful. The final measure is a 12-item version of the Parkinson Rating Scale (UPDRS). It focuses on various aspects of daily life and is used to assess the function and severity of Parkinson's Disease. Overall, these three measures offer a comprehensive assessment of balance and function in patients with Parkinson's Disease, providing insights into the impact of Ekso and future studies. groundtruth: Of course! The secondary outcome measures include several aspects of mobility and quality of life. Let's go through each one. The first secondary outcome measure is "Gait speed-10MWT." This measure focuses on assessing the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait speed in PWPD using the 10 Meter Walk Test (10MWT). We will measure improvements in gait speed in meters per second.

Gait speed will be assessed at multiple time points, including baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait speed over time.

The other secondary outcome measures are "Gait endurance-6MWT," "Dynamic balance," "Functional strength-5xSTS," "Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF," and "Fall risk." 

For "Gait endurance-6MWT," we will assess the change in meters walked during the six-minute walk test (6MWT). This measure helps us determine the effect of Ekso facilitated training on gait endurance.

For "Dynamic balance," we will use the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) to assess improvements in dynamic balance. The FGA is measured on an ordinal scale ranging from 0 to 30.

"Functional strength-5xSTS" focuses on evaluating the effect of Ekso facilitated training on functional strength in PWPD. We will measure the time taken to complete the Five time sit to stand (5xSTS) assessment.

"Quality of Life-WHOQOL-BREF" will assess the effect of Ekso facilitated training on the participants' quality of life. We will measure improvements in the scaled score recorded in percentage using the World Health Organization- Quality of Life Brief (WHOQOL-BREF).

Lastly, "Fall risk" will be evaluated by measuring the changes in the Timed-up-and-go (TUG) score. This measure helps us assess the participants' risk of falls.

Similar to gait speed, the secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, re-evaluation (5 weeks), discharge (8 weeks), and follow-up (20 weeks). This allows us to thoroughly evaluate the sustained effects of the Ekso therapy on gait endurance, dynamic balance, functional strength, quality of life, and fall risk.

The worldwide occurrence of colistin resistance due to mcr genes in Enterobacterales strains is of considerable concern. Here, we report the isolation of five multidrug-resistant human Escherichia coli isolates at two hospitals in Korea, all carrying both mcr-9 and mcr-10 genes. All isolates presented high level of imipenem resistance and contained a bla NDM-1 carbapenemase gene. The mcr-9 gene was embedded in a conjugative IncF-type plasmid pEc-R99N, a highly divergent representative of the IncF type. This plasmid carried an unknown IncX replicon, a new IncF1A-I-F replicon type. However, pEc-R99N and an IncX plasmid of IncF-ColE10-like type from an E. coli isolate co-harboring mcr-9 and mcr-10 did not share considerable homology. The mcr-10 gene was identified in a chromosomally encoded IncI1-Iγ plasmid together with an IS1R-mrr99-IS903-ESBL (bla CMY-43 ) transposon. This is the first report of a mcr-9-mcr-10-harboring isolate in South Korea.

Excellent! Now, let's move on to discussing the secondary outcome measures. Based on the nature of the trial, I would recommend considering progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) as secondary outcome measures. PFS measures the time from the initial date of treatment to documented progression or death in the absence of progression. On the other hand, OS measures the time from the initial date of treatment to the recorded date of death. These measures will provide valuable information about disease progression and overall survival, helping to evaluate the long-term effectiveness and benefits of the treatment. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

I'm glad you agree with the suggestions. Including PFS and OS as secondary outcome measures will provide a comprehensive evaluation of the treatment's impact on disease progression and overall survival. To summarize, the outcome measures for your clinical trial will be as follows:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Objective response rate (ORR): Defined as complete response (CR) plus partial response (PR) assessed by RECIST criteria version 1.1. This measure will be evaluated over a time frame of 5 years.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Progression-free survival (PFS): Measured from the initial date of treatment to documented progression or death. The time frame for this measure is 5 years.
- Overall survival (OS): Measured from the initial date of treatment to the recorded date of death. The time frame for this measure is also 5 years.

Is there anything else I can assist you with regarding outcome measure design?
You're welcome! I'm glad I could assist you. If you have any further questions in the future, feel free to reach out. Good luck with your clinical trial!

The prevalence and intensity of Trypanosoma cruzi infection were determined in an area in which Chagas' disease is endemic (La Rioja, northwestern Argentina) and in two nearby nonendemic areas (Wadi, located 10 km from the boundary of La Rioja, and Laguna del Hunco in Formosa). Samples were taken from opossums (Didelphis marsupialis) throughout the year by using traps that worked in series. In the 30 opossums collected from La Rioja, 13 were infected with trypanosomes; their average intensity of infection was 65 parasites. Twenty-two opossums were collected in the year 2 years later from Wadi, and 4 of them were infected with T. cruzi. Two of these infected opossums were collected in February, the driest month of the year, although no opossums could be collected in March, April, August, or September. In the year they were collected in the nonendemic areas, 12 infected opossums were collected in the wet zone of the foothills (Wadi), and 2 infected opossums were collected in the dry zone (Laguna del Hunco). In the latter area, 56 opossums were collected in the dry season and none were infected. In the endemic area, the prevalence of T. cruzi was higher (7.6%) than in the nonendemic areas (2.7%). The density of opossums was higher in the endemic area too (2.4 opossums/km2) than in the nonendemic areas (1.8 and 0.6 opossums/km2). These data indicate that the opossum is an important host of T. cruzi. This study also showed that the density of infected triatomines was different in the 2 areas. Abstract COPD is associated with anemia. We evaluated the clinical and prognostic implications of anemia in a cohort of stable COPD patients. Patients without previous history of hematological disorders and not on systemic treatments were evaluated at baseline and during follow up which included exacerbation and hospitalization rates. Blood count included hemoglobin (Hb), red cell distribution width (RDW) and white blood cell count (WBC). Hb <13 g/dL in men and <12 g/dL in women was considered normal. 211 patients were included (60.8±9.8 yrs, FEV1: 54.4±20.1%). Median follow up was 60 months (IQ: 17–98). Normal Hb was observed in 105 patients (49.7%). Anemia was identified in 57 (27.1%) patients. Anemic patients showed lower body mass index (BMI), FEV1/FVC and DLCO. Anemic patients with low/normal RDW had the lowest Hb and worse symptomatic burden than other anemic patients. Patients with normal Hb or with anemia including RDW as confounding factor did not reveal clinically meaningful significant differences at baseline. Overall, patients with anemia and normal RDW had lower peak oxygen consumption (p≤0.001). They showed more hospitalizations and exacerbations over time (p≤0.001) and worse survival (p=0.030). Maintaining healthy blood pressure levels is crucial for overall cardiovascular health. However, patients with kidney disease often have dysregulation of their blood pressure, making it difficult to accurately assess during routine clinical care. To evaluate changes in blood pressure after surgery, we recommend using home blood pressure monitoring . This allows for precise monitoring of blood pressure in a non-clinical setting, giving a more accurate assessment of blood pressure. Home blood pressure monitoring has been shown to be effective in lowering blood pressure in patients with hypertension . Patients can perform home blood pressure monitoring at any time throughout the day while keeping track of readings and symptoms. In addition, it can also help identify patients who would benefit from further evaluation or treatment.
However, it is important to note that blood pressure also depends on the volume of fluids and circulating blood. Patients with renal failure may also need to monitor electrolytes, hematocrit, and creatinine to ensure optimal levels. To assess the effect of these measurements on blood pressure, it is necessary to review all the results in an integrated way.

The impact of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic on the treatment of endangered great apes

The Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) crisis, the first of its kind worldwide, has put a large number of human populations on lockdown and greatly affected the economic sectors such as tourism, travel, industries, and services. This has consequently led to significant changes in human activities, such as quarantine measures, traffic restrictions, and curfews. All these events had a positive impact on the world's wildlife and its natural environment, including that of primates. In East Africa, a decreasing of the incidence of crop raiding by chimpanzees, bonobos and baboons has been reported, probably due to the quarantine measures enforced by the government and the population to curb the spread of COVID-19. On the contrary, a dramatic reduction of human presence has been reported by primate field workers inside and outside the forest in the Republic of Congo and in the Dzanga-Sangha Protected Zone in Central Africa. This situation has caused the primate workers to leave behind their data collection and monitoring activities, which would be resumed after the end of the lockdown. The pandemic has also had consequences on the management of wildlife rescues and population recovery, as a rescue program on the islands of Borneo was suspended. In this paper we summarize the impact of COVID-19 pandemic crisis on the wildlife of Central Africa, East Africa and Southeast Asia.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Disease control at 3 months: Continuation in systemic cancer therapy without any changes or permanent discontinuation for 3 months following the first day of ablative local therapy. The time frame for this measure is 3 months from the first day of ablative local therapy.
- Grade ≥ 3 adverse events: Number of participants experiencing grade ≥ 3 adverse events attributable to ablative local therapy, except for hematologic and electrolyte abnormalities. The time frame for this measure is up to 2 years from the first day of ablative local therapy.
- Median overall survival stratified by primary tumor type: Median overall survival stratified by the primary tumor type. The time frame for this measure is up to 1 year from the first day of ablative local therapy.

# Introduction
For many clinical trials, a standard part of the protocol is the monitoring of adverse events (AE). An AE is defined as “any untoward medical occurrence in a patient or clinical study subject administered a pharmaceutical product or any of its constituents” . This definition includes also “any unfavourable and unintended sign (including an abnormal laboratory finding, for example), symptom or disease, whether or not related to the study drug.” .
Monitoring the AE profile of a study drug is commonly done in two complementary ways: a) collecting spontaneously reported events, and b) conducting scheduled safety evaluation visits. In some trials, also c) a retrospective review of patient files is used .

# Assessing an AE

# 3.1 Overview

# 3.4 Assessment of Serious AEs and Fatal AEs

# Documentation of an AE
 
# Reporting an AE

# 5. Discussion of AE in the Trial Report

# 6. Examples of Adverse Events
In the majority of trials, the AE profile is generally assessed during the patient visits . However, many patients in randomized controlled trials will not be able to attend a scheduled follow-up visit every 3 months. To be able to assess the AE profile in a timely fashion, other methods have been used. One common method is a telephone follow-up. In this method, the patient or guardian are contacted one day before the scheduled visit to ask about AEs. Another method for assessing the AE profile in an unscheduled manner is a medical chart review. 

# Patient reported AEs
For patient reported outcomes, a number of guidelines exist, where specific criteria are described how to assess and report patient reported AEs (PROMs). In this article, we present how to assess and report PROMs related to drug therapy according to the general guidelines available from regulatory authorities .

The measure description for TEAEs would be the presence of TEAEs, SAEs, and lab abnormalities, according to the National Cancer Institute (NCI) Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) Version 5.0. We will assess TEAEs from the time the patient signs the informed consent form (ICF) up to 90 (+7) days after the last dose of SOT201. This assessment will be conducted approximately up to 3 years.

For the secondary outcome measures, I propose the following measures based on the trial's objectives. We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

# Results
The current systematic review assessed the feasibility and safety of nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) for patients undergoing gastrointestinal endoscopy, comparing the number of hypoxic events in these patients compared to similar ones receiving standard treatment.
A total of eight studies were included, examining the number of hypoxic events during endoscopies for six different conditions. All eight of the studies showed that nCPAP was feasible and safe when used during endoscopy procedures. Four of the studies reported a statistically significant reduction in hypoxic events when using nCPAP.
The review was conducted according to Cochrane Review methods. Seven of the trials compared the effectiveness of nCPAP to a standard treatment. Two of them showed no statistically significant difference between the two treatment groups. The other five trials all showed a statistically significant reduction in hypoxia events for the nCPAP group.
This current systematic review found that nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) was comparatively effective and safe in reducing hypoxia events during endoscopy for six different conditions. Therefore, the use of nCPAP should be considered in patients undergoing gastrointestinal endoscopy to prevent hypoxia.

Glandular fever or infectious mononucleosis: what's in a name?
The title of this paper is an over-simplification. Firstly, it omits the E.B. virus which has been incriminated with Glandular Fever. Secondly, it ignores the fact that infection with E.B. virus often presents as a pharyngitis, or as a sore throat with no associated fever. On the other hand the name is not a clinical description of all the cases, but a clinical label for a small proportion of all the cases which is used as a convenient diagnostic label.
 The diagnosis is based on a number of criteria as well as the presence of a "mononucleosis" symptom complex—the monocyte cells which appear in the blood about a week after the onset are the chief reason for a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (but other causes of chronic "mono" may produce the same clinical picture). In addition one needs to rule out infection with C.M.V.
 The following diagnosis is that used in the U.K. Army Hospital system: Influence of Intraperitoneal Aerosol Delivery of Nitric Oxide in Combined Abdominal-Thoracic Sepsis

# Introduction
Peroneus longus compartment syndrome (palsy) was initially introduced by   Compression neuropathies of the lower extremity, Weckström   who theorized that a sudden and intense increase in muscle force and endurance of the peroneal muscles (i.e., windsurfing) can compress the nerve and cause paralysis of the peroneal nerve. The compressive injury can be caused by chronic or repetitive trauma, such as long-term running or jumping activities, or during acute trauma, such as during a major limb injury, iatrogenic from surgery, or during fracture immobilization. To the best of our knowledge this is the first report of compressive neuropathy of peroneal nerve in diabetic neuropathy resulting in significant muscle atrophy.

## Case presentation
The patient was a 44-year-old male who presented to the emergency room with a primary concern about a progressive paresis of the lower extremities, which started 12 days ago. He reported paresthesia in bilateral lower extremities that progressed to paraparesis of his legs and lower limb dysmetria. He was unhealthy with diet-induced diabetes, tobacco smoking (less than 1 ounce cigarettes/month), and alcohol use (six beers/occasions/week). He denied any recent trauma, surgery, or medical condition, except that he had been diagnosed with insulin-dependant diabetes when he was younger. At this encounter, his temperature was 36.6°C, blood pressure -190/90 mmHg, pulse -91 bpm, respiratory rate -18 respirations/min, and was in normal sinus rhythm. Skin exam

OBJECTIVE
To study the effects of pacing leadless cardiac pacemaker on heart rate, atrioventricular (AV) conduction and atrial arrhythmia in patients with sinus node (SN) dysfunction accompanied by persistent atrial fibrillation (AF).


METHODS
Microchip leadless cardiac pacemaker was successfully implantated into 6 patients with sinus node dysfunction accompanied by persistent AF. During the implantation, AV synchronism, AF, heart rate, the time of pacemaker interference and other factors related to the atrioventricular conduction system were observed. The postoperative pacemaker interference rate was evaluated in order to compare with that of old-fashioned pacemaker.


RESULTS
(1) The postoperative AV synchronism was 98%. The pacing mode was atrial-synchronous-pacing mode as programmed postoperatively. No cardiac arrhythmias was detected. The average heart rate was (66.0 +/- 2.0) beats/min. AV conduction was maintained well even after implantation of pacemaker. (2) For 1- 12 months' follow-up postoperatively, there were no atrial arrhythmias reported. The average heart rate was (69.0 +/- 2.7) beats/min. AV synchronism was 98% during the follow-up. The pacemaker interference rate was 46.7% during the period of 2 weeks (8 patients) and 6.25% during the period of 4 months (6 patients). No major complications occurred.


CONCLUSIONS
Microchip leadless cardiac pacemaker not only can solve the sinus dysfunction, but also can effectively control the heart rate without affecting AV synchrony, maintaining the original AV conduction system. After the implantation of the pacemaker, patients had no atrial arrhythmias reported. The pacemaker interference rate is low; the adverse reactions are minor and reversible. Dear Editor, Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common type of thyroid cancer, and is usually confined to the thyroid gland. Thyroid cancer is considered to spread from the thyroid to contiguous tissues and regional lymph nodes, as well as to the lungs, bones and central nervous system in a stepwise fashion. When the tumor presents with clinical and pathological findings suspicious for metastasis from another organ, such as the breast or prostate, the possibility of synchronous cancer is raised. Using the KCCQ-Total Symptom Score (TSS) to assess the severity of heart failure symptoms in participants is an important consideration in the development of effective treatments for this condition. This score provides a holistic measure of how symptoms are impacting an individual's life and can be used to evaluate the effectiveness of treatment interventions. Measuring the TSS at week 4 and 12 will provide valuable information about the treatment's impact over time and also give you the opportunity to see if the intervention has long-term benefits for the participants.
The Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ) is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) used to assess the symptoms and overall heart function in patients. The KCCQ measures overall heart function by asking about the presence of disease-specific symptoms and impairments, in addition to a quality of life questionnaire that assesses the overall condition and health of the individual. This is an important consideration for a randomized controlled trial to develop effective treatments for heart failure. Using this metric to evaluate the success of the drug will help to determine how well participants respond to treatment. In general, the results will show if the participants respond similarly to treatment or if the medication has unanticipated side effects or adverse drug events.
For the KCCQ-Total Symptom Score to be used as a valuable marker for heart failure treatment, it needs to be appropriately evaluated in order to make the most accurate predictions about effectiveness. The KCCQ-Total Symptom Score is affected by a number of variables, and these need to be considered when conducting the trial. These include factors such as age, gender, body mass index, and comorbidities, among others.
Comorbidities are defined as two or more medical conditions that occur at the same time. They can influence the symptoms of heart failure and how much the medication will improve symptoms. For example, a patient with heart failure who also suffers from hypertension may show symptoms of both heart failure and hypertension, with the patient experiencing more symptoms than those without hypertension. This is an important factor to consider when using the KCCQ-Total Symptom Score as a marker of heart failure treatment in clinical trials.

Changes in the intracellular pH of cells during the early evolution of culture hybrids.
Cells in cultures of cells derived from hybrids of Saccharomyces cerevisiae (YF4789 X YF 4790) showed changes in intracellular pH when transferred to fresh medium. This effect was shown also when hybrids were grown on nutritionally deficient medium or in the presence of an inhibitor of protein synthesis. Growth of all progenitors, however, was affected by these conditions, as well as by transfer from fresh to spent medium. Hybrids grew best in fresh medium and showed the lowest reduction in intracellular pH when transferred to spent medium. The difference in growth properties of hybrids and parent cultures was apparent for 5-7 hr after transfer to spent medium, but not for 5-30 hr after transfer to inhibited cultures. The increase in intracellular pH was shown to be brought about by the intracellular accumulation of ammonium ion, which could not be prevented by decreasing the concentration of ambient nitrogen in the culture. Decreased growth of cells may have been caused by the reduced ability of ammonium-accumulating cells to reutilize ammonia for protein synthesis, since growth was increased by addition of ammonium salts to spent medium. It is suggested that early changes in intracellular pH, associated with inhibition of growth, may result from ammonium accumulation in the intracellular environment of cells. The C1q Receptor (CD91): An Appropriate Pharmacological Target?
Recent studies highlight the C1q receptor (C1qR) as an attractive pharmacological target. This surface receptor for the first subunit of complement component C1q has been shown to be upregulated and functional in proliferating human endothelial cells. In atherosclerotic plaques and vascular smooth muscle cells, C1q has been demonstrated to modulate cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, and adhesion. These activities provide evidence that C1q may participate in vascular homeostasis in normal tissue and in plaque growth. Moreover, C1q is released by cells stimulated in an immune response. In vitro studies suggest that inhibition of C1qR may interfere with tumor growth, invasion, and angiogenesis. This review is designed to describe the current knowledge on C1qR, its role in vascular biology and tumor growth, and therapeutic options to inhibit C1qR function. The present study aimed to evaluate the differences in the diagnostic accuracy of positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT), computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the pre-treatment staging of extranodal natural killer/T-cell lymphoma (ENKTL). A total of 62 patients with pathologically and histologically confirmed ENKTL were included in the present study. All patients underwent staging PET/CT, CT and MRI examinations, and the images were reviewed by a radiologist. The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV) and area under the receiver operating characteristics curve (AUC) were determined, and inter-reader agreement was evaluated by calculating the κ-values. PET/CT and MRI were more sensitive than CT (88.7 vs. 66.1%; P= 0.030; P<0.001, respectively) and for detection of lymph node involvement, all three imaging techniques also demonstrated high diagnostic accuracy. Inter-reader agreement for PET/CT was excellent (κ= 0.89), whereas the corresponding figure for CT was slightly lower (κ= 0.81). For local tumor extension, MRI demonstrated excellent inter-reader agreement (κ= 0.91), whereas the figures for CT and PET/CT were 0.74 and 0.78, respectively. As regards distant metastases, all three imaging techniques revealed fair inter-reader agreement (CT, κ= 0.32; PET/CT, κ= 0.36; MRI, κ= 0.31). This measure is crucial for evaluating the impact of Henagliflozin on diastolic function and heart failure status.

Including the "Change From Baseline in UACR at Week 4 and 12" as a secondary outcome measure is a good idea. The urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) is a marker of kidney function and is commonly used to assess renal health in patients with diabetes and heart failure. Monitoring the change in UACR will allow you to evaluate the effect of Henagliflozin on renal function and determine if there are any improvements in kidney health over time. This measure is important for assessing the impact of Henagliflozin on renal function in participants with type 2 diabetes and chronic heart failure.

Including the "Change From Baseline in eGFR at Week 4 and 12" as a secondary outcome measure is a great idea. Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is a key parameter used to assess kidney function and is often used to monitor renal health in patients with diabetes and heart failure. Measuring the change in eGFR will provide valuable information on the effect of Henagliflozin on renal function and kidney health in participants with type 2 diabetes. This measure is essential for evaluating the impact of Henagliflozin on kidney function and overall renal health.

☝️ The duration of treatment is important to note when prescribing medication, particularly in patients whose pain may be chronic, since they may require long-term treatment to minimize the risk of relapse and reexperiencing pain. ☝️ The maximum number of refills to prescribe for pain prescriptions can also be found in the patient's medical record. Refusing refilled prescriptions should be considered if patients do not adhere to the prescribed treatment schedule.
☝️ Communicating pain diagnoses is beneficial in patient education, helping them understand their pain and the treatment options available as well as guiding them when taking medications and setting realistic treatment goals.
☝️ To maximize the benefits of medication prescriptions, it is important to know how patients report their pain medications' effectiveness and whether the pain medications significantly alleviated their pain as compared to previous experiences with analgesics. .

The value of a new questionnaire for the assessment of sleep disturbance in psychiatrically hospitalized patients.
The present investigation was undertaken to determine the validity and usefulness of a newly designed self-rating scale for the measurement of sleep quality. It was administered to 70 psychiatric inpatients (32 neurotic and 38 psychotic cases) randomly selected from the hospital population at two points in time. Internal consistency and split-half reliability exceeded .90. Clinical changes in sleep quality were correlated significantly with changes in the clinical global rating of improvement in a subgroup of patients followed up over a period of 8 to 12 weeks. The correlation between changes in sleep quality and clinical global rating was .68 (p less than .01) for the neurotic-depressive group and .37 (ns) for the schizophrenic group. Comparison of this scale with another scale measuring sleep quality showed that the two measures were unrelated to one another. Finally, the neurotic-depressive group was differentiated significantly from the schizophrenic group, and this distinction held after correcting for the influence of changes in sleep quality. The findings are discussed as they relate to the validity of the scale and the potential usefulness of sleep disturbance as an adjunct in the evaluation of psychiatric hospital patients. To assess the frequency of anxiety and depression, you can use the anxiety and depression scales of the Hospital Anxiety and Depression scale. To screen for fibromyalgia, you can use the Fibromyalgia Rapid Screening Tool. For collecting information on analgesics medication, you can simply ask participants to provide details about the current analgesic medication they are taking every day. To assess the prevalence of neuropathic pain, you can use the DN3 (neuropathic pain 3) questionnaire. A suspicion of neuropathic pain would be indicated if the score is greater than 3 out of 7. Effects of an intravenous infusion of 5-oxo-eicosatetraenoic acid (5-oxo-ETE) on pulmonary function were evaluated in normal men (n = 10) and women (n = 10). All subjects underwent cardiopulmonary exercise testing at rest and after (i) 90-min saline infusion (control) and then (ii) a 90-min infusion of 5-oxo-ETE (mean dose, 0.64 mug.kg-1.min-1). Cardiopulmonary exercise tests were performed before initiation of saline and 90 min later during saline, and the end of the control test was compared with the first and final measurement during 5-oxo-ETE administration. A reduction of the forced vital capacity with 5-oxo-ETE was found to reach significance only in women . In addition, flow-volume curves were obtained before initiation and again at 90 min during saline infusion. Significant differences were found from baseline with saline, with decreases in expiratory flows at all lung volumes (18-20%). During 5-oxo-ETE, there was a further significant decrease in expiratory flows; however, in contrast to saline, there was a significant increase in mid-maximal lung volume in the flow-volume curve. These results show that 5-oxo-ETE caused a decrease in lung volumes. However, this was in contradistinction to the effect of saline, in which there was a significant decrease in mid-maximal lung volume, thereby causing a decrease in expiratory flow through the "plateau" portion of the flow-volume curve. Mitochondrial electron transport chain impairment by the fungicide propiconazole through the formation of free radicals.
The fungicide propiconazole (PPZ) causes toxicity via its inhibitory effect on the mitochondrial respiratory chain. The inhibitory effect of PPZ and two of its metabolites (i.e. 2,4-dihydroxybenzophenone and 2,3,39,49,5-pentachlorobiphenyl) on the succinate oxidase activity has been proved in vitro in isolated rat brain mitochondria. The inhibitory effect is prevented by the addition of an uncoupler, showing that the site of PPZ inhibition is due to the complex III (at the level of Q-cycle). In vivo, the inhibition of the metabolic complex III (but not complex IV) is detected in liver, kidney and blood plasma of PPZ-treated rats through the spectrophotometric assay of the activity of complexes III + IV using dinitrophenol and myxothiazol. The free radical scavenger alpha-tocopherol blocks the inhibition of complexes I and III. The inhibition of mitochondrial respiratory complex III appears to depend on the generation of free radicals by propiconazole

Our objective was to evaluate the efficiency and safety of adding a second anti-TNF agent to an initial anti-TNF treatment in anti-TNF refractory CD patients. Data of 59 anti-TNF refractory CD patients treated with a second anti-TNF agent were reviewed. Response was defined as corticosteroid reduction ≥50% versus baseline, corticosteroid free remission or response to a step-up therapy. Response rate and adverse events (AEs) were evaluated at weeks 12 and 52 of therapy. Median clinical follow-up was 24.2 months; median patient follow-up (25-75th percentiles) was 22.5 (11.3-32.6) months. Addition of a second anti-TNF agent was followed by clinical activity improvement in 69.5% of patients (response rate); this response rate dropped to 44.9% during follow-up. Response rates did not differ (1) by anti-TNF combination, (2) between patients in early (<3 years) versus late (≥3 years) onset of anti-TNF refractoriness, (3) between patients using a biologic for <6 or ≥6 months. Response rate was significantly higher in patients with a previous history of anti-TNF drug holidays. Adverse events (54%) were mostly mild. In conclusion among anti-TNF refractory CD, addition of a second anti-TNF agent provided clinical activity improvement in three quarters of the patients (either complete response or partial response). An automated 3D modeling approach to predicting functional morphology and mechanisms of performance enhancement in athletes

Many functional, biomedical, and athletic applications of biomechanics require accurate estimation of both the form (geometry) and the function (behavior) of biological systems. Unfortunately, despite the ubiquitous availability of inexpensive optical motion capture (hereafter capture) of organisms in motion, predicting the function of biological systems by linking geometry to function remains a major challenge in biomechanics. Here we explore an automated method of mapping geometry to function that leverages advances in machine learning to automatically detect, segment, and match organisms, and uses a variety of statistical and morphometric techniques to predict biomechanical performance. We demonstrate application of this method using 3D models of cycling and swimming performance. Our method automates the steps required to model biological systems using optical motion capture data. Cognitive behavioral therapy for depression in adults: a narrative review

Depression is one of the most widespread chronic diseases worldwide. The latest evidence, based on randomized controlled trials, demonstrates the effectiveness of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), either in person or through digital media, as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder. It is recommended for adults of both sexes who meet the diagnostic criteria for depressive disorder according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders. There is also substantial evidence about the effectiveness of CBT in patients with subsyndromal depression, minor depression, and dysthymia. In contrast, there are no studies that have demonstrated the effectiveness of CBT in people with depressive disorder and coexisting psychotic symptoms. There is also no evidence to support the use of individual CBT versus group CBT as part of a treatment approach for patients with depressive disorder. CBT is as effective as other psychotherapies in the treatment of depression. According to a review of the literature, the effect sizes of CBT for depressive disorder range between 0.4 and 2.0, or about 50%, with a mean value of 0.9, at a cutoff point of 0.8. Individual CBT is more effective than psychopharmacotherapy. The studies also demonstrated effectiveness in treating depression using other approaches to cognitive-behavioral therapy with specific interventions, such as the behavioral approach to depression, interpersonal psychotherapy, positive psychology, mindfulness-based therapy, and problem-solving therapy. One of the most important advances of recent years in the use of CBT is the availability of apps for its use. Some of these apps show clinical efficacy in some aspects, while others have some positive results. The implementation of CBT in clinical practice requires the use of appropriate technological instruments. This process requires training and supervision of the professionals so that they can adapt their knowledge and understanding of the basic science and conceptual models of CBT, especially with regard to new techniques or interventions offered online. Following approval of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) in the USA in 1996, there was dramatic reduction in the risk of vertical HIV-1 transmission that now hovers around 2%. [2][3] Today, the use of cART in HIV serodiscordant couples is highly effective in preventing transmission, with a reported efficacy ranging between 51 and 90%. [4][5] The key to prevention of vertical HIV transmission lies in reducing plasma virus with undetectable viral load and therefore minimizing the risk of maternal-fetal transmission. In women who do not receive cART, a high viral load is the best predictor for perinatal virus transmission. [6] In addition, a maternal viral load above 100,000 copies/mL results in a 4%-6% risk of HIV transmission, which rises to 18%-36% when the maternal viral load exceeds 400,000 copies/mL. [7] Since maternal viremia is a strong predictor of perinatal HIV infection, all women with HIV should have a plasma HIV RNA viral load measured by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) at the end of the first trimester, and again at 28-34 weeks of gestation. [8] A PCR result between 500-1,000 copies/mL and 1,000-2,700 copies/mL translates into an approximate 20% and 50% risk of vertical HIV transmission respectively. [9] These data have led to new recommendations from ACOG

Patient-reported outcomes usually include standardized questionnaires and surveys that assess patient's pain levels, disability, function, and other related symptoms. Functional performance tests assess the individual's ability to perform certain activities, such as walking, climbing stairs, or lifting objects. Common tests include the Timed Up and Go test, the Six-Minute Walk Test, and the One-Leg Stand Endurance test.
Quality of life assessments involve evaluating different aspects of a person's well-being, including physical, emotional, social, and financial domains. Some measures include the World Health Organization Quality of Life Instrument, the Short-Form Health Survey - 36 Items (SF-36), and the EuroQol EQ-5D. Methotrexate and the risk of lymphoma and other cancers

Lymphoma (Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), diffuse large B cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) and multiple myeloma) and other cancers are relatively common malignancies in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) on immunosuppressive therapy (IST) including methotrexate (MTX). However, the exact role of individual IST in lymphomagenesis and the risk factors associated with these diseases is not fully elucidated. The prevalence of cancers other than lymphoma is slightly increased in SLE patients, but does not seem to be increased in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients. Several epidemiologic studies have reported an increased incidence of lymphomas within different autoimmune diseases. Several studies demonstrated a protective role of MTX in lymphoma. Several risk factors are suggested to contribute to lymphoma development in SLE patients on IST including female sex, African American ethnicity, higher Systemic Lupus Collaborative Clinics activity index (SLAM score) and higher anti-double-stranded DNA levels. MTX use has a protective effect against lymphomas in SLE patients. We recommend screening all SLE patients on high-dose MTX for lymphoid malignancies, especially those with other risk factors.

OBJECTIVE To determine the prevalence and socioeconomic and epidemiologic associations of diabetes (DM) and impaired fasting glucose (IGF) in a Spanish population. RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS A cross-sectional study of DM and IGF was performed in the Diabetes Epidemiology Study Group of the San Antonio Heat Project, from Navarra. The study population consisted of 600 residents of Navarra aged 55–78 years. The study was performed in 1992 and 1993. Two blood specimens were collected, and a 75-g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) was administered. The diagnosis of diabetes was based on fasting glucose and OGTT plasma glucose determinations. RESULTS The prevalence of DM was 8.8% and was higher in hypertensive subjects than in normotensive subjects (10.1 vs. 8.3%). With regard to other associations, the following results were obtained: an inverse correlation with age and educational level and a direct correlation with smoking, body mass index (BMI), and total/high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol ratio. DM prevalence was higher among women than men but there was little difference in the prevalence of IGF between the two sexes. CONCLUSIONS The prevalence of DM and IGF in Navarra is lower than that found in other studies, but this could be explained by the high prevalence of hypertension in the studied population. The most common NLE manifestations during the neonatal period include hepatitis, myocarditis, arrhythmias, intrauterine growth restriction, and cutaneous involvement. 2 Cardiac involvement in NLE can lead to significant morbidities, including heart dysfunction or failure, pulmonary hypertension (PH), supraventricular or ventricular tachycardia, atrioventricular block, left ventricular hypoplasia, cardiomyopathy, atrial and ventricular septal defects, atrial flutter, and even death. These cases have been more commonly seen in infants with cutaneous manifestations, and usually with the presence of anti-Ro/SSA or anti-La/SSB antibodies. 3 NLE is a rare cause of congenital heart disease, but when diagnosed, it can lead to cardiac defects that affect the outflow tract, valves, atria, and ventricles (as well as septal defects) 4 Most infants with NLE develop cutaneous lesions, and the most common cutaneous lesions are erythematous macules that present in the central face and scalp, and in several days or weeks, progress to a generalized rash. However, the rash is generally not seen in premature infants, particularly those with <35 weeks of gestational age. Prematurely born infants usually present a range of cutaneous manifestations (or even none at all), some of which are atypical and therefore the diagnosis is delayed.
PH has been described in patients with NLE. It has been recognized as an extra-cardiac manifestation of complete or incomplete form of pulmonary venous occlusion. 3 According to the European Network of Congenital Pulmonary Hypertension (PHAE.net), PH is defined as a mean pulmonary artery pressure of ≥25 mmHg in neonates, ≥20 mmHg in older children, and ≥13 mmHg in adults. 5 The association of NLE and PH in premature infants has not been widely reported, although patients suffering from severe pulmonary hypertension (PH) are often premature. Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) promotes chemotactic migration of renal epithelial cells.
VEGF is a potent mitogen, chemokinetic and chemotactic mediator for endothelial cells. Because renal epithelial cells also express VEGF receptors, we evaluated the effect of VEGF on cell migration and chemotaxis by using primary cultures of glomerular visceral epithelial (PEC) and proximal convoluted epithelial cell (PCT) line of PCTs derived from the normal rat kidney (NRK52E) epithelial cells. Chemical and serum deprivation alone only slightly reduced the migration potential of epithelial cells, and this decrease was further reduced by the mitogen angiotensin II (Ang II) or the chemokinetic peptide chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligand 12. Incubation of epithelial cells with VEGF significantly, in a dose-dependent manner, increased the migration of cells, an effect that was inhibited by the addition of anti-VEGF antibodies. A positive control experiment using serum-stimulated NRK52E cell monolayers confirmed the chemotactic effect of VEGF on epithelial cells. These results further suggested that angiogenesis, through expression of VEGF and angiogenic factors by kidney epithelial cells, plays a role in a number of renal injury processes.  Evaluation of the effectiveness of a standardized instruction video for training the newborn neurological exam.
BACKGROUND
In this study, we sought to determine if a standardized instructional supplement (SISS) video improves the ability of an intervention team of neonatal nurse practitioners (NNP) and neonatologists to identify abnormalities during the standardized neurological exam (SNE).


METHODS
Participants received a pretest for recognition of abnormalities on the SNE followed by immediate standardized instructional supplement (SISS) training video review and final pretest. Scores were evaluated and paired t tests performed to evaluate accuracy.


RESULTS
Thirty-three participants (NNP/neonatologists), including 17 interventionists, completed the pre-and posttests. The participants improved the overall mean score from 63.5% ± 18.9% to 82.6% ± 9.3% (p < 0.01). Individually, the intervention group scored 67.7% compared with 51.6% for the nonintervention group (p < 0.01).


CONCLUSIONS
The use of a SISS video improved the ability of the intervention team to score abnormalities, but the impact of this is unclear. Preliminary Results of the Bone Cement Penetration Index in the Vertebroplasty of Osteoporotic Vertebral Compression Fractures

A comparison of an amoxicillin-clavulanate and ceftriaxone plus amikacin combination in the treatment of acute pyelonephritis in children.
A comparative study of an amoxicillin-clavulanate combination (75 mg amoxicillin, 25 mg clavulanate) with ceftriaxone (50 mg) plus amikacin (12.5 mg/kg) was undertaken in 23 children over 1 month of age with acute pyelonephritis. Amoxicillin-clavulanate combination was prescribed for three days, ceftriaxone for two days after which amikacin was replaced with oral amoxicillin. Of the 12 children in each group 4 had catheterized urine samples for microbiology. Eight children had Escherichia coli isolated before therapy, from three anaerobic Gram negative bacilli were isolated, one each from Klebsiella sp., Shigella sonnei and Proteus mirabilis. Bacteriological eradication of the causative micro-organism was seen in 75 and 78% of the patients in the two groups respectively (NS). Clinical cure was seen in 9 of 10 treated with ceftriaxone + amikacin, and in 8 of 12 treated with the amoxicillin-clavulanate combination. No side-effects were seen in either group. Long-term results of conservative management of acute diverticulitis
Abstract Objective. The aim of this study was to analyse the long-term outcome of patients with acute diverticulitis after conservative management and determine whether clinical factors are associated with the occurrence of recurrence. Material and methods. Seventy-seven patients (median age 62) with first-time episodes of acute diverticulitis in 1984–2009 were managed with conservative therapy and then followed indefinitely (median follow-up 25 years). Patients with recurrent diverticulitis were compared with patients with a single episode of disease, and the cumulative recurrence rate was evaluated using competing risk and non-competing risk analyses. Results. There was no significant difference between the groups. Twenty-nine patients (38 percent) were affected by recurrent diverticulitis (8 patients once, 5 times, and 16 patients more than 6 times). The initial characteristics of the 29 patients revealed 17 had complicated uncomplicated diverticulitis, 16 patients had uncomplicated diverticulitis and 2 patients uncomplicated diverticulitis with complications. The overall cumulative (competing-factors) recurrence curve reached 17.7 percent/patient at 20 years. It may be inferred that the recurrence curve continues to increase slowly with time. Conclusion. The long-term outcome of patients with acute diverticulitis managed conservatively is influenced by recurrent diverticulitis and not the occurrence of complications at the primary presentation. Differences in metabolism of benzo(a)pyrene in human colonic and lung tumor cells: role of cytosolic glutathione S-transferase(s).
The ability of benzo(a)pyrene (BaP) to induce tumors in several organs and its carcinogenic nature necessitate the determination of genes involved in its metabolism. BaP is activated and detoxified in humans, but little is known about the inter-individual variability of these metabolic steps. Glutathione S-transferase P1 (GSTP1) has been extensively studied in lung tissue and cells, in view of its putative role in carcinogenesis, but the role of glutathione S-transferase 7-2 (GSTT1) and 7-3 (GSTT2), and GST pi (GSTP1) and alpha (GSTA1) in cytosolic and mitochondrial metabolism of substrates in the colonic adenocarcinoma cell line HT-29 and the lung carcinoma cell line A549 has yet to be established. We found that the activities of both cytosolic GSTs and mitochondrial mono-, di-, and trihydroxylation of BaP were different in the two tumor cell lines, suggesting that they have specific properties. This implies that the metabolism of BaP in cells at the target site may differ considerably from the situation in normal human cells, and from that of cells from other organs. groundtruth: Great. Now, let's move on to designing the outcome measures. We can start with the primary outcome measure. Do you have any ideas for the primary outcome measure?

That's a great suggestion. The percentage of complete follow up is crucial to determine the overall feasibility of the intervention and study design. We can measure the percentage rate of those who complete the study follow-up measures at 9 weeks and 3 months. This will provide valuable information on the reliability of the results obtained.

Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.
