Certainly! For the secondary outcome measures, we can consider the following:
1. "Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced": This measure will provide valuable information on the level of physical activity and sports participation of patients post-surgery. It would quantify the number of sport units per week and the variety of sport disciplines practiced. This will help us evaluate the impact of the surgical intervention on patients' ability to engage in sports.
2. "Length of sport units": Measuring the length of sport units in minutes will give us insight into the intensity and duration of physical activity patients are able to perform post-surgery. This information is important in assessing the functional outcomes and endurance of patients following the surgical intervention.
3. "Range of motion after surgery": Evaluating the range of motion in degrees after surgery is essential in determining the success of the surgical reconstruction in restoring normal joint function. Changes in range of motion can indicate improvements or limitations in mobility and flexibility post-surgery.
4. "Subjective change of instability after surgery": Using a visual analog scale to assess subjective changes in instability post-surgery will provide valuable information on patients' perception of their joint stability. This outcome measure allows for the evaluation of functional outcomes related to stability and balance following the surgical intervention.
5. "Change of pain after surgery": Measuring changes in pain levels using a visual analog scale is important in assessing the effectiveness of the surgical intervention in reducing pain associated with insertional Achilles tendinopathy. Patients' pain levels can significantly impact their ability to participate in sports and physical activities.
6. "Satisfaction with result": Assessing patients' satisfaction with the surgical result using a visual analog scale provides insight into their overall experience and outcomes following the intervention. Patient satisfaction is an important indicator of treatment success and can influence their quality of life and willingness to engage in sports activities.

Certainly! Here are the measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures:
1. "Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced": This measure will be reported in absolute numbers and should be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.
2. "Length of sport units": The measure for the length of sport units will be reported in minutes and also assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.
3. "Range of motion after surgery": This measure will be reported in degrees and should be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.
4. "Subjective change of instability after surgery": The measure for subjective change of instability will be assessed using a visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means no instability and 10 means worst instability. This measure should also be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.
5. "Change of pain after surgery": The measure for change of pain will be assessed using a visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means no pain and 10 means worst pain. This measure should be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.
6. "Satisfaction with result": The measure for satisfaction with the surgical result will be assessed using a visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means not satisfied and 10 means maximum satisfaction. This measure should also be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.

Prevalence and correlates of suicidal ideation as measured using the Suicidal Ideation Questionnaire 5 in three samples of Chinese elderly people This study examined the prevalence of suicidal ideation (SI) in older Chinese people and its association with various correlates. For this cross-sectional retrospective study, 1,596 community-dwelling individuals aged 60 years or above were recruited from three regions in mainland China. Socio-demographic characteristics, health conditions, and loneliness and family support were measured through a structured questionnaire, while psychological characteristics were assessed based on the Zung Self-Rating Anxiety Scale, Zung Self-Rating Depression Scale, and Suicidal Ideation Questionnaire 5. Statistical analyses were performed to determine the prevalence of SI and its relationship with mental health and socio-demographic correlates. The prevalence of active suicidal ideation was 5.85% in the total sample, and was lower in the urban sample (3.48%) than in the other two samples (1.18% rural and 8.33% agricultural). Older adults with SI were significantly older, more likely to be male and have lower educational levels, poor health, worse psychological health, and lower levels of family support. Higher levels of perceived loneliness and poorer family support were significantly associated with all suicidal behaviors. Our study reveals a lower rate of SI in older Chinese adults than in the global average. The correlates of suicidal ideation were similar across various studies. Public health interventions aimed at reducing the prevalence of SI among the elderly should focus on psychopathology, loneliness, and family support.AbbreviationsSAS Zung Self-Rating Anxiety Scale SDDS Zung Self-Rating Depression Scale SIQ-5 Suicidal Ide

Antisocial and psychopathic traits in psychiatric inpatients: gender differences and comorbidity
Synopsis This study examined gender differences in antisocial and psychopathic traits as well as the comorbidity of these traits in a diverse group of psychiatric inpatients. Subjects were 101 depressed and non-depressed inpatients (14 male, 87 female) referred for psychometric testing by their psychiatrists. As measured by the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM III Personality and Axis II Disorders, women were less likely than men to have a psychopathic personality disorder (PPP), but, if PPP was present, there was a significantly greater co-occurrence of psychopathy in men than in women. Axis II diagnoses in this group suggested that comorbidity was common among personality disorders but did not appear to distinguish PPP from other personality disorders in this group. Overall, these results indicate a need to consider gender in research on antisocial traits and, as well, the utility of the DSM-III PPP diagnosis in psychiatric research and practice. The influence of adrenalectomy and replacement therapy on some of the activities of the brain.
The effects of adrenalectomy and glucocorticoid replacement therapy on some aspects of rat brain function were investigated. 1. After 2 and 5 weeks of adrenalectomy the ability of the rat brain to convert choline to acetylcholine is increased, the enzyme is in a more active state. Other activities of the brain, however, are unaffected by adrenalectomy. 2. Corticosterone replacement therapy for 2 weeks reverses the effect of adrenalectomy on the acetylcholine-forming ability of the brain. 3. Corticosterone replacement therapy over a long period of time, however, raises the acetylcholine- and choline-utilizing enzyme activities of the brain. Moreover, during corticosterone replacement therapy the basal metabolic rate (BMR) of adrenalectomized rats is lowered to the level observed with normal rats. .

# Scope
These SOPs apply to all staff working on the project, including study team members, sponsored trainees and volunteers. The primary aim of this SOP is to provide a framework for the standardization and adherence of quality assurance throughout the project study life cycle.
# Standard Operating Procedure
1. Establish a steering committee (SC), which consists of at least one scientist at the coordinating site and every international site with active researchers.
2. The SC is accountable to PI.
3. Each SC member must be informed about the content of this SOP.
4. The SC members must make it part of the routine study procedures.
5. The SC is not to make any study-related decisions without prior approval from, and in consultation with, the investigators. The SC is responsible for the study procedures, budget and overall responsibility for the project in their countries.
6. The SC has the authority to make decisions on the allocation of resources allocated by each institution, the recruitment of patients or volunteers at all sites, as well as the inclusion criteria for participation of a site.
7. To ensure that all study procedures are executed according to the study protocols and SOPs, it is essential to have all study staff trained and certified prior to commencement of recruitment.
8. The SC is to meet, usually once every three or four months, to discuss study progress and the outcome of any discussions with the PI.
9. The SC can only decide to initiate or close parts of the study that do not require protocol changes.
10. The SC shall be made aware of the study start‐up (baseline questionnaire or examinations at baseline), the inclusion rates and the recruitment progress (new sites). In addition, the SC shall be made aware of all changes in enrollment procedures, eligibility criteria and other criteria needed to describe a patient as recruited, screened positively, entered into the protocol or started on the intervention.
11. The inclusion of a new site or investigator will only be accepted by the SC after all investigators on the site have given approval. The investigator at each site has the right to withdraw.

A Case Report of Immune Checkpoint Inhibitor-Related Cutaneous Sarcoidosis

a b s t r a c tSarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disease that affects genetically susceptible individuals with a Th1-type immune response to pathogens. Cancer immunotherapies targeting anti-PD-1 antigen and CTLA-4 have immunomodulating effects, leading to immune-related adverse effects (irAEs). Here, we report the first case of cutaneous sarcoidosis following anti-PD-1 treatment of lung adenocarcinoma. A 62-year-old male who was started on pembrolizumab 3 weeks prior developed persistent erythematous, well-demarcated, and infiltrated papules on the trunk and lower limbs for 6 weeks. He has previously been treated for the same tumor with both pembrolizumab and nivolumab twice without dermatologic irAEs. Biopsy of the lesion showed non-caseating granuloma with numerous epithelioid histiocytes. In situ hybridization revealed that CD4, CD8, and CD45RO were all positive. Additionally, CD163, an M2 type macrophage marker, was expressed with in the histiocytes. Histopathologic findings, including histiocytes in histiocytic infiltrate, positive CD4 and CD45RO, and positive CD163, were compatible with a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. Discontinuing immunotherapy with pembrolizumab was done. Oral prednisolone was started with a tapering plan over 4 months. To date, the lesions are resolved, and it has been 1 year of follow-up without disease relapse.This case suggests that PD-1 blockade may upregulate the expression of antigens that promote a Th1-type immune response to sarcoidosis antigens.

Let's summarize the outcome measures we have so far:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. CRT maximal amplitude: This measure assesses the maximal amplitude of the CRT test, reflecting the overall coagulation profile of the patient within 24 hours.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. CK reaction time: The value of the r-time of the CK test.
2. CK alpha angle: The value of the alpha angle of the CK test.
3. CRT maximal lysis: The value of maximal lysis of the CRT test.
4. CFF maximal amplitude: The value of maximal amplitude of the CFF test.
5. Hemoglobin: Serum hemoglobin value.
6. Packed RBC: Number of units of transfused packed RBC within 6 hours.
7. Fresh frozen plasma: Number of units of transfused fresh frozen plasma within 6 hours.
8. Cryoprecipitate: Number of units of transfused cryoprecipitate within 6 hours.
9. Platelet: Number of units of transfused platelet (apheresis) or platelet concentrate within 6 hours.
10. Seizure: Incidence of postoperative seizure within 48 hours.
11. Thromboembolism: Incidence of postoperative myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, pulmonary thrombosis, and intestinal infarction within 48 hours.
12. Postoperative bleeding: Amount of bleeding from surgical drains within 48 hours.
13. Re-operation: Incidence of re-operation due to postoperative bleeding within 48 hours.

Macro-initiators based on 2-ethyl-2-oxazoline were synthesized to investigate the effect of chain-end functional groups on the hydration properties of the macro-oligosaccharides. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and 1 H NMR analyses confirmed successful synthesis of the macromer. As the ratio of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid to divinylbenzene was increased, the DS of ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid was decreased. 2-Ethyl-2-oxazolinemacromer was confirmed as a water-soluble macromer with D 2 O NMR spectroscopy. For determining hydration of the macro-oligosaccharide chain, an NMR probe was designed to directly load the solution into the NMR spectrometer. It enabled rapid determination of hydration ratio within minutes. The obtained hydration ratio showed that the ratio of backbone to end group of macro-oligosaccharides was an important factor for determining the hydration properties.

# Introduction
2-ethyl-2-oxazoline (ETO) is a polymeric material. The characteristic of ETO is a hydrophilic backbone with high glass transition (T g ) temperature. Therefore, ETO is typically used to construct macromolecular systems such as hydrosol solutions or thermoreversible gels. Furthermore, since ETO has a unique polar structure, it is often used as a hydrophilic chain end. The ETO's hydrophilic chain end is functionalized by a conjugated group or a non-conjugated group. By changing the nature of the chain end group, the ETO-based macromers can be utilized in diverse biomedical applications, such as smart hydrogels, drug-delivery systems, scaffolds for tissue regeneration and drug-elution system.

Clinical Trials are expensive and complex research, which requires proper planning. As well as ensuring your study objectives can be achieved, it’s vital that you design your outcome measures with ease of interpretation in mind. If you leave your statistical analysis to the end it can cause some serious problems. For one thing, it could put undue strain on your budget, by which point most trial expenses are locked in. Avoid this by designing your study now with an understanding of the types of data you plan to analyse, and what you wish to see happen.
In our previous postwe covered the first fundamental component of outcome measures, primary outcomes. This post will explore the second fundamental component, secondary outcomes. It will cover what to measure, why to measure it, when to measure it, how to measure it, how to interpret it, and we will finish by summarizing what we covered on how to combine your results. Don’t forget if you have designed your secondary outcome measures with ease of interpretation in mind then your results will be more useful to you and the others that need to scrutinise them.
Designing Secondary Outcome Measures
There are four things you need to consider when designing secondary outcome measures:
- Why
- What
- When
- How
Each of these fundamental components of outcome measures will be discussed individually below.
Why
The why is about the reason that you have decided to include something in your secondary outcome measures. Perhaps you think this particular thing is important, and you want to try and change it, improve it, or otherwise measure how it changes.
It’s important to think about these things before selecting secondary outcome measures, as you want to know if you have selected the ‘right’ secondary outcome measures. For example, if you are thinking that you want to reduce the pain of those in your study, then you probably shouldn’t choose to measure the amount of time they spend sleeping, as reducing the pain is more likely to have an effect on the amount of pain they suffer throughout the day, and less likely to have an effect on how much sleep they get. In that case, rather than measuring how long your pain patients in your study sleep each night, you should measure other things.
- Is my treatment giving pain sufferers a sense of wellbeing?
- Does my treatment reduce or lessen any of the problems associated with my illness?
- Does my treatment less

Disease control rate (DCR) is an important metric in cancer treatment, defined as the percentage of patients who experience either a confirmed complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD) for a period of time. It is a measure of a therapy's effectiveness and safety. In this context, disease control rates for RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 assess the percentage of patients who achieved at least a 30% or 50% reduction in tumor volume, or a stable disease (i.e., no increase in tumor volume) for a period of time. To calculate this score, we can compare the total tumor volume before the treatment starts and after a set number of months—perhaps three months or six months—to determine whether or not the treatment worked. If the therapy is successful at controlling the tumor volume, the patient will have a higher DCR score, which could indicate a more positive outcome and higher chance of survival.

Duration of response (DoR) in YL201 treatment of mCRPC is a critical measure that can provide insights into the length of time cancer patients can remain in remission after treatment. Doctors consider this measure during the evaluation of treatment outcomes, but it's not often reported. A successful treatment of mCRPC, for example, may include a large percentage of patients who no longer require further treatment due to lack of disease progression or toxicities associated with other treatments. Thus, longer DoR may indicate a more favorable outcome for these patients as their life may be extended longer with the treatment. While a treatment's efficacy is an important factor, more importantly, a therapy's ability to achieve long-lasting remission and reduce recurrence is essential in mCRPC. In this context, a DoR for YL201 would be defined as the length of time a patient remains in a predefined response state, such as complete response (CR), where the size of tumor or other related disease is not changing to a significantly greater extent than what could be accounted for by chance alone.

Time to objective response (TTR) for YL201 provides valuable information about how long patients must wait to determine whether or not the treatment is effective. Understanding TTR can provide insight into the time frame for response, facilitate clinical decision-making, and help

A randomized controlled trial (RCT) is a study design that compares the effectiveness of one treatment to another. The participants are randomly assigned to one of the two groups and the study is then controlled for all confounding factors.
An RCT can have one or more arms, each arm representing a treatment group. Often there are three arms in an RCT, which may be a placebo, or a control or an active treatment group.
An RCT is very useful for assessing the efficacy of new treatments. Researchers run an RCT to compare the new treatment with existing standard treatments. They randomize the participants in the RCT to each group, and then record any positive or negative effects the treatments have on the individuals. The positive effects of the trial drugs can then be observed more accurately once the RCT is conducted.
RCTs are often seen as the gold standard in terms of scientific rigor, however, they can still have some limitations. One of the possible issues regarding randomization is that participants are blind to the actual treatment they are receiving, and therefore could introduce bias.
Another limitation of randomization is the problem of adherence. If the participants in a study do not adhere to the treatment, then the results of the study might not be reliable. Radiographic progression-free survival (rPFS) measures the time from the date of first administration to first documented progressive disease (PD) per RECIST1.1 and PCWG3 criteria, or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. OBJECTIVES To confirm the efficacy and duration of efficacy of the SIRB compared to that of a conventional ivermectin bolus at killing adult nematodes, and to assess the level of reemergence of nematodes, if any, in horses following a second treatment. METHODS Horses were assigned to treatment with the SIRB (n = 17) and conventional ivermectin bolus (n = 7) or to the untreated control (n = 6). RESULTS After the first treatment the nematode egg output was reduced by 55 and 50% in the ivermectin bolus and SIRB treated horses, compared with that in the control horses. After the second treatment the second treatment, the SIRB continued to reduce the average FEC by 76% (P < 0.05), while the FEC increased slightly in the conventional ivermectin bolus treated horses and was at the same level in the control horses. CONCLUSIONS AND PAYOUT The results show both treatments to be equally efficacious in the initial reduction of adult parasite numbers, but highlight differences in the efficacy of the second treatment and that of a single treatment, with clearance in the SIRB group having been achieved after 6 months, while the conventional bolus has failed to do so. # Introduction
Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a common neuropsychiatric condition, with typical earlyonset signs and symptoms including hyperactivity, inattention, and impulsivity which persist into adulthood. The neurobiological mechanisms of ADHD remain ambiguous. Previous studies have shown that ADHD is under genetic control, with familial aggregation accounting for as much as 70-80% of the total variation in risk for ADHD. Currently, several lines of evidence support an association between ADHD and the 7q36 fragile X region. The genetic component of ADHD is the largest of all psychiatric disorders. Therefore, identifying individual gene variation will contribute to a better understanding of ADHD.
The etiology of ADHD is complicated and may involve interactions among multiple genetic and environmental factors. Both genetic and environmental factors are important to the pathogenesis of ADHD. ADHD is polygenic and genetically heterogeneous, involving a variety of different risk factors. In the UK in 2008-2009, spending attributable to complementary medicine (including over-the-counter (OTC) medicine and dietary supplements) was estimated at £2299-£2647million, equivalent to between 0.4% and 0.6% of the total UK National Health Service budget. This estimate, based on sales data, was £633-£797million in the category of OTC medicines and dietary supplements alone. The cost of OTC medical devices is not included in the estimate, but the expenditure on these is estimated at £108-£130million, including the cost of 'homeopathy' and 'herbal medicines'. The most important components of this class of medicine are acupuncture, herbal medicine, homeopathy and anthroposophic medicine, which, in the UK and the USA, is known as 'vitamin C'. Homeopathy is used in cancer, asthma, cystitis, arthritis, rheumatism, tinnitus, menopausal and climacteric disorders and the treatment of chronic fatigue syndrome, irritable bowel syndrome and the common cold. Other therapies include 'reflex therapy', 'biofeedback' and magnetic field therapy. These are based on the principle that body functions, particularly cardiorespiratory rhythms, are affected by disturbances in the normal balance of the electromagnetic fields of the human body.

Otogenic brain abscesses are, even in the modern antibiotic era, a rare disease. We herewith report two cases. Both young children, 7 and 10 years of age, presented with ear discharge during the summer and a mild temperature. The ear disease was diagnosed a couple of months after initial presentation. The children underwent myringotomy at the age of 9 months or 6 years, and the myringoplasty was performed at the age of 1 year or 4 1/2 years. The pathogens found were Staphylococcus aureus in one case and Streptococcus pneumoniae plus Haemophilus type influenzae in the other case. The patients were not given any antibiotic after myringoplasty and recovered in good condition. The myringoplasty performed using perichondrium as a patch graft is considered to be adequate not only for the size of the tympanic membrane defect, but also for the age of the patient. There are several secondary outcome measures in this study. The first is the assessment of lung function parameters such as the forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) and the forced vital capacity (FVC). This measures the airflow obstruction indicative of COPD and provides valuable information on the disease’s progression. The second is the measurement of plasma IL-18 levels, which is elevated in many inflammatory disorders including COPD. This is a biomarker that measures the extent of inflammation and can help predict disease progression. The third is the assessment of quality of life, which is directly impacted by COPD symptoms such as cough and shortness of breath. This is measured using the Medical Outcomes Study 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey (SF-36), which consists of domains such as physical health, role limitations due to physical health problems, emotional health, and social functioning. The last is measurement of exacerbation rates of COPD, which are defined as any episode of acute deterioration that requires hospitalization or the use of oral or intravenous corticosteroids or antibiotics. These criteria were agreed upon by the International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research and the European Society of Respiratory Medicine. These secondary outcome measures help assess the overall impact on the participant’s health and well-being during the study. They also provide valuable insight into treating a debilitating disease such as COPD. The Effect of Substance Use on Health Outcomes in Patients Diagnosed With HIV
Objective: The aim of this study is to examine the effect of substance use on HIV-related health outcomes, including HIV viral load (HVL), CD4 cell count, and adherence. Primary care clinicians (PCCs) must be able to screen for substance use and provide proper referrals and treatment. Methods: A retrospective chart review of patients with HIV/AIDS seen for care at the University of Kansas Medical Center in January 2010 was conducted. Patients were included if they: were 18 to 65 years of age; diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV); and had at least one substance use screen within the prior year (N = 19). Chart review revealed information about substance use, including positive toxicology screens, current or previous active treatment, referrals to outside resources, and CD4 cell counts and HVL measurements. The patients selected for this study were considered “heavy substance users” if they reported alcohol, marijuana, cigarette or prescription-drug abuse in the past 3 months or had significant drug or alcohol-related health issues. Of the 19 patients selected, 7 (37%) were considered heavy substance users. Results: There were three CD4 cell count ranges for heavy substance users compared with four for nonheavy substance users. For HVL status, there were two ranges for heavy substance users compared with three for nonheavy substance users. Although HVL rates were higher for heavy substance users, overall the study population showed an average of good adherence to medication. Conclusions: Patients were fairly adherent with medication despite the high number of patients who received positive drug or alcohol screens. Substance use continues to be a barrier for PCCs in treating patients with HIV/AIDS. Clinicians treating HIV/AIDS patients should use a universal screening method for patients who are experiencing substance use issues. If appropriate, clinicians should make the referrals or make appointments at local resources to better tailor the patient's care to their unique needs. .

A novel splice variant of TGFBR3 gene is associated with schizophrenia

Objective: Schizophrenia is a common, severe mental disorder that causes lifelong disability affects 0.8% to 2.7% of population worldwide. TGFβ receptor 3 (TGFBR3) is a critical gene that encode transforming growth factor β receptor, which is involved in the neurodevelopment and synaptic plasticity. It remains unclear whether TGFBR3 gene is associated with schizophrenia.Methods:We recruited 813 schizophrenia patients and 877 healthy controls from China. This was the first time that we evaluated association between TGFBR3 gene and schizophrenia by genome-wide association study (GWAS) and replication analysis.Results:We found that TGFBR3 gene and its intronic loci rs1011171 and rs10112226 showed significant association with schizophrenia. Gene score analysis revealed that haplotypes GAAA and GAGA of rs1011171 and rs10112226 were associated with susceptibility of schizophrenia. Conclusions: This is the first time that we found that the novel splice variant of TGFBR3 gene and its intronic loci rs1011171 and rs10112226 were associated with schizophrenia susceptibility, providing a novel perspective of gene discoveries related to schizophrenia. Effect of anastomosis on flow within the main vessels of the thoracic and abdominal vascular bed.
Blood flow through the vascular bed of the rabbit hindlimb was studied in three groups of vessels: 1) those between the abdomen and the thorax (abdominal-thoracic anastomosis ), 2) the femoral arteries of the hindlimb (FA) alone, and 3) the femoral veins of the hindlimb only (FV). For each vessel, flow as a percentage of cardiac output was continuously recorded and recorded in two conditions: 1) following surgery and 2) at the time of sacrifice five days later. The post-operative FA and FV flow rates were not significantly different from the immediate post-surgical period. The FA to FV ratio was 1.407 ± 0.27. This suggested that, in the five days that elapsed following surgery, blood had been diverted away from the FA and toward the FV. It is suggested that the major influence upon post operative vasomotor activity was the degree of venous congestion. It is hypothesized that vasomotor activity is related to the degree of congestion in each section of the systemic vasculature. The aim of this study was to examine the effects of ageing and gender on the responses of rat myofibres to ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) of the anterior tibial artery, with and without ischemic preconditioning (IP). I/R was induced by a 60 min ligation followed by a 48 h reperfusion. IP was induced by two 15 min occlusions. The responses of myofibrillar, mitochondrial H(+)-ATPase activities and sarcomere length were assessed. I/R induced myofibrillar, mitochondrial inhibition and a decrease in sarcomere length of the slow-oxidative myofibres. IP reversed the myofibrillar and mitochondrial inhibition and the change in sarcomere length. The decrease in myofibrillar activity was larger in young than in old rats. The decrease in mitochondrial H(+)-ATPase activity with IP was larger in young than in old rats. In contrast to the decrease in mitochondrial activity, the IP-resistance of slow-oxidative myofibres was unrelated to age. Psychologist Dr. Andrew Bartha developed a list of tests and evaluations to assess the patients he treated at Boston University in the 1920s to help guide his mental analysis of various conditions... This was the "Boston Psychological Test".
One of the questionnaires was the PDQ - the Pattern Discrimination Questionnaire. The PDQ was designed by Bartha as a more convenient alternative to a more lengthy test, the Stanford Binet Intelligence Test, which consisted of four parts. The PDQ used short questions that could be answered with yes or no based on patterns and images presented as visual stimuli with four response options to evaluate a participant' behavior, mental activity, and the degree of their psychological maturity. He concluded that the PDQ was a viable option to measure intelligence and mental activity.
After several modifications to the original test, Albert H. Henshaw wrote a new series of questions that evaluated a subject's intelligence and personality. These questions were tested in the Harvard community in 1936 and the test was termed the Henshaw-Tilden Mental Test. The test contained three sets of five questions. When comparing the original test to the Henshaw-Tilden Mental Test, it seemed to be more appropriate to use both series together instead of one alone.
Bartha decided to further modify his test by combining the more accurate questions about intelligence and personality. Henshaw modified his mental test, resulting in the introduction of the PPQ - Pattern and Personality Quesionnaire and the RIQ - Rank Influence Questionnaires in 1948.
We also considered a more recent PDQ-4-SV, which is based on DSM-IV-TR Axis I and II. .

OBJECTIVE
To investigate the effect and underlying mechanism of electro-acupuncture (EA) on gastric emptying in diabetic rats.


METHODS
One month after a single intraperitoneal injection of streptozotocin (ZT), thirty five SD rats were randomly divided into a normal group, a model group (ZT), and a EA (ZT + EA) group. EA was applied to " Zusanli" (ST 36) and "Shangjuxu " (ST 37) for 2 weeks after successful establishment of the model. Gastric emptying rate was detected by gamma scintigraphy before and after EA intervention. The expression of ghrelin receptor in antrum and duodenum was detected by immunohistochemistry before and after EA intervention. The expression of ghrelin receptor mRNA in antrum and duodenum was detected by reverse transcription and polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) before and after EA intervention.


RESULTS
Compared with normal group, ZT model rats showed delayed gastric emptying rate and down-regulated expression of ghrelin receptor mRNA in two segment of gastrointestinal tract (P < 0.05). After EA intervention, the delayed gastric emptying rate in ZT rats was improved significantly compared with that of ZT rats (P < 0.05), the expression levels of ghrelin receptor mRNA were up-regulated in two segment of gastrointestinal tract (P < 0.05).


CONCLUSIONS
Diabetic rats show delayed gastric emptying, down-regulation of ghrelin receptor mRNA expression in two segment of gastrointestinal tract and EA can improve delayed gastric emptying and up-regulate ghrelin receptor mRNA expressions in antrum

High-resolution computed tomography findings in lung disease in rheumatoid arthritis.
High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) was performed in 79 patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) who had interstitial lung disease (ILD), with the purpose of finding the frequency of specific HRCT findings in the lungs of RA patients with ILD and to compare the HRCT findings with lung biopsy and lung function measurements in order to find the usefulness of HRCT findings in the diagnosis and prognosis of the disease. The HRCT scan revealed that the lungs of 24 patients had various infiltrative, reticular or cystic lesions on the scans, as well as ground glass opacity or both of these findings. Bronchial wall thickness was more common than the other manifestations on the CT scans. 53 patients showed findings of a predominantly normal, non-specific pattern of lung involvement. Thereafter, a correlation study was performed to establish the correlation between the HRCT manifestations and the lung biopsy specimen or lung function parameters. There was no correlation between the lung biopsy specimen or the lung function parameters, as demonstrated by high resolution computed tomography. In this study a large number of RA patients had interstitial lung disease with high resolution computed tomography. High resolution computed tomography is a useful diagnostic tool for the evaluation of lung disease in RA and has additional value. Discoloration can pose a significant problem for dental restorative materials. It can compromise the appearance and function of restorations, resulting in dental replacement procedures. The color of restorations can also affect the dentist’s rating of the materials success. Certain factors can contribute to the marginal discoloration of dental restorations, including inadequate polymerization, over-contouring, and material selection. Inadequate polymerization can lead to decreased strength and less favorable mechanical properties of restorations. Over-contouring can create voids and micro leaks, which can allow for staining agents such as blood, saliva, and bacteria to infiltrate. Material selection can also be a factor in marginal discoloration, with some materials being prone to staining more than others. Some commonly used materials, such as composite and amalgam, can stain over time. These discoloration problems can be avoided with proper polymerization procedures, appropriate contouring, and the selection of materials that are resistant to staining.

It assesses any loss of restorative material. We'll need to evaluate retention from baseline to 24 months.

The scoring criteria for retention will be based on the United States Public Health Service criteria. We'll use the following scores: Alfa for no loss of restorative material, Charlie for any loss of restorative material. These scores will help us assess the effectiveness of the deep margin elevation technique in improving the stability and longevity of the restorations.

Marginal discoloration is an important measure to evaluate the sealing ability of the restorations and the presence of any gaps or defects at the restoration margins. We'll assess marginal discoloration using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration, Bravo for discoloration without penetration in pulpal direction, and Charlie for discoloration with penetration in pulpal direction. The evaluation will be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

Marginal adaptation focuses on the precision and fit of the restorations. We'll evaluate it using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. Two independent clinicians will visually inspect the restorations with a mirror. The scores will be Alfa for closely adapted with no visible crevice, Bravo for a visible crevice where an explorer can penetrate, and Charlie for a crevice in which dentin is exposed. This evaluation will also be done from baseline to 24 months.

Secondary caries is an important consideration for the long-term success of restorations. We'll evaluate the presence of secondary caries using the United States Public Health Service criteria. The scores will be Alfa for no caries presented and Charlie for caries present. This evaluation will also be conducted from baseline to 24 months.

# Background - Research area

# Background - Scope
- The project explores the relationship between chronic kidney disease (CKD) and mental health as measured by generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), major depressive episode (MDE), suicidality, substance use disorder (SUD), binge eating disorder (BED) and other types of anxiety/depressive disorder.
- Mental health refers to the ability to recognize emotionally-salient stimuli, effectively regulate emotion, and effectively communicate and cope with the emotional implications of life events.
- CKD - kidney damage for ≥3 months
- CKD - glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <60 mL/min/1.73m2
- CKD - urine ACR >30mg/g for >6 months
- ACR - albumin-creatinine ratio
- ACR - urine albumin to urine creatinine ratio
- GFR - glomerular filtration rate

# Background - Overview
- In the USA, it is estimated that 5% of people (or 21 million) have CKD and about one in 10 adults (18 million) have GFR<60 mL/M2 (1). Among people with GFR<60 mL/min/1.73m2, 10.6% of people report anxiety and 19.1% report depression.
- CKD is not only a risk factor for cardio-and cerebrovascular disease via vascular calcification, but also for various co-morbidities, including mood and anxiety disorders, insomnia, hypertension and CAN.
- CAN, otherwise called 'malnutrition-inflammation complex syndrome', appears to involve chronic inflammation and malnutrition and leads to protein energy wasting syndrome, sarcopenia, and decreased insulin sensitivity. All of these contribute to CKD progression and increased mortality.
- CKD and kidney failure increase the prevalence of symptoms that lead to depression and anxiety, as well as depression and anxiety.  It

Inhibition of endogenous nitric oxide generation reduces the development of hypertension by a high cholesterol diet in normotensive rabbits
The present study was designed to determine whether inhibition of endogenous nitric oxide (NO) generation reduces the development of hypertension by high cholesterol diet in normotensive rabbits. Male New Zealand white rabbits aged 12 to 14 weeks were fed a cholesterol (HCD) or normal chow diet (NCD) and given either vehicle (ethanol, ET), nonselective NO generation inhibitor NG‐nitro‐L‐arginine methyl ester (L‐NAME; 1 mg mL−1), or isosorbide‐5‐mononitrate trihydrate (IS‐5 MN, 0.4 mg mL−1) for 4 consecutive weeks. Blood pressure (BP), plasma endothelin‐1 (ET‐1), nitrite levels, and urinary nitrate/nitrite levels were measured. Compared with NCD controls, HCD‐induced hypertension was associated with an increase in plasma ET‐1 levels. Urinary nitrate/nitrite excretion was decreased in HCD group but plasma nitrite levels were not significantly changed in HCD. The expression levels of several biomarker candidates for drug resistance were examined in MTX-R and TXn-R cells using a panel of biomarker discovery microarray. # Overview
Limb lengthening procedure is a surgical procedure conducted to increase the leg size by a surgical gap.  It may be performed as a  single stage procedure or in  two stages, wherein the lengthening is stopped in the mid-term followed by a second stage for completion of the lengthening.  This is a major procedure performed in specialized centers with a team of orthopaedic and plastic surgeons. 

# Indications
- Limb Length Discrepancy due to congenital disorders
- Traumatic Loss
- Infections, nonunion, malunion
- Hemihypertrophy
- Lengthening of the leg for an amputation stump
- Charcot arthropathy

# IAP for Limb Lengthening
- IAP for lengthening may be performed as a one stage surgery in patients with 0 to 1 cm leg deformity or in a two-stage procedure wherein the lengthening is stopped in between with wound healing and then a second stage is planned at the end to complete the lengthening.
- The distraction rate and lengthening ratio will be determined as per the table below:

# Pre-operative Planning - Staging
- Planning of lengthening may involve the planning of stages or may be done as a single stage procedure.  In the single stage procedure, the leg deformity is corrected and lengthening is planned in one operation. This may be done in patients with leg deformity <0.5 cm or for lengthening up to <5 cm. 
- For greater bone defects, leg lengthening is performed in a two stage procedure, i.e. the leg is lengthened up to <5 cm and the deformity is corrected. This is done with wound healing as an interim stage and the leg is then lengthened in a second stage.
- The planning and timing of stages depend upon the defect size, the child's growth and the surgeon's preference. 
- The timing of stages depends upon the defect size, age of the patient, growth pattern and surgeon preference.

There are also certain considerations based on the design of the study 

### Statistical issues
Statistical significance does not mean clinical relevance. 

### Economic evaluation
Economic issues must be considered if a trial is planned to be conducted in a cost-effectiveness and/or cost-utility analysis. For economic evaluation, the quality of life (QoL) tools must be validated before use and must be standardized for comparison. If the patients are not willing to participate in the studies, the QoL will be unreliable. Furthermore, the outcomes of the QoL tool may not reflect the patient’s priorities, and this will cause the study results to be questionable.

> If a 1000-pound sum is allocated to each patient based on the results of the trial, the results will be unreliable and the economic value will be reduced. This also happens when the results are published in a journal with a limited influence factor or no journal but not a peer-reviewed journal article. 
> > To address this problem, the study funding application or peer-reviewed journal articles should follow the Standards of Reporting Trials (SORT) statement for trial report publication.
> > SORT is a statement, but not a reporting guideline; therefore, there are some issues remaining such as ethical considerations, funding applications, study conduct (data collection, statistical analyses, economic evaluation), and outcome validity. The SORT was designed for the following outcome reporting: participants, intervention, control, outcome assessed, and time-points. 
> > SORT for outcomes: ○ Participants’ socio-demographic characteristics and description will be reported in the introduction.

That's a great choice for a primary outcome measure. To measure the functional muscle power output of the leg, we can use the cycle sprint test. This test measures the maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts from three times 10-second maximal efforts. Higher values indicate better muscle power output. We can assess this outcome measure at different time points: preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

Absolutely! For measuring muscle strength, we can use the manual muscle testing (MMT) as a standardized measuring tool. The patient, in a sitting position with 20 degrees knee flexion, will be asked to actively extend the knee against resistance proximal to the ankle. We'll use the numeric score 0-5 from the Daniels and Worthingham Scale to assess quadriceps muscle strength. Higher values indicate better muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To measure mobility, we can use the timed up and go test (TUG). This test is a standardized measuring tool that times the patient's ability to rise from an armchair, walk to a line on the floor 3 meters away, turn, and walk back to the chair. Lower values on the TUG test indicate better mobility. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

For clinical results, we can include parameters such as redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. These parameters will provide a comprehensive evaluation of the clinical outcomes and potential complications associated with the surgery and nerve blocks. We can assess these clinical results at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To assess radiological results, we can use x-rays, including ap and lateral views, patella views, and whole leg axis views. These x-rays will help us evaluate the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. We can assess radiological results at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To measure pain control, we can use the numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 to 10, with lower values indicating better pain control. We can assess pain levels before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this measurement for pain control?

To document opioid consumption, we can keep a record of the administered drugs, including the name of the drug, dosage, and frequency of use. This documentation will help us evaluate the patterns of opioid consumption before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can simply keep a record of the number of days the patient spends in the hospital. This will help us evaluate the duration of the hospital stay before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this approach?

For patient satisfaction, we can use two questionnaires: the Oxford Knee Score and EQ-5D-5L. The Oxford Knee Score is a questionnaire with a range of 12-60 points, with lower values indicating better satisfaction. The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire consists of 5 questions with 5 answers each, including EQ-VAS, which ranges from 0 to 100, with higher values indicating better satisfaction. We can assess patient satisfaction at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

# Background on Outcome Measures

# Criteria for good outcome measures

# Outcome measures - general guidelines
- Outcome measures should capture both process and outcome
- Outcome measures should be feasible to collect
- Outcome measures should be comprehensive (i.e., collect a representative range of outcomes)
- Outcome measures should be reliable (e.g., use of appropriate scales, test-retest reliability)
- Outcome measures should be easily interpreted
- Outcome measures should be relevant (i.e., they should be important)
- Outcome measure selection should be evidence-based
- Outcome measures should be clinically meaningful/relevant
- Outcome measures should be feasible to implement with the given time and resources (e.g., cost associated with data collection, number of participants needed for feasibility study, number of data collection points required to maximize the utility of the data, etc.)
- Outcome measures should be validated for the target population on the LHIN
- Patient-important outcome measures should be collected. Ideally, there should be an equal mix of outcome measures for patients, staff and the health system

# Outcome measures - selection criteria
Clinical importance:
- Clinically significant and well-known for that condition
Clinical utility:
- Easy / fast to implement, collect or score (i.e., no complex math skills needed) 
- Patient / staff are able to easily complete (i.e., simple Likert scale questionnaires)
- Does not have a long recall period for patients (i.e., less than 6 months) 
- Does not require resources (i.e., questionnaires, extra testing, etc.)
- Does not require more than 5 minutes of time for patients to complete (i.e., questionnaires, extra testing, etc.) 
- Does not require more than 15 minutes total for patients to respond to the questionnaire (i.e., questionnaires, extra testing, etc.) 
- Relatively low burden (i.e., not taking multiple test measures)
Respect for participants’ time:
- Takes roughly 5 - 15 minutes to complete and does not have a long response time (i.e., questionnaires, extra testing, etc.)

# Background
DNA methylation is an important epigenetic modification and also plays a vital role in different biological functions. DNA methylation is mainly involved in gene regulation by repressing transcription and is also involved in genome stability. Hypermethylation in the gene promoter regions is mostly associated with tumour progression, while hypomethylation results in genomic instability and aberrant gene expression. This review details the role of DNA methylation-regulated genes in human diseases. The DNA methylation-regulated genes were analysed by using the Cistrome Cancer database, and their relationship with diseases was analysed by using the disgenet database or the GeneCards database. This review provides a wide range of information on some of the DNA methylation-regulated genes that are associated with human pathologies.

## Keywords
Human, diseases, DNA methylation, Cistrome Cancer database, disgenet database, GeneCards database

## Review classification of dna methylation in human disease
Aberrant patterns of DNA methylation are associated with many disorders, including human diseases and cancer. Hypermethylation and hypomethylation are associated with tumours. The DNA methylation-regulated genes, including hypermethylated and hypomethylated genes, are listed in the supplementary file.

However, the ER gene is hypermethylated only in breast cancer. The FHIT gene is hypermethylated in head and neck tumours

Sixty per cent of the patients were Caucasians, 22% were Blacks, 11% were Yellow and 6% were Mixed-Bloods. In relation to EBV serological profile, 75% of patients had positive serology for virus, 93% for EBV VCA-IgG, 77% for EBV-EBNA-1-IgG, 33% for EBV VCA-IgA, 11% for EBV-EBNA-1-IgA. The immunosuppressive therapy was: MMF n=51, Tacrolimus n=50, Prednisone n=43, Azathioprine n=20, Cyclosporine n=17. The predominant histopathological profile was monomorphic lymphoid: 65%, followed by polymorphic lymphoid 18%, and follicular 13%. CONCLUSIONS: Lethality rate of epstein-barr virus associated post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder in kidney transplant patients was higher in patients aged above 50 years than younger patients. The immunosuppressive therapy employed was a risk factor for development of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder in our study, and should therefore be better controlled in clinical practice. Methane activation was studied with high level of quantum chemistry coupled with the metadynamics molecular dynamics simulations based on molecular clusters Au@Ni (Au is a cluster with 20 gold atoms and Ni is a cluster with 10 nickel atoms) for methane activation. The Au@Ni double-atom cluster (Ni@Au10) has been identified to be the most active catalyst. Based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations at BP86/TZ2P/SMD, the activation barrier is 1.45 eV. This activation barrier is much lower than that for Au/Ni(111) surface (2.01 eV) or Ni@Au11 (2.17 eV). The theoretical results also indicate that the Ni@Au10 cluster is the most stable in the considered cluster models and can be stable under room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Ni@Au10 is a very promising candidate for catalyzing methane activation, but needs further experimental verification. We believe that double-atom cluster has great application prospects in the field of heterogeneous catalysts due to its unique feature of low cost and high catalytic activity. AIM
The study aims to explore the relationship between pain and quality of life of patients with kidney failure undergoing hemodialysis. It also aims to evaluate anxiety levels and demographic factors affecting patients' quality of life.


METHOD
The study is retrospective in nature and is based on a cross-sectional survey and includes 90 randomly selected adult patients (age > or = 18 years) who were undergoing hemodialysis in a university hospital in Duzce/Turkey on June 1, 2013. CONCLUSION

The aim was to assess the consequences of prenatal nicotine exposure and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) on the brain electrical activity of the developing fetus using a multi-scale model. Using a combined multi-scale brain model of fetal electrophysiology (neuronal network model of the brain stem and a computational model of the human field potential), we investigated how prenatal nicotine exposure at various doses (300, 600 and 900 µg/day) and different exposure time windows (third-trimester) affects the oscillatory activity at various scales. Hz), and an increase in low frequencies . Furthermore, we demonstrate that the use of nicotine patches and nicotine inhalers during pregnancy can lead to lower adverse effects in the fetus. The results of this study suggest that prenatal nicotine exposure (and/or pharmacotherapy) can have a significant impact on the development of the human fetal brain and that this disruption increases with increasing exposure intensity and prolonged exposure.

groundtruth: Thank you for sharing the interventions being evaluated. Could you also let me know the study type and phase of your trial?

Perfect, an interventional trial in Phase 2/Phase 3. Now, let's focus on designing the outcome measures. The primary outcome measures are crucial for evaluating the effectiveness of the treatment. Do you have any ideas for the primary outcome measures?

That's a great suggestion! The ORR measured by a blinded independent review committee using RECIST 1.1 is indeed a reliable measure to evaluate the treatment's effectiveness. We can track the ORR over a time frame of up to 136 weeks. Is there anything else you would like to add or modify regarding this measure?

Absolutely! Secondary outcome measures are important for providing additional insights into the treatment's impact. Based on the trial design and patient population, I have a few suggestions for secondary outcome measures. One suggestion is to include overall survival (OS) as a secondary outcome measure. This would allow us to assess the time from randomization to the date of death due to any cause.

We can track overall survival for up to 5 years. This longer time frame will provide a comprehensive understanding of the treatment's impact on patients' survival. Are there any other secondary outcome measures you would like to discuss or any modifications you would like to make?

Excellent suggestion! Monitoring the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events is crucial for evaluating the safety profile of the treatment regimen. We can track the incidence of TEAEs for up to 108 weeks. Is there anything else you would like to add or modify regarding this measure?

Certainly! Here are the outcome measures we have discussed for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Objective response rate (ORR) as assessed by blinded independent review committee (BICR) using RECIST 1.1. This measure assesses the proportion of patients with confirmed complete or partial response to the treatment regimen. The time frame for assessment is up to 136 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Overall survival (OS): Defined as the time from randomization to the date of death due to any cause. The time frame for assessment is up to 5 years.
2. Incidence of treatment-emergent adverse event (TEAEs): Assessing any untoward medical occurrences in patients receiving the study drugs. The time frame for assessment is up to 108 weeks.

These outcome measures will help us evaluate the effectiveness, safety, and impact on patients' quality of life in your clinical trial.

Accurately assessing the risk factors for mental health service utilization is of great importance in health planning and the effective allocation of available resources. We designed a prospective cohort study to identify the risk factors for mental health service utilization by elderly people in a city of Shandong province, China. The participants (N = 9329, aged 60 years and above, male = 4134 (44.3%), married = 7637 (81.8%), living in urban = 8473 (90.5%)) were recruited by drawing from a community-dwelling elderly population in Jinan, China in July 2014. Elderly people who ever received mental health services (n = 127) in the past six months due to psychological and mental health problems were considered as the cases. Elderly people who had not used mental health services were considered as the controls. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were used to identify risk factors for mental health care utilization by elderly people. Elderly people who had ever lived in rural areas and had received disability allowances, who lived in rural areas and underwent mental health services, who had disability and received disability allowances, who had depressive symptoms and utilized services had a significantly increased risk of mental health care utilization. The significant risk factors of mental health care utilization included rural residence, rural residence and receiving mental health services, rural residence and having disability, depression and utilizing mental health services. Our findings would provide practical implications for clinicians and health policymakers to assess the impact of mental health service utilization with regard to socio-demographic characteristics of older populations, and then develop appropriate interventions to meet the needs of elderly people who use mental health services. We want to define the term "drug resistance." We want to be able to measure whether or not someone's drug use has changed over time, and particularly how they feel about taking their drugs.
"Drug resistance" is a broad term that describes a wide range of behaviors and attitudes related to using drugs and managing drug-related conditions. In this study, we'll be focusing on drug resistance in two specific areas: adherence to medication regimens and abstinence.
Adherence refers to how well someone adheres to their prescribed medication regimen. For example, a person may not take their medication as prescribed for an extended period or miss doses because they feel ill or don't have enough time. Abstinence refers to whether a person chooses to abstain from using drugs, and how well they stick with their intention to do so.

Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a pleiotropic cytokine with strong mitogenic and hepatogenetic effects on hepatocytes. In the present paper, we examined whether HGF could affect the transcript levels of several nuclear transcription factor genes after tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha stimulation in AML-12 mouse liver epithelial cells. Among the nuclear factors examined, treatment of the cells with TNF-alpha resulted in the down-regulation of NF-E2-related factor 2 (Nrf2)-regulated genes, and the stimulation of nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kappaB)-regulated genes. In addition, the treatment of TNF-alpha-stimulated cells with HGF resulted in enhanced NF-kappaB activities, as well as down-regulation of Nrf2-regulated genes. Since the enhancement of NF-kappaB transcriptional activity was required for HGF-mediated cell proliferation, we next studied how HGF affects TNF-alpha-induced NF-kappaB activity, and concluded that TNF-alpha induced the phosphorylation and degradation of IkappaB kinase-beta (IKKbeta). However, the inhibition of IKK-beta activity resulted in the enhanced nuclear localization of p50/p65 heterodimers with concomitant activation of NF-kappaB-regulated gene transcription. Based on these results, we concluded that TNF-alpha-induced NF-kappaB transcriptional activity by HGF in AML-12 cells was related to the enhanced nuclear localization of p50/p65 heterodimers, consequently resulting in cell proliferation. .

 Improved performance in the Sleep/Wake Detection Algorithm by combining Heart Rate and Temperature Thresholds in a Movement threshold

Introduction: Although there are many types of movement recognition algorithms, the most widely developed algorithm is the movement detection algorithm which is combined with either Heart Rate (HR) or Temperature (Temp). The current state-of-theart on this combination is to combine two thresholds. However, we investigated the effect of combining the HR and the Temp threshold into one single threshold within the same movement algorithm. Methods: A total of 223 data set recordings of the Philips Respironics Actiwatch2 were analyzed. A total of 112 nights were classified as sleep and 111 nights were classified as non-sleep. One by one, we replaced different levels of each threshold (HR, Temp, Movement) with a single threshold. With the single thresholds, we determined their optimal cut of points, as defined by the lowest Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) for each individual. Result: The most accurate method for detecting wake events was the algorithm using the combination of the optimal Temp (35.6°C) and HR (76.5 beats per minute) thresholds within a Movement threshold. A RMSE of 66.4 [95% Confidence Interval (CI) = 20.8 to 112] and accuracy of 93.0 (95% CI = 88.5 to 95.8) percent was achieved. Discussion: The combination of the optimal HR and Temp thresholds within a Movement threshold resulted in the lowest RMSE and highest accuracy. This results in an improvement to the current state-of-the-art movement detection algorithm of 52.5 percent.

7. Change in day heart rate following renal denervation: Evaluating day heart rate following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
8. Change in patient activity: Assessing patient activity following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.
9. Change in heart rate variability: Monitoring heart rate variability following renal denervation compared to before, as assessed by the implantable cardiac monitor.

It has been generally accepted that for a two-band fermionic model with the spinless band the transition from non-Fermi liquid to Fermi liquid is controlled by the Luttinger-Ward equation with a momentum integrand which has the same form as the single-band version except that the electron number operator is replaced by the spin-up, and the spin-down, electron number operators. We discuss this issue in the case the Fermi surface is half filled. It is found that the Luttinger-Ward equations for the spinless band model has no solution when the momentum integrand is the single-band type, but has the solution when the momentum integrand is of the two-band type. Our results establish the fact that the single-band theory is not applicable to the spinless band model when the Fermi surface is half filled. If one tries to apply the non-Fermi liquid picture in which the Fermi surface is described as a superposition of single electron Fermi surfaces to realistic materials, such as strongly correlated metals or heavy fermion superconductors, a non-Fermi liquid phase may be reached with the Fermi surface consisting of one occupied and two unoccupied bands, i.e. the Fermi surface with the same properties as the band structure model considered in this paper, although this non-Fermi liquid phase is not a phase characterized by the spinless bands.

2. Neuropathic Pain 4 Questions (DN4): DN4 is a screening questionnaire to help identify neuropathic pain in clinical practice and research. A high score indicates a bad result. Time frame: Pre-intervention, 1st month, 3rd month.
3. The O'Leary-Sant Interstitial Cystitis Symptom Index (ICSI): The ICSI contains 4 items that measure urgency and frequency of urination, nighttime urination, and pain or burning. A high score indicates a bad result. Time frame: Pre-intervention, 1st month, 3rd month.
4. Interstitial Cystitis Problem Index (ICPI): ICPI is a form that investigates how much problems the symptoms of interstitial cystitis cause. A high score indicates a bad result. Time frame: Pre-intervention, 1st month, 3rd month.

Malignant mesothelioma is a tumor of mesothelial cells with a high mortality rate. Clinical presentation may include chest pain and shortness of breath. Imaging can assist in defining the extent of disease. Mesothelioma is primarily caused by environmental exposure to asbestos, most commonly in the form of amphibole fi bers. Pleural mesotheliomas are treated with a combination of therapeutic modalities, including surgery, systemic chemotherapy, localized radiotherapy, and targeted therapies. Treatment of pleural mesotheliomas remains controversial, but surgery with multiagent cytotoxic chemotherapy has resulted in some improvement in response rates and overall survival. New targeted therapies show promise in combination with conventional chemotherapeutic agents in patients with mesothelioma. This article provides a review of current and future treatment options for this disease with potential new therapies on the horizon.

Characterizing the Interaction between Flexible Protein Capsules and Microgel Surfaces to Enable a More Efficient Drug Delivery System for Cancer Cells.
The surface interaction of protein capsules with the hydrogel surface plays a significant role in controlling the overall properties of the hybrid materials. Here, the interaction of protein-polysaccharide capsules (PPCs) with microgels surfaces were studied to enable a more efficient drug delivery system for cancer cell treatment. Two PPCs with different sizes, pH, and zeta potentials, as well as two microgels were prepared by manipulating the synthesis conditions. The effects of these variables on the size and structure of the formed hybrid materials were determined by fluorescence measurements, dynamic light scattering, cryo-transmission electron microscopy, cryo-electron tomography, and small angle neutron scattering. It was observed that size, pH, and zeta potential values inversely affected the PPC-microgel surface interactions. The capsules with the smallest size and highest negatively charged charge were found to interact more strongly with positively charged microgels. Additionally, the interaction of PPCs and microgels with cancer cells was investigated, and the results indicated that the protein capsules interacted most strongly with cancer cells compared to microgels, potentially because PPCs are larger and more negatively charged in pH conditions that facilitate capsule formation. Furthermore, it was observed that the amount of released drugs from protein capsule-microgel hybrid materials in the presence of cancer cells was lower, in comparison to that from capsules with drug only, which is the most critical condition that should be reached to achieve the effectiveness of the drug delivery system. Overall, the present study contributes important information that can be utilized in designing more efficient drug delivery systems for cancer cells by manipulating the conditions that govern the formation of PPCs and their interactions with microgels.

The use of propolis as an animal feed additive has emerged as a new concept in the fields of nutrition and health. Propolis has excellent nutritional properties and exhibits potential beneficial effects on animal reproduction, including antibacterial, antiviral, and immunostimulatory properties, as well as enhancing digestion and the reproductive biology of animals. However, more research work should be initiated to fully elucidate the molecular mechanisms of propolis as a feed additive with the potential for enhancing animal reproduction. Our objective was therefore to evaluate the use of propolis as an animal feed additive. Here, we reviewed, through various databases, the biological activities of propolis in various fields, emphasizing the effects of propolis and propolis derivatives (propolis extracts and propolis constituents) on animal reproductive performance. To date, few reports have elicited the effects of propolis on animal reproduction. Furthermore, there is no information available regarding the nutritional, health, and reproductive applications of propolis in animals. However, studies have provided data on the potential beneficial effects of propolis on animal reproduction, and further experimental work is necessary to define the most appropriate level for propolis use.KEYWORDSanimal, propolis, feed additive, nutrition, health, reproduction

Influence of the size of the anterior fontanelle on neurodevelopmental outcome in infants with a gestational age of less than 32 weeks, as observed by the neonatal neurological examination.
INTRODUCTION
The gestational age at birth, low birth weight and the severity of the illness are all variables influencing the long term prognosis in the neonatal intensive care unit population. Neurological examination at birth is a useful tool to assess early neuromotor development in premature infants.


METHODS
A prospective study was performed in the neonatal intensive care unit of the University Medical Center Utrecht from September 1992 to September 1994. All infants born with gestational age < 32 weeks were eligible to participate in the study. Infants included were between birth and 28 days of age when neonatologists and physiotherapists performed a neurological examination. Thereafter, a neurodevelopmental examination was repeated when the infant was followed in the outpatient department.


RESULTS
A follow-up examination was performed in 32 infants. A significant difference in the severity of the neonatal neurological examination was found between males and females; the female infants scored more favorably. In the long term, no significant difference could be demonstrated between the mean Bayley mental and motor developmental indexes of girls and boys. Furthermore, there was no significant difference between the mean Bayley Mental Developmental Index (MDI), Motor Developmental Index (MDI) and Infant Neurological Examination scores of infants with a large anterior fontanel and infants with a small anterior fontanel.


CONCLUSION
Since the neonatal neurological examination at birth is associated with neurodevelopmental outcome in infants born prematurely, an adequate neurological examination is therefore recommended before discharge from the neonatal intensive care unit. Despite the presence of a large anterior fontanel, the results indicate that premature infants should be able to develop into normal, mildly mentally retarded and moderately/severely mentally retarded infants without long term sequelae. .

Phylo-Transfer Analyses Disclose the Relative Importance of Intra- and Inter-Domain Transfers of Lateral Genes between Proteobacteria

Background: Lateral gene transfer (LGT) can greatly influence the evolution of specific genomic regions. Most previous work on lateral transfer and functional impact has focused on the analysis of gene neighborhoods. However, the influence of neighboring sequences on functional changes during gene history remains unclear. To explore such relationships, we applied phylogenetic-based analyses to a large dataset of Proteobacteria 16S rRNA sequences for which phylogenetic information and annotation of functionally relevant domains exist.Methodology:We calculated the frequency of LGT per gene as the ratio between the number of hits between each species pair and the total number of hits in the dataset. For the analysis of the functional effects of LGT, we selected transfers that occurred between any organism of the Flexibacter-Brevundimonas clade and one of the other Proteobacteria, as the functional annotations of the recipient species might differ from those of their donors. We combined domain information in those proteins with phylogenetic information of those genes to evaluate the functional transfers that occurred in these proteins.Principal Findings: Based on the relative magnitude of inter-domain versus intra-domain transfers we showed that the donors of intra-domain transfers are a major LGT source for the Proteobacteria and suggested that these transfers have a relevant effect on lateral transfer at the gene level. The analysis of transfers between the Flexibacter-Brevundimonas and Proteobacteria clades showed a higher frequency of lateral transfer in this direction. In addition, we found differences in the functional impact of inter-and intra-domain transfers, as intra-domain transfers in the Flexibacter-Brevundimonas transfers resulted in more transfers from the lower taxonomical level to the higher one, whereas inter-domain transfers had a major impact on the functional transfer between distant taxonomical levels.Significance: Our results provide an insight into the frequency and role of LGT at the domain level in the evolution of Proteobacteria. We would suggest using the following outcome measures:
1. Infant hearing screening: In the first 3 months of life, we could test the infant using universal newborn hearing screening (UNHS) with otoacoustic emissions to confirm if he or she has normal hearing, moderately severe or greater hearing loss, or severe or greater hearing loss. If the infant was confirmed to have hearing loss, we suggest referring the infant directly to a multidisciplinary pediatric diagnostic audiology team to determine the type and severity of the hearing loss. After the infants turn 1 year old, they need to go through periodic screening to determine if there has been any delay in hearing development. If there are any delays in the child’s speech and language development, we can use the results from these screenings to rule out a hearing-related etiology.
2. Audiology assessments: There are several different audiological tests that we can use with the child to determine the cause of his or her hearing loss. We would test the child using distortion product otoacoustic emissions, and electrophysiological tests, including auditory brainstem response with click stimuli and event-related potentials (ERPs) with speech sounds. Once we have determined the cause of the hearing loss, we can start treatment. The best method for treating certain types of congenital hearing loss is not clear. Treatment options could be medical, surgical, or the use of hearing aids, devices that amplify sound, or cochlear implants, that help improve hearing in babies who cannot hear well. The best time to offer these treatments or to begin hearing aids would be to wait until the child is 2 years old, by which time we know if or when he or she will be able to use these devices.
3. Hearing aids or cochlear implant fitting:
- Cochlear implantation: When the auditory brain area for the ear is underdeveloped and the bone conduction hearing is poor, we can fit the child with a cochlear implant to help the child hear better; this is recommended in infants with hearing loss at 3 months of age.
- Hearing aids: Children who require hearing aids should be fitted with them in time

Objective: To assess the effectiveness of test, trace and treat (TTT) strategy with two different test frequencies in Indonesia to prevent COVID-19 infections. Methods: This study used an agent-based Susceptible-Exposed-Infectious-Removed (SEIR) framework. First, we simulated the spread of COVID-19 in Indonesia under the baseline scenario. We then assessed two TTT interventions, first at 40% test frequency with a 48 h turnaround time and the second at 80% test frequency with an identical turnaround time.Results: Under the baseline scenario, the number of COVID-19 infections would peak in April and the peak number of infections would be 333,720 for the first 3 months and 53,909 for 3e6 months. With the 40% test frequency and a 48 h turnaround time, we projected that the number of infections would peak in June and be 121,598 for the first 3 months and 15,636 for 3e6 months. With the 80% test frequency and equivalent turnaround time, the number of COVID-19 infections would peak in July and be 94,811 for the first 3 months and 6276 for 3e6 months. Conclusion: These simulations show that the TTT strategy can reduce projected COVID-19 infections and deaths in Indonesia. Both 40% and 80% test frequencies showed substantially lower numbers of infections, hospitalisations and deaths. The most effective scenario can reduce infection rates down to 20% of the baseline scenario.
