Understood. Now, let's move on to designing the outcome measures. Based on the information you've provided, we can focus on hearing-related outcomes as the primary outcome measures. How does that sound?

I would suggest considering the following outcome measures:
1. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) intensity: This measure provides objective information about the integrity of the auditory pathway from the ear to the brainstem. It can help monitor the progression of hearing loss in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure ABR intensity at different time points throughout the study, such as annually for 4 years.

Another important measure is otoacoustic emission (OAEs) amplitudes. OAEs are a non-invasive measure of cochlear function and can provide information about the health of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. Monitoring OAEs amplitudes can help assess the structural integrity of the cochlea and detect early signs of cochlear dysfunction in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can also measure OAEs amplitudes annually for 4 years.

Yes, we should include pure tone intensity thresholds as an outcome measure. This measure assesses the softest sound that a participant can hear at different frequencies. It's crucial for evaluating the degree and configuration of hearing loss and tracking changes in hearing sensitivity over time in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure pure tone intensity thresholds annually for 4 years as well.

The last outcome measure I would recommend is speech detection and perception thresholds. This measure evaluates the ability of participants to detect and perceive speech sounds at different intensity levels. It's important for understanding the impact of gene-related hearing loss on speech understanding and communication abilities in pediatric participants. We can assess speech detection and perception thresholds annually for 4 years.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest focusing on auditory skills and speech perception over time. We can include measures such as open- and closed-set task phoneme accuracy and word comprehension, early speech perception (ESP), pediatric speech intelligibility (PSI) test, and auditory skills checklist (ASC). These measures will provide insights into the development of auditory skills and speech perception abilities in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can assess these measures annually for 4 years as well.

In a clinical trial of a drug or diagnostic agent, a Phase I study (often the initial study) does not use a conventional comparison group, but rather measures toxicity among a group in which people who received the agent of interest are compared to those who did not, and among groups in which varying doses are compared. A Phase II study compares people with disease who do and do not receive the investigational agent.

Methylenetetrahydrofolate Reductase 677T Polymorphism Is Positively Associated with Lung Cancer Risk and Promoted Cancer Development; Further Studies Based upon a Meta-Analysis

In the past decade many studies have evaluated the association between methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) and lung cancer risk. However, these findings on the role of MTHFR 677T variant in lung cancer development remain inconsistent. To evaluate the association between MTHFR 677T polymorphisms and lung cancer risk, the present study was based on a meta-analysis using unpublished data from 13 studies with 11,065 subjects. The MTHFR 677T variant was associated with a 1.83 fold (CIs = 1.13-2.96, P = 0.014) increase in lung cancer risk based upon all the data. Subanalysis of ethnicity indicated that the risk of lung cancer was only increased in Caucasians. Moreover, stratification by disease state demonstrated that individuals with MTHFR 677T alleles had a significantly higher risk of lung cancer from both hospital-based case-control studies (1.72 fold, CIs = 1.22-2.44, P = 0.003) and population-based case-control studies (2.64 fold, CIs = 1.10-6.35, P = 0.031). Furthermore, the association was strengthened in studies with the larger sample size, and also in smokers, nonsmall cell lung cancer patients, and early stage cancer patients. In conclusion, our meta-analysis indicated that the MTHFR 677T variant could be positively associated with lung cancer susceptibility and promoted cancer development.

A multilingual, free internet-based computer-assisted cognitive behavioral therapy program for symptoms of depression and anxiety: randomized controlled trial

The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of "Stressless-Anxiety and Depression" (http://turk-stressless.com/en/) a computerized cognitive behavioral therapy (CCBT) program that includes cognitive-behavioral as well as relaxation techniques for symptoms of depression and anxiety in patients with comorbidities. The study was a randomized controlled trial among 190 adults with comorbid depression and anxiety recruited from across Turkey in 2 general medicine clinics. The patients were assessed 3 times: at intake (t1), after 2 weeks of intervention (t2) and 4 weeks after the end of therapy (t3). Participants randomly assigned to one of the two conditions (CCBT+waitlist; N = 100) or to the waitlist condition (N = 90) underwent an online survey that assessed depression and anxiety, using the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21) and physical activity using the International Physical Activity Questionnaire-Short Form (IPAQ-SF). Results indicated that the CCBT group showed lower anxiety and depression levels (p = 0.001) than the waitlist group at t2. Moreover, there were significant differences between the two groups at t3 for all three of the dependent variables depression, anxiety, and stress level (p < 0.001). The CCBT program was associated with greater improvement in depression and anxiety symptoms and physical activity than waitlist and was effective in alleviating depression and anxiety symptoms.

1. Aim & objective / hypotheses

3. Sample & sample size
4. Measurements (how you measured each of the variables) and instrumentation (what you used to measure each variable)
5. Results & analysis of results
6. Outcome / Conclusion (including limitations)
7. Reference from academic journals.

The effectiveness of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccination in a prospective observational study of patients infected with HIV in London

Objectives:The incidence of invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD) is increasing among adults infected with HIV in the UK despite vaccination. We have measured the effectiveness of pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) in preventing IPD in HIV-positive patients.Methods: Between April 2001 and December 2006, 920 HIV-positive individuals in the UK AIDS cohort study were vaccinated with PPV. We evaluated the effectiveness of PPV in preventing IPD events through nested case-control analysis.Results: Sixteen cases and 150 controls were vaccinated with PPV within 5 y before their cases; and 17 cases and 658 controls were vaccinated more than 5 y before. Vaccination was less protective in cases if it was more than 5 y before the event (aOR 2.9; CI 1.7-4.7). PPV vaccine effectiveness in preventing IPD events within 5 y was 69% (CI 41-82; 12 cases and 18 controls vaccinated less than 5 y before their IPD event), and this vaccine effectiveness was not influenced by CD4 count at vaccination (P = 0.60) or age over 50 y (P = 0.46).Conclusion: PPV is effective in preventing IPD in HIV-positive adults irrespective of CD4 count at vaccination. The effectiveness of PPV vaccine is lost if more than 5 y has elapsed since vaccination.

Sleeping Beauty Mutagenesis as a Tool to Identify Genes Governing the Molecular Mechanism for Foldable Drosophila Embryos
Development is often accompanied by rapid embryogenesis and the occurrence of morphological transitions. The molecular mechanism of these transitions remains poorly understood. We previously demonstrated that overexpression of the small GTPase GTPase-activating protein 1 (CG2165) generates mutant Drosophila embryos that fail to undergo the second embryo fold, resulting in nonfunctional egg shells. In an effort to identify the genes governing this molecular mechanism, we used the Sleeping Beauty (SB) system to carry out an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea screen to identify genes that would render mutant embryos insensitive to CG2165 expression. Out of the 170 insertions we recovered, we identified two genes for which mutation rescues the defects caused by CG2165 overexpression. The first is a gene encoding the transcription factor fork head. Loss of one copy of the gene for this transcription factor is sufficient to rescue the morphogenesis defects caused by CG2165 overexpression. CG2165 overexpression also resulted in increased levels of fork head protein, which in turn was reversed in the insensitive mutants. The second gene rescuing the folding defect is a gene encoding the protein phosphatase type-2A associated protein 49γ. Loss of two copies of the gene rescues the first larval instar lethality as produced by CG2165 overexpression. Mutation of this gene also reduced the levels of Fork head protein in CG2165 overexpressing mutant embryos. We show that the two proteins form a stable complex, and this interaction is independent of the transcriptional regulation. These data indicate that the folding defects caused by overexpression of CG2165 can be rescued at least in part by the loss of Forkhead protein regulation. .

Role of intestinal microbiota in lipid metabolism.
INTRODUCTION
The gut microbiota is a complex ecosystem that plays an essential role in human well-being, promoting intestinal homeostasis. Nevertheless, during a life time, various factors can induce dysbiosis and a loss of microbial diversity, leading to a significant modulation of host metabolism. In the gastrointestinal tract, the lipid metabolism is regulated by a large number of bacterial enzymes, generating a wide repertoire of metabolites that influence in various different processes, such as inflammation, immunity and metabolic host health.

In this review, the influence of gut microbiota on lipid and cholesterol metabolism, and the effect of various dietary interventions are considered. Special emphasis is placed on bacterial metabolite production by the gut microbiota, and its capacity to promote the host's lipid homeostasis. The current scientific knowledge on the gut microbiota impact on this process is discussed, and future applications are considered.


EXPERT OPINION
The current scientific knowledge on the role of the gut microbiota and bacterial metabolites in cholesterol and lipid metabolism is increasing and may be the subject of multiple applications in the close future. However, many aspects remain to be investigated to understand the exact role of gut microbiota and its metabolites, before being able to propose new microbial-based therapeutic approaches. Moreover, as host-microbiota relationships are extremely variable among individuals, dietary intervention to restore the microbiota composition through the enrichment of species linked to physiologic host cholesterol and lipid homeostasis will help to better understand the mechanisms linking gut microbiota and a healthy lipid metabolism. A clinical trial measures all three types of medical research, which are:
- Clinical research;
- Epidemiological studies; and
- Basic science research.
- These three types of medical research are considered to be the 3 pillars of medicine which is a scientific practice concerned with the prevention, study, and treatment of disease.
- Medicine is a science of healing illness and injury. It is usually divided into a wide variety of health professions. In addition, there are some occupations related to medicine.
- Other types of studies can be conducted as:
- Clinical trials;
- Clinical research;
- Basic science research; and
- Epidemiological studies.
- The research types can vary in design and methods, but all are typically intended to generate scientific knowledge or to develop new treatments.
- Examples are: epidemiological studies; clinical trials; cross-sectional, correlation, and case-control studies; randomized controlled trials; or other observational studies for treatment effect sizes.
- In this, a clinical research trial or interventional study is a study method that randomly assigns participants to groups of two or more to take part in a clinical study or interventional study to test the safety and efficacy of a medical, surgical, or behavioral intervention.
- A random assignment of patients to the treatment and control groups is a useful method to increase the reliability of the results.
- Randomization is the process of assigning people to each group by a simple random sampling method that is simple to perform and is widely used in everyday life.
- It is a random arrangement scheme that determines a set of sequences without giving preferential treatment to a specific entity.
- In this case, a study method with a random assignment to 2 arms will have a higher number of patients in the control group than in the group at risk.
- Also, each individual has an equal chance to be assigned to the arm with a higher possibility of receiving treatment (the treatment arm) or to the arm with a lower possibility of receiving treatment (the control arm).
- The study arm with a higher probability of receiving treatment will have a higher number of patients.
- The study arm with a lower probability of receiving treatment will have a lower number of patients.
- For example, random assignment to 2 arms of 200 patients

Let's continue to consider the potential challenges or limitations of our study design. One thing to consider is the potential burden on the participants. We recognize that chronic pain can be a challenging experience. It can affect many aspects of a person's life, including their emotional and physical health. It is not uncommon for people to experience depression, anxiety, and other emotional distress related to chronic pain. One way to address this challenge is to include support services or referrals in our study design. This could involve providing participants with access to a mental health professional, or providing them with resources and referral information to help them manage their pain. Another challenge is the potential for confounding variables that we haven't considered. These variables might interfere with the evaluation, interpretation, or conclusions drawn from the study. Possible confounding variables could include participant characteristics such as ethnicity, gender, and age; social factors such as marital status, education level, and income; and medical conditions that may mimic or complicate a participant's pain. While including participants will help alleviate the burden of pain, we should continue to prioritize this by focusing on the potential confounding variables and ways to address them. Participants in our study may have underlying emotional or medical factors that prevent them from completing the full research protocol. It's essential to address these potential obstacles to achieve the best research outcomes. These factors may include emotional and medical distress, mobility limitations, mental health and cognitive disabilities. Additionally, the participants may have had injuries or surgery that made it difficult to remain in the research. To mitigate these burdens, we can include support and assistance services for participants in our study design. This may involve providing emotional support and counseling services, assistive technology, and respiratory equipment, as well as mobility aids that allow participants to remain active. The support and assistance may also include access to transportation services, home healthcare, and other essential services. As I told you earlier, when I worked for the psychologist I became aware of the many barriers that are present in doing research in a clinical setting. Some psychologists, psychotherapists, and even those in the same field as mine are afraid of research, but I saw myself as someone who was open to it. We talked about ethics in research at my psychology teacher’s seminar, and she often emphasized that we need to be clear about our goals if our research should be ethical. What I also found interesting is that many studies are conducted without ethics committees, probably because they are conducted in a clinical setting.

OBJECTIVE
To investigate whether autologous bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) transplantation could promote the recovery of spinal cord injury (SCI).


METHODS
A complete spinal cord transection model in adult rats was established by the modified New Haven method, 10 spinal cords were left as the sham group, in another 80 rats SCI models were established, and then they were randomly grouped into control group, sham group, PBS group, bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells group, anti-miRNA221 group, bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells and anti-miRNA221 group (n=10 for each group). Chromatin organization of the 6q21 region including the major histocompatibility complex

Background: The region 6q21 near the centromere is characterized by a high concentration of transcribed genes and by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) genes located in several gene-enriched clusters, which are subject to various regulatory elements. The structure of the 6q21 chromatin in B-lymphoblastic cell lines MOLT-4 (human leukemia) and DG75 (German guinea pig lymphoma) was explored. A comparative analysis was performed using restriction enzymes of various specificity, including rare cutters. Chromatin digestion with restriction analysis has revealed two major chromatin units in the pericentromeric region. Methods: Restriction fragments were analyzed by two-dimensional electrophoresis in polyacrylamide/agarose gels, and the genetic map of overlapping restriction fragments in the 6q21 region was created.Results: In the restriction map, there were two major fragments (one with two copies and the other with three to six copies of the restriction fragments) that were specific for the B-cells in the lymphoblastoid cell lines MOLT-4 and DG75.Conclusions: The results provide evidence for high chromatin compaction in the pericentromeric region of the human chromosome 6q.

# Background
One of the objectives of human genetics and cytogenetics is to predict the phenotype based on the genotype, which requires a complete knowledge of the human genome. The regions of the genome with high gene density and regulatory elements in the vicinity of the promoters are most often considered as chromatin unitsthat are referred to as "active" chromatin. The use of high‐resolution computerized sonography in the prenatal diagnosis of fetal limb defects
Historically, sonography has been a useful tool in the evaluation of fetal anomalies. In the study of limb defects, the inexperienced examiner who relies on routine obstetrical sonography can fail to detect many minor defects. With the high‐resolution sonography (HRS) of 7.5 mHz, one can readily examine the fetus for major and minor limb defects. To our knowledge, this is the first report that deals with the application of this level of resolution to the prenatal diagnosis of limb defects. Sure! Secondary outcome measures are additional measures that provide further insights into the intervention's impact on various aspects related to physical literacy. We have a list of secondary outcome measures that we can consider. Would you like me to provide you with the full list?

Here are the secondary outcome measures we can consider for your study:
1. Change of the active commuting to/from school
2. Change of the body Mass Index
3. Change of the cardiorespiratory fitness
4. Change of the physical activity participation (self-reported)
5. Change of the alienation with school
6. Change of the body image perception
7. Change of the physical activity intention
8. Change of the physical activity psychological need satisfaction according to the Self-Determination Theory at physical education
9. Change of the perceived physical self-concept
10. Change of the sedentary behavior
11. Change of the school satisfaction
12. Change of the social identity
13. Change of the knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles
14. Change of the math fluency calculation

Of course! Here's a brief description of each secondary outcome measure:
1. Change of the active commuting to/from school: This measure assesses changes in active commuting behavior, such as walking or biking to school.
2. Change of the body Mass Index: This measure evaluates changes in participants' body mass index, indicating changes in weight and overall health.
3. Change of the cardiorespiratory fitness: This measure assesses changes in participants' cardiovascular fitness and endurance levels.
4. Change of the physical activity participation (self-reported): This measure captures participants' self-reported physical activity levels and habits.
5. Change of the alienation with school: This measure evaluates changes in participants' feelings of alienation with school, which can impact their overall well-being and engagement.
6. Change of the body image perception: This measure assesses changes in participants' perception of their own body image, providing insights into self-esteem and body satisfaction.
7. Change of the physical activity intention: This measure assesses changes in participants' intentions to engage in physical activity in the future, indicating the sustainability of behavior change.
8. Change of the physical activity psychological need satisfaction according to the Self-Determination Theory at physical education: This measure evaluates changes in participants' satisfaction of psychological needs related to physical education, which is crucial for intrinsic motivation and engagement.
9. Change of the perceived physical self-concept: This measure assesses changes in participants' perceived physical self-concept, which can influence their self-perception and confidence in physical abilities.
10. Change of the sedentary behavior: This measure evaluates changes in sedentary behavior, indicating participants' overall activity patterns and health behaviors.
11. Change of the school satisfaction: This measure assesses changes in participants' satisfaction with school, which can impact their overall well-being and academic engagement.
12. Change of the social identity: This measure evaluates changes in participants' social identity related to physical education or sport, indicating their sense of belonging and motivation.
13. Change of the knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles: This measure assesses changes in participants' knowledge related to physical activity and healthy lifestyles, indicating the intervention's educational impact.
14. Change of the math fluency calculation: This measure evaluates changes in participants' math fluency calculation skills, providing insights into cognitive abilities beyond physical activity.

Development and application of a simple, inexpensive and easy‐to‐use microfluidic system for rapid and quantitative SARS‐CoV‐2 antibody detection

Development of simple, cost-effective point-of-care (POC) diagnostic kits with a short turnaround time and without professional training is crucial to the timely diagnosis of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and management of the ongoing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. Herein, we developed a simple, easy-to-use, affordable, microfluidic-based SARS-CoV-2 immunoassay (SAMIS) that could be applied to a POC diagnostic platform for rapid and simultaneous detection of SARS-CoV-2-specific antibodies and viral antigens. Antigen-antibody complexes were formed in the channels of a 2 × 2 well-arrayed microfluidic system through sequential antibody incubation and washing steps. The resulting SARS-CoV-2 complexes were visualized with an organic dye that exhibited red fluorescence only when intercalated into double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) and thus exhibited a colour change from a blank to a red state. The developed SAMIS exhibited a high sensitivity to the antibodies against both the nucleocapsid protein and the spike surface protein of SARS-CoV-2 and demonstrated a superior turnaround time compared to that of real-time polymerase chain reaction and commercial IgG/IgM rapid test kits. For this particular research project, I found this to be a lot more enjoyable than the previous project because the literature was more relevant to the specialty I chose. The research question was related to current practice guidelines and standards and so it was easy to relate to the article. This research project also required the extra effort to find a patient, record baseline tracheostomy data, and follow up with the patient at each data collection point. The extra effort was worth it because I was able to see the impact of decannulation on my specialty. Many respiratory therapists are not aware of the impact of tracheostomy on patients because they are not necessarily involved in all phases of patient care. My research project showed to me that respiratory therapists can not only be involved with providing care to tracheostomy patients but also to help with the prognostication and planning for such patients. This was shown in one of the projects I reviewed where a physician described their respiratory therapist to be the ones who followed up with the patients after discharge to provide additional support to them (American Academy of Pediatrics, 2016).

Ideally, tracheostomy patients can expect to decannulate and use the vocal channel effectively. To assess the vocal outcomes post-decannulation, the assessment of vocal range and quality, as well as the assessment of the perceptual characteristics of the voice, should be included in the patient's evaluation.
The assessment of vocal range and quality post-decannulation is important as it helps to determine whether the tracheostomy affected vocal cord mobility. It can also help determine whether the larynx is affected by the tracheostomy procedure. Measuring vocal parameters and evaluating patient preferences and perceptual characteristics are important ways to assess vocal outcomes post-decannulation and address patient concerns. It is essential to assess the patients' feelings and expectations concerning the decannulation process, along with the vocal outcomes and other factors influencing their well-being and life satisfaction to ensure the best possible outcomes.

The negative consequences of problematic internet use are often ignored and may result in unanticipated consequences for teenagers such as depression and suicide rates. Although there is a large amount of literature on the association between online addiction and other mental health symptoms, such a relationship has yet to be defined among the youth population in Greece with such preliminary findings.Objectives: The goal of this research is to assess the psychopathological symptoms of problematic internet addiction amongst Greek teenagers from urban areas. Furthermore, it is hypothesised that there will be a significant positive correlation between problematic internet use and several psychological symptoms including mood disorders, anxiety disorders, behavioural disorders, somatic symptom disorders, substance use, and sleep disorders.Methods:A cross-sectional pilot study was conducted in order to quantitatively evaluate the association between psychopathological symptoms and problematic internet addiction. Two hundred seventy-six questionnaires were collected. Adolescents were asked to fill in the Internet Addiction Test (IAT) and also the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview for Children and Adolescents (MINI-KID). The results were analyzed by using the Cox and Snell R square test and Pearson's correlation coefficient test

groundtruth: Absolutely. Another primary outcome measure could be the rate of reintubation post-decannulation. Reintubation is a critical event that may indicate the failure of decannulation or the presence of complications that require immediate intervention. Monitoring the rate of reintubation post-decannulation will help us evaluate the success of the decannulation process and the need for additional medical support.

Exactly. Now, let's move on to the rate of recannulation post-decannulation as another primary outcome measure. Recannulation refers to the reinsertion of a tracheal cannula after its removal. Monitoring the rate of recannulation post-decannulation will help us assess the durability of the decannulation process and the occurrence of complications that may necessitate re-cannulation.

Lastly, we should include the rate of death post-decannulation as a primary outcome measure. Although a rare outcome, monitoring the rate of death post-decannulation is crucial for assessing the overall safety and mortality risk associated with the decannulation process. This will provide important information on potential life-threatening complications that may arise after tracheal cannula removal.

Excellent! Now let's move on to the second outcome measures. These measures will provide more detailed information on the specific complications, prognostic factors, and patients' perspectives related to decannulation.

One important second outcome measure could be the types of decannulation-related physical complications short- and long-term. This measure will include complications such as excessive secretion, altered respiratory frequency, respiratory insufficiency, respiratory infections, newly occurring neurological symptoms, sleep apnea, intratracheal complications, and complications with tracheostoma. We can assess these complications for 3 months post-decannulation at the same time points as the primary outcome measures.

Absolutely. Another second outcome measure could be identifying candidate prognostic factors for physical complications post-decannulation. By assessing individual demographic and clinical patient characteristics, we can determine risk factors that may influence the occurrence of complications. We can collect this data 1 week pre-decannulation, 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.

Lastly, we should include patients' perspectives on decannulation outcomes as a second outcome measure. By using questionnaires, we can assess patients' experiences, preferences, and overall satisfaction with the decannulation process. We can also use the Harvard Human Flourishing Measure to evaluate their well-being. We can collect this data at different time points: 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation for the questionnaire, and 1 week pre-decannulation and 3 months post-decannulation for the Harvard Human Flourishing Measure.
Great! Now let's summarize the outcome measures we have discussed so far.

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Rate of physical complications post-decannulation: Assessed at 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.
2. Rate of reintubation post-decannulation: Assessed at 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.
3. Rate of recannulation post-decannulation: Assessed at 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.
4. Rate of death post-decannulation: Assessed at 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.

Second Outcome Measures:
1. Types of decannulation-related physical complications short- and long-term: Assessed for 3 months post-decannulation at the same time points as the primary outcome measures.
2. Candidate prognostic factors for physical complications post-decannulation: Assessed 1 week pre-decannulation, 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation.
3. Patients' perspectives on decannulation outcomes: Assessed with questionnaires at 4 days, 1 month, and 3 months post-decannulation, and with the Harvard Human Flourishing Measure at 1 week pre-decannulation and 3 months post-decannulation.

In situ visualization of transient receptor potential melastatin 8 channel expression and function in mouse intestinal epithelial cells.
Transient receptor potential (TRP) melastatin 8 (TRPM8) was first identified as a cold-sensing receptor in human and mouse epithelial cells. However, little is known about the functional and expression of TRPM8 in intestine. Using our newly developed antibody, we now demonstrate the expression of TRPM8 in the epithelium of the mouse GI tract and describe a novel physiological role for it. Immunofluorescence, Western blotting, and patch-clamp studies demonstrated the expression of TRPM8 in intestinal epithelial IEC-6 cells. Stimulation with cool stimuli (5-20 degrees C) evoked Ca(2+) influx in TRPM8-transfected HEK293 cells and endogenous TRPM8-expressing IEC-6 cells, whereas cells without TRPM8 expression were unresponsive. Pharmacological inhibition of the channel with AMG9810 (10 microM, 15 min) completely reversed temperature-induced Ca(2+) influx in IEC-6 cells, suggesting that the influx is mediated by TRPM8 channels. Application of the TRPM8 antibody (10 microg/ml) transiently decreased the basal transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) of IEC-6 cell monolayers in vitro. The antibody-induced TEER decrease was TRPM8-dependent because it was prevented by TRPM8 deletion or TRPM8-blocking antibody. This decrease in TEER is due to a rapid, reversible increase in ion fluxes through the paracellular pathway. Taken together, our results demonstrate the expression of TRPM8 channel in mouse intestinal epithelium and its role in altering ion and water transport. Effect of dietary copper and zinc concentrations in rangeland calves during the growth season on growth performance and immune function indices.
BACKGROUND
Concern about the deficit or excess nutrient in ruminants are often reported. For this study, the growing condition of rangeland calves on varying levels of copper and zinc supplements were investigated.


METHODS
At the beginning of the growing season, 60 calves (average age of 12 months) of Holstein and Mazandarani purebred livestock breed, with an average initial live weight of 65 kg, were randomly placed in six replications. Four treatments were defined: no supplements (control treatment), and three dose levels (10 and 20 mg copper element /kg live weight/day, plus 100 and 200 mg zinc element, respectively).


RESULTS
Results showed that different concentrations of copper and zinc supplements had no significant effects on average daily gain between weeks 4, 8, 12, 16, 20 and 24 of the experiment. However, weekly weight gain tended to increase in the control group (0.28 kg/week) compared to the other control groups (0.22, 0.24 and 0.26 k/week respectively in Zn 100, Zn200, Cu100 and Cu200 groups ). Copper and zinc concentration were in the healthy and ideal range for sheep, goats and beef cattle.


CONCLUSION
The results suggest that 10-20 mg Cu/kg live weight/day and 100-200 mg Zn/kg live weight/day can be used as growth factors for improving immune performance in rangelands livestock. Therefore, these amounts of Cu and Zn supplements are recommended for use in rangeland calves. Hormones of the pituitary and adrenal glands were reported to stimulate alkaline phospbataes of liver extracts and this stimulation has been attributed to the stimulation of liver cell proliferation by adrenal and pituitary hormones (Harris et al., '55 ; Harper & Haddock, '53). Recently, it has been found that the activity in serum of alkaline phosphatase is closely related to the rate of cell proliferation in a wide variety of tissues (Ludford & Barker, '54b, '56). Also, alkaline phosphatase activity from sera of many species (mammals, birds, and reptiles) has been shown to be partially purified by the technique of affinity chromatography (Ochoa, '53; Singer et al., '55). In the present report the activity of alkaline phosphatase in mouse serum has been determined by this immobilized phosphatase method prior to and following treatment of these mice with dexamethasone. Since alkaline phosphatase activity has been shown in serum to be a measure of cellular proliferation, this report may be extended to determine the effect of steroids on the cellular proliferation of normal animals. Pain intensity is a subjective measurement of the level — or quality — of pain experienced by a patient. It is measured on a scale from 0 to 10 (10=the most severe pain ever experienced by the patient)

# Pain Intensity Assessment
- Subjective assessment of pain intensity by the patient (self-assessment)
- Pain intensity should be assessed using a pain scale

# Pain Scale

## Visual analogy scale
- A 10-cm horizontal visual analogy scale
If the patient identifies the pain intensity on the 0-10 cm visual analog scale, the score will be:
- In the case of no pain (0), patient indicates on a horizontal (on millimeter scale);
- In the case of mild pain (1-3) on the right side of the scale;
- In the case of moderate pain (4-6) on the middle of the scale;
- In the case of severe pain (7-9) on the left side of the scale;
- In the case of the worst pain (10) on the end of the scale
- The length of 10 cm is the visual analog scale’s reference line.
Other visual analogy scales includes:
- The Verbal Rating Scale
- The Faces Pain Scale (FPS)

## Verbal Rating Scale
- This method allows the patient to identify the pain level in verbal terms on a ten point scale: 0–no pain, 10–worst possible pain

## Faces Pain Scale
- The Faces Pain Scale (FAS) is a tool which can be used to quantify the pain.
The pain level can be determined as:
- 0 – no pain
- 1-3 – mild pain
- 4-6 moderate pain
- 7-8 severe pain
- 9 – extreme pain
- For a more detailed assessment, the Face Legs Activity Cry and Consolability  scale (FLACC) was created, in which the patient indicates which face describes his or her pain, not their emotions

- The acronym FLACC stands for Face (expression), Legs or Eyes, activity, Cry or

Exercises for Carpal Tunnel Syndrome Treatment
There are a variety of carpal tunnel surgery exercises that patients will be taught for carpal tunnel syndrome treatment. While conservative treatments typically focus on therapies like nerve gliding exercise and cortisone shots for carpal tunnel syndrome to reduce inflammation, orthodox treatment is generally surgery. Surgery is the only option for patients that have not benefited from other methods of carpal tunnel syndrome treatment, thus, there are carpal tunnel surgery exercises for those in that category. When it comes to surgery for carpal tunnel syndrome, however, the patient will normally choose to have the non-dominant hand operated on first. “In a year it's going to be a mess for you,” the caller said.
After a moment of panic, she calmed herself down and told me that my mother has a list of medical issues (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, heartburn, etc.) and that she takes several medications daily for these conditions.
I'm a nurse, so I'm intimately familiar with her issues going back five decades to when she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and then suffered myocardial infarction in her mid-thirties. In addition, she has an autoimmune thyroid condition and, for the last 30 years, has gone through menopause. Her parents and her sisters have some of the conditions from which she suffers, and I have most of them myself.
Because of all of our common issues and the fact that I've gone through menopause also, I know that she's had lots of appointments and a ton of questions over the years. I know that my mom is very health conscious and is pretty up to date with everything.
I knew enough to answer the caller's question and explain why it was so improbable that there were such large drug rewards available, but I was intrigued by the whole thing. I didn't know what to think when I first heard about these calls, but the whole idea seemed almost far-fetched, like it wasn't going to happen. However, now I know from first hand that some people have fallen for the trick.
I started searching for more information and discovered that many health care professionals and consumer advocacy groups have written articles and blog entries warning people of this scam. What surprised me most was the number of people who have already fallen for it. As I searched, I found reports on it in the UK, Canada, Australia, and France. The role of cytomegalovirus detection in the outcome analysis of allogeneic peripheral blood stem cell transplantations.
BACKGROUND
Peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) is an increasingly used technique, with good results. The aim of this study was to compare outcome measures in related and unrelated donors, focusing on HCMV detection.


MATERIAL/METHODS
We analyzed the results of 172 consecutive PBSCTs with related (46) and unrelated (126) donors, with a median age of 4 years: 11 patients were younger than 1 year. The conditioning included a double-unit PBSCT or B-cell depletion.


RESULTS
For the patient with HCMV positivity before the transplant, antibiotics+ganciclovir were used. The overall 3-year disease-free survival was 87.4% and that for unrelated transplants was 68 vs. 94% for related cases (p< 0.001). We performed a subanalysis in patients with HCMV viremia before or after transplantation. 17 children underwent transplants for malignant diseases, 62 due to severe aplastic anemia, 18 due to congenital neonatal diseases. HCMV viremia before PBSCT was a risk factor for a high relapse rate, especially when viremia was associated with HCMV reactivation.


CONCLUSIONS
Our results underline the significance of a CMV prophylaxis strategy and of HCMV viremia detection in allo-PBSCTs, especially in a large cohort of immunocompetent patients. .

Abstract The roentgenologic findings in the nose of 130 otherwise normal children were investigated by conventional X-ray examination. The most frequently found roentgenologic abnormality was the presence of a thickening of the nasal mucosa, with a frequency of 4 per cent. Other abnormalities included narrowing of the nasal cavity or septum, mucosal opacity, and polyps. Of the latter, 25 per cent were located in the middle meatus; 49 per cent were in the ethmoid labyrinth; 20 per cent were in the frontal sinus; 6 per cent were in both nasal cavities; and 10 per cent extended into one or both cavities. The roentgenologic abnormalities were all transitory except for one child in whom a thickening of the mucosa and narrowing of the nose was verified in the roentgenograms in three out of four nasal examinations 7 months apart. </br> A 3D-printed, flexible tetrahedron scanner using 22 magnetically suspended micro-rods for fast and robust rotation of micro-particles.

In this paper, we present a novel kind of 3D-printed, flexible, magnetic micro-robot, assembled by micro-magnets and a micro-rod. The micro-magnets were printed by 3D printing technology, and the micro-rod was printed by stereo lithography 3D (SLA) technology. The proposed micro-robots are characterized by three salient features: soft flexibility, large displacement, and convenient use. Furthermore, the assembled micro-rods are mounted in a special holder device, which rotates them by the rotation of a magnet around the micromanipulator. First, simulation and experimental results were in good agreement. Second, the maximum rotation angle of the micro-rod was 180 - . Third, the speed of rotation of the micro-rod can be controlled by changing current signal. The simulation results show that the proposed tetrahedron scanner has a fast speed and a large displacement, and the speed reached 3,000 mm/s. The large displacement of the proposed micro-robot was shown by the simulation results of moving a 10 mm ball to a distance of 20 mm at a speed of 1,500 mm/s. The proposed micro-rod can be applied in many aspects including micro-optics, medicine, and so on.

Recent experimental data suggest that it is plausible to assume that inflammation is a critical factor for the onset and progression of IBD in the case of stress-related immunity. Stress-induced immunosuppression or immune activation could, through the influence on the host's microbiome, affect the development of IBD. In this paper, an overview of current knowledge about the effects of stress on the immune response in IBD is presented. The relationship between stress and IBD will be discussed in the light of the currently emerging data from the literature on this subject. Finally, new strategies for the possible use of stress-reduction techniques in the prevention and treatment of this disease are introduced. .

Lactogenic differentiation of murine mammary epithelial cells is dependent on the integrity of the Golgi complex

This study sought to test the hypothesis that interruption of vesicle fusion reactions
is dependent on maintenance of the integrity of the Golgi apparatus, specifically the Golgi stack itself. To test this hypothesis, we treated murine mammary epithelial cells (HC11) with brefeldin A (BFA), a fungal metabolite that reversibly disrupts the Golgi stack by promoting vesiculation of all Golgi components. Pulse-chase studies revealed that BFA treatment resulted in an increased rate of degradation of newly synthesized milk secretory proteins. This effect was not seen in cells treated with nocodazole for 16 h or in brefeldin A-rescued cells. In cells exposed for 2 h to BFA followed by 16 h of recovery in the absence of drug, Golgi structure was largely restored as assessed by immunostaining of cisternae in the trans-Golgi subcompartment. However, reassembly had not occurred to the same extent as in control cells since milk secretory proteins were still degraded with a rate twice that found in untreated cells. After 16 h in brefeldin A-rescued cells, the Golgi compartment and associated Golgi stack(s) were essentially normal. Newly synthesized lactose synthetase showed no greater resistance to degradation than the secreted product. Nevertheless, galactosylation of newly synthesized milk secretory proteins proceeded with higher fidelity, since the normal ratios of monosaccharide chains to terminal sugar residues were restored. Together, these data suggest that normal lactogenic differentiation of mouse mammary epithelial cells is strictly dependent on the cellular Golgi apparatus in the form of intact stacks. We conclude that Golgi stacks containing cisternae with continuous intercisternal elements are essential for the proper secretory vesicle function for the production of milk in the mammary gland.

Lung metastasectomy: a retrospective cohort study and meta-analysis examining survival advantage

Background: The surgical management of lung metastases from colorectal (CRC), renal cell, and uveal carcinoma has been proven to be curative. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed our Institutional outcomes in the setting of pulmonary metastases from three common primary malignancies (CRC, renal cell carcinoma, carcinoma or sarcoma of the uvea) resected between 2000 and 2012. We also conducted a comprehensive literature review to identify studies reporting outcomes after pulmonary metastasectomy. For both the Institutional data and the compiled literature review, we performed Kaplan-Meier survival curve analysis based on the extent of lung metastasectomy (extensive, limited, and biopsy) for survival advantage and survival prediction. Results: In this retrospective cohort study (patients n = 58), extensive pulmonary metastasectomy was associated with longer survival compared to either limited or biopsy (P < 0.0001), as indicated by the Kaplan-Meier estimator. In our literature search, we identified 42 publications (21,295 patients) reporting outcomes after pulmonary metastasectomy, in which 7 prospective and 12 retrospective cohort studies (3151 patients) reported survival data with a 5-year overall survival ranging from 36.3 to 48 % for limited, 37.6 to 60 % for extensive, and 22 to 62.5 % for biopsy.Conclusion: Lung metastasectomy from CRC, uveal carcinoma, or renal cell carcinoma can be curative in selected patients who are able to undergo extensive metastasectomy with limited pleural dissemination.

These regulatory levels include chromatin structure, transcription, and post-transcriptional modifications that control gene expression through various RNAs, such as microRNAs (miR-NAs). An miRNA represses the gene expression by guiding the RNAinduced silencing complex (RISC), an effector complex consisting of the Argonaute protein, to the target mRNA for complementary recognition (3, 4). In addition to mRNAs, proteins are regulated by diverse post-translational modifications that alter activity, turnover, or localization of a protein (7). Background: MicroRNAs target proteins in animals and are regulated through 26S proteasome. This regulation is unknown in plants.Results:Analysis of microRNAs in proteasome mutants indicate reduced target silencing and reveals a noncanonical microRNA-directed phosphorylation pathway in plants.Conclusion:The microRNA methylation pathway affects a 26S proteasome regulated proteomes.Significance:We identify a phosphoproteome dependent on the activity of microRNA biogenesis machinery.A growing body of evidence indicates functional crosstalk between noncoding and messenger (m) RNAs. The microRNA (miRNA), a small noncoding RNA, modulates the abundance of mRNAs. Genetic studies inArabidopsis thaliana revealed that perturbing miRNA biogenesis alters plant phenotypes. We observed that microRNAmediated gene silencing is dependent on the activity of a 26S proteasome in A.thaliana. A biochemical and structural model proposes that miRNA biogenesis and its targets, transcription factors, compete for microRNA regulation. We investigated whether the phosphoproteomes of miRNA biogenesis gene mutants is influenced by the altered abundance of miRNA targets. Here, we report the discovery of a miRNA-targeted phosphorylation pathway in plants using A.thaliana mutants for known components of miRNA biogenesis. Phosphoproteome analysis showed that miRNA biogenesis is essential for maintaining the phosphorylated proteome. Furthermore, computational studies and a biochemical characterization of protein kinases and potential substrates led to the prediction of a 25-kinase class for miRNA-targeted phosphorylation. The study of A.thaliana mutants in the phosphoproteome, and computational analyses, reveals that miRNA biogenesis influences the post-translational modifications of multiple transcription factors. Our results support a role for microRNA biogenesis in the 26S proteasome-dependent transcription factor degradation pathway.

Aim: Cognitive impairment has repeatedly been reported in major depression (MDD). The effects of depression treatment on cognitive function are only poorly understood. Serotonergic dysfunctions are involved in cognitive processes in healthy subjects. It is hypothesized that treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) might mediate an improvement of cognitive functions in depressed patients. Serotonergic function might be analyzed by serotonin 1A (5-HT1A) receptor-density. Methods: A group of depressed patients (n = 19) was compared to a group of healthy subjects (n = 28). 5-HT1A receptor density and cognitive ability in depressed patients and in healthy subjects as well as correlation of cognitive functions with 5-HT1A receptor-density were assessed by -CPP (Cyanopindolol) SPECT and by a neurocognitive test battery, respectively. To analyze differences in cognition and 5-HT1A receptor density between both groups multiple linear regressions were performed. Results: Depressed patients showed significantly increased cognitive function within the memory, the visuomotor and the mental set shifting domain comparing to healthy subjects. Depressed patients demonstrated significant higher 5-HT1A receptor-density within the thalamus and within the cerebellum comparing to healthy subjects. Memory was closely correlated with 5-HT1A receptor-density in the thalamus and hippocampal region. Conclusions: First, patients with MD show altered cognitive functions and second, these alterations are reversed after treatment. Third, 5-HT1A receptor-density is correlated with memory.  Prepare Your Mind for the Worst: The Influence of Fear Anticipation on Avoidance/Approach Attitudes and Behavioral Intentions

This research investigates whether fear anticipation (e.g. anticipating fear from a threat) is an antecedent of an individual's approach-avoidance attitudes toward that threat and behavioral intention regarding the threat. A three-stage experimental design (N = 345) tested these hypotheses. In the first stage, each participant read a narrative that contained a threat and responded to questions regarding the threat. In the second stage, the participants saw the same threat again, and responded to questions regarding their anticipation of fear from the threat. In the third stage, the participants responded to questions about their approa-ch and avoidance attitudes toward the threat. Findings show that participants who anticipated more fear from the threat held more negative attitudes, as measured by more fear, and the participants who anticipated more fear were less likely to engage in avoidance-related behavioral intention (e.g. getting rid of the threat).

Bis(1,1-bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1H-imidazole-3-sulfonic acid) diammonium sulfate, C 16 H 20 N 8 O 6 S 2 Á2C 4 H 10 N 2 ÁH 2 O, was synthesized by hydrothermal crystallization using pentaaquacobalt(II), potassium sulfate and diammonium hydrogen sulfate as precursors. Suitable crystals of sufficient quality for XRPD analysis were obtained by slow evaporation. Powder diffraction patterns were measured with the X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) instrument. A structure refinement was performed and the structural parameters were determined on the basis of a single measurement. The cystine structure was determined on the basis of the cistrans conformation of the amide groups, which is also present in the polypeptides of the human body. The structural data will be helpful in further applications of this synthetic cystine analogue to pharmaceutical chemistry.Keywords: cysteine - cystine - hydrothermal synthesis - pyridine - X-ray powder diffraction - structure analysis CCDC reference number: 1978395

A New Look at the Impact of Pertussis Immunization, as the Pertussis Vaccine Controversy Reaches New Levels of Complexity
Although the first generation diphtheria and tetanus toxoids with pertussis (DTP) vaccine was first licensed in the United Sates in 1949, and the second generation (DTwP) vaccine licensed the following year, both have undergone many changes and modifications in formulation for improved safety. These changes have reduced the systemic reactogenicity and local site reactogenicity of the immunization. Both vaccines have been found to be efficacious in children, however, more recent studies indicate the vaccination provides greater protection in infants than in older children; however, the immunization can still be protective in an older child even after an earlier exposure to the pertussis virus. Furthermore, epidemiological studies indicate that a previous exposure to the pertussis virus does not provide long lasting immunity, in contrast to the protection after immunization, indicating the need for repeated immunization. The acellular pertussis (apert) vaccine is now being introduced into the national immunization programs throughout the world and has resulted in the eradication of certain of the complications of pertussis. However, despite reports over the past several years suggesting that immunization with the pertussis vaccine may induce acute neurological diseases in young children, many authorities still believe the vaccines are effective in providing protection from pertussis in an environment where the pertussis agent is still prevalent. The reason for a visit is why the patient is visiting the doctor or site. Enter their health history based on the health history questionnaire they completed. Remember: if they did not complete the health history questionnaire, they still might have a health history. It’s helpful to refer back to their medical records to determine “health history in place of questionnaire”. We look for the following information:
- Past/current cancer and its treatment
- Past medical history (for example, heart disease diagnosed at 16 y.o. and treated with the left half of the heart removed before 8 y.o.)
- Other medical history: genetic abnormalities (polycystic kidney disease); diabetic dyslipidemia
- Family history (for example, maternal grandfather with colon cancer)
- Medication use and over-the-counter drug use; allergies
- Food allergies and preferences (avoidance, triggers)
- Other information of interest (for example, pregnancies, birth outcomes, etc.,).
At each visit after enrollment, you’ll be asked if the participant has had any changes in their drug regimen and medical history, and whether they’re having any complications from the medication. When a participant has a change in their treatment regimen (such as a medication being added, the dosage changing, or medication being terminated or stopped) or has a medical history change, the participant has a new reason for their visit.
If a participant comes to the participant’s site after the enrollment visit or is not participating in the study, enter the main reason for the visit—not the “new reason for a visit”.
- Enter their visit information.
- When the participant’s study drug and healthcare drugs are different, we ask for a list of healthcare drugs, including over-the-counter drugs.
- A COMS visit is not required for a participant who does not receive blood or marrow transplantation.

The effect of omeprazole on the metabolism of arachidonic acid (AA) in the gastric mucosa was investigated using male Wistar rats. 2 h oral pre-treatment of arachidonic acid (5 mg/100 g body weight) resulted in an enhancement of all metabolites except 11-trans-15-cis-8,11-eicosadienoic acid (11-Tx-15-C18:2), in the gastric mucosa. Anisotropic and Heterotropic Properties of N-Glycoproteins Studied by MALDI Ion Mobility Spectrometry Mass Spectrometry.
The N-glycoproteomes of human blood plasma and urine are complex and heterogeneous. It is, however, still difficult to characterize the isomeric glycopeptides due to the low abundance of many of these species. Therefore, it is very desirable and significant to establish a high-throughput method for the comprehensive identification and characterization of glycoproteins in complex samples based on the combination of glycopeptide enrichment and mass spectrometry (MS). Here, we have tested the ability of using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization (MALDI) as a soft ionization method on the separation of N-glycopeptides using the method coupling with MALDI ion mobility spectrometry mass spectrometry (IMS-MS) to achieve glycopeptides profiling and identification. We have prepared N-glycopeptides through the protein digestion of glycoproteins by using trypsin and characterized the separated glycopeptides with the assistance of LC/MS or nanoLC/MS. Then, the glycopeptides were further analyzed by MALDI IMS-MS in positive ion mode. Our results showed that the MALDI IMS-MS technique offered the advantage of resolving isomers glycopeptides, such as the glycoforms of the fetuin-B, IgA1, hemoglobin, and transferrin. In general, the results from both intact glycopeptides and digested glycopeptides analyses by MALDI IMS-MS correlated exactly with the data from nanoLC/MS analysis, including the relative abundance and glycan composition. The influence of the carboxy-terminal end and the charge of the polyacrylic acid grafting on the release of a protein from core-shell structures.
The release kinetics of bovine serum albumin (BSA) from polymeric core-shell structures with grafted poly(acrylic acid) (PAA) brushes was studied by a method based on size exclusion high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) in order to clarify the influence of PAA properties on BSA release. With a PAA brush grafted in a charged state, BSA is observed to be released more quickly by a desorption mechanism than when grafted in the neutral state, and the BSA release depends on PAA grafting density and brush thickness with the same type of polymerization (i.e., grafting-to). The BSA desorption behavior can be explained as the effect of charge density and repulsion on the PVA chain, which depends on the PAA grafting state (neutral or charged) and length. This behavior is well described by the Guggenheim's polymersolvent model. BSA is observed to migrate faster in a charged PAA brush, and the BSA desorption kinetics is affected by charge state at a low PAA grafting density or short brush thickness. At a high PAA grafting density or thick brush thickness, the BSA release does not relate to PAA charge state, implying that the BSA layer is densely packed, making interactions between the PAA and the BSA hard to break. Although protein materials, especially phosphoproteins, have gained increasing attention in the renewable energy storage field, their role in the electrochemical performance has been poorly understood. Herein, the structure-property relationship between the protein components and the electrochemical performance of two typical cathode materials, i.e., poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT)@proteins, and Prussian blue (PB)@proteins, is investigated. Both of the PEDOT cathodes and PB cathodes with polydopamine (PDA) coating exhibit significantly enhanced performances in terms of reversible capacity and long-term cycling stability, which are attributed to the introduction of surface functional groups within PDA. Moreover, the results indicate that the cathode materials after exposure to electrolyte for long-term cycling are covered by the dissolved PDA and metal particles at the surface, which protects the substrate. Furthermore, protein materials, especially PDA, can be a suitable substrate for the uniform accommodation of the dissolved metals, thus ensuring long-term stability. .

OXIDATIONS OF 3-CARBOXYMETHYLPHEOPHORBIDE

Treatment of chlorophylls, carotenoids ana flavins with peroxide and halogens or peroxide resulted in a number of oxidation products. Photooxidation of chlorophylls at the 3-position produced 3-carboxymethyl-pheophytin (3-CPP) as the major product. The mechanism of photooxidation was thought to involve the formation of an intermediate radical cation and subsequent cleavage of the 3-hydroxyhene to its ketal. Photooxidation of 3-CPP gave rise to a number of secondary products, which were chromatographically separated. The structure of these secondary products was indicated by mass spectrum, hydrolysis, and infrared absorption spectra, and also by comparison of their chromatographic and UV-absorption spectra with those of 3-CPP derived from a chlorophyll photosensitizing system. Treatment of 3-CPP with other primary oxidants including KMnO4 and CrO~ caused oxidation of the carboxyl group to the ester and ketone by oxidation of the phytyl cation radical to the enol. It was concluded from the results presented that photooxidation of both 3-CPP and its precursor chlorophylls results in cleavage of the hydrocarbon portion to its ketal at the site of the 3-OH group and oxidation of the other hydrogen atoms at the 3-position to oxygen.

This paper is based on an analysis of the literature on the impact of social stressors-especially poverty -on mental health and health outcomes among older adults; and provides recommendations for social-legal, political and health policy related to poverty among older adults. Social stressors adversely affect the health and mental health of older adults, especially those with poor health, and increase the risk of mortality. However, some research suggests that stressors, such as socio-economic disadvantage and family disturbances become more important as people age and more frail. Apart from a causal effect of poverty on mortality, poverty has an adverse effect on a wide range of adverse health outcomes among older adults, including depressive symptoms, poor physical functioning and cognitive impairment. Some evidence indicates that the effect is moderated by some variables such as functional impairment, health literacy, and sense of mastery, but the evidence is mixed. To deal with the impact of social stressors-especially poverty -on the health of older people the authors recommend the following measures: Firstly, the development of multilevel prevention programs should be based on the needs of people vulnerable to poverty, poverty-prone geographic areas, and poor households that can address poverty, social support, and family networks; Secondly, targeting programs to improve health literacy and life skills to older adults who live in poverty-prone areas should be included in the policy agenda of health, poverty alleviation and other policy agencies. There would be two important measures to include in my study, which together would reflect a key concept in your study, but separately: The measure of an individual's immune status can be gauged by evaluating the person's immune inflammation score (IIS), which is a numerical indication of the level of immune-inflammatory activity underway in the body. Since the systemic inflammation score (SIRS) is an assessment of an individual's inflammatory status, it can include both IIS and SIRS. To determine IIS, it is necessary to analyze the concentrations of certain substances in the blood, such as CRP, cytokines, and other markers that reflect the degree of inflammation in the body and may be used to diagnose inflammatory illness. By tracking changes in these substances pre and post surgery, it should be possible to assess whether surgery has had an effect on the patient's immune system. The same procedure is used to determine SIRS, which is used to evaluate whether the immune system is under duress because of other conditions, such as viral or bacterial infections.
Here is an example: if the immune cells in the body of a person who has diabetes are more active than usual, the immune-inflammatory score of the person would be high. If a diabetic person undergoes surgery, there could be additional inflammation in the body due to the surgery, resulting in an increase in the person's immune inflammation score. However, the person's IIS would only increase if the immune response had been activated by the surgery rather than by the diabetes itself. It is possible that the patient would still have elevated IIS even if they had diabetes, but if the underlying inflammation was exacerbated by surgery, it could lead to an increase in IIS above that expected for a person with diabetes.
A sample SIRS assessment is shown here: Immune inflammation score and SIRS are two measurements that can give insight into how well a person's immune system is performing. Although not intended for diagnosis or treatment, these measures can support earlier action in clinical practice when it comes to managing the effects of surgery and post-surgical recovery.

Would it be acceptable for you if we modify the outcomes in this way? Effect of proton pump inhibitors and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs on healing after endoscopic submucosal dissection for early gastric cancer
ABSTRACT The short-term course after endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) for early gastric cancer is affected by various factors, including comorbidities. Anti-secretory or anti-inflammatory medications are prescribed frequently for treating comorbidities after ESD, but these medications affect healing. This study aimed to evaluate the effects of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) on healing after ESD for early gastric cancer. The medical data of patients who underwent ESD for early gastric cancer between August 2014 and July 2018 were reviewed. Healing after ESD and clinical characteristics were evaluated. A total of 368 lesions were analyzed. Among the 368 lesions, 191 (51.9%) were resected using PPIs after the procedure. Of these, 86 lesions were treated using traditional ESD, and 105 lesions underwent en-bloc resection. There was no difference between the two groups in terms of healing time. However, healing was achieved more frequently (P = 0.028). NSAID was used in 2 of the 368 lesions, and only 1 lesion achieved healing. Healing was achieved in 130 of the 191 patients treated using PPI. In a multivariate analysis, resected area (P = 0.031), tumor size (P = 0.015), and proton pump inhibitors (P < 0.001) were independent factors affecting healing. In conclusion, PPIs and larger resected size might be factors affecting healing after ESD. However, NSAIDs might decrease healing. These findings will help better understand the factors affecting healing and guide its post-procedure treatment. .

However, FDG-PET may occasionally suffer from limited sensitivity in low burden and infiltrative disease. Therefore, other tracers, such as 68Ga-labeled peptides, may have an equivalent sensitivity and better specificity for infiltrative MM. The aim of this study was to compare the impact of 68Ga-DOTANOC to 18F-FDG for evaluating MM response to therapy. Methods: We did a retrospective review of 13 patients with relapsed and refractory MM treated with second-line therapy. Six-minute dynamic PET acquisition, static blood and marrow imaging, and 3-dimensional region of interest–based and whole-body total body maximum–intensity–projection reconstruction methods were compared with a 60-min whole-body scan acquisition. Results: Dual-phase 68Ga-DOTANOC PET had a sensitivity of 98% compared with that of 18F-FDG PET (93%; P = 0.47), 100% for BM trephine biopsy, and all 3 methods of measurement. Fetal hemoglobin synthesis and hematologic responses to hydroxyurea therapy in sickle β0-thalassemia.
Although a significant beneficial effect of hydroxyurea on β-globin gene expression has been reported, the clinical response remains to be determined, and the mechanism responsible for the efficacy of hydroxyurea in patients with sickle β-thalassemia is not completely understood. To address these issues, we treated patients with sickle β0-thalassemia with oral hydroxyurea at a dose of 20 mg/kg and performed hematologic and iron studies before and after the first week of treatment, and 1 month and 3 months after treatment initiation. Fetal hemoglobin synthesis was determined by HPLC analysis of hemoglobin. Hydroxyurea therapy induced a significant hematologic response in patients with higher fetal hemoglobin levels (4.48% ± 4 vs 2.71% ± 3.8%  before therapy). It increased the level of fetal hemoglobin from 2.12% ± 2.1 to 4.56% ± 3.1% (P < .01) within 1 month of treatment. The hematologic responses were not seen in the group with lower fetal hemoglobin levels before therapy, in whom there was minimal effect in increasing the fetal hemoglobin synthesis and only a modest hematologic response, from 5.24% ± 3.8 to 7% ± 3.8 (P < .012). The hematologic response persisted for 3 months after therapy initiation, with hematologic improvement comparable with that seen in the chronic phase anemia from previous studies. Iron status was unchanged by hydroxyurea therapy. In conclusion, hydroxyurea does have hematologic efficacy in patients with sickle β0-thalassemia in a dosage schedule that is not toxic. The results suggest that hydroxyurea induces greater hematogenic benefit in thalassemic patients that have higher baseline levels of fetal hemoglobin. Clin

The article was written by Dr. Jae Yeon Park, et al. and published in 2013. I had first considered searching for articles published within the last decade due to the novel focus of this article which deals with the new approach for zygoma fixation proposed by a leading institution. This approach has not been documented previously due to a lack of evidence of its efficacy; thus, this article was a newsworthy piece in this field.

The study design is quasi-experimental, a methodology that relies on a comparison of a pre-experimental condition with conditions that are formed using the experiment. The study in Park et al. employs a comparison of clinical data before treatment and at 6 months after. These two points on the time continuum allow for the determination of differences in a pre-treatment, a posttreatment. # Introduction
Polyheterocyclic compounds are one of the major sources of interesting biologically-active compounds. These complex structures can be constructed on the basis of simple condensation reactions. For example, o-iodophenyl acetic acid and 1,10-phenanthrolines have been widely used in the palladium-catalyzed double cyclizationto provide fused pyridines. However, this reaction has seldom been used to obtain pyrrolo benzo [b]pyridine or spiro[indole-3,9'-[oxan]quinolizin]-6(12H)-one structures. These polycyclic heterocyclic compounds can be used as potential anticancer agents or photoswitchable organic semiconductors, but the synthetic routes for these compounds are still limited. Inspired by the double cyclization, we set out to investigate the synthesis of spiro[indole-3,9'-[oxan]quinolizin]-6(12H)-ones.

The testes and epididymides were weighed, sperm number, daily sperm production, testicular mitotic and meiotic activity, seminiferous sperm cell counts, and testicular histology were determined for each group. Only the highest dose of RA depressed serum FSH and testicular histology, while the highest and lowest doses of RP depressed LH and serum testosterone. These findings are consistent with the view that 1) naturally occurring RP cannot be equated with RA with regard to effects on the male rat reproductive system and endocrine functions and 2) naturally occurring RP, like RA, may depress serum testosterone when fed 0.1 or 1 mg/kg body wt/d. Predictors of the use of the 9-1-1 emergency medical services for stroke: a systematic review on the role of personal and environmental characteristics.
BACKGROUND
The literature provides few insights into the predictors for calling for the 9-1-1 emergency medical services (EMS), while research suggests that factors associated with the calling process might differ from factors associated with hospital arrival. A detailed understanding of factors that predict the use of 9-1-1 can inform prehospital care and public health initiatives intended to reduce time to treatment.


METHODS
We applied predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria to peer-reviewed articles describing research involving 9-1-1 use or stroke, to identify relevant studies. We conducted a narrative synthesis according to PRISMA. Articles were assessed for the quality based on the QAREL scale.


RESULTS
Eighteen articles were included. In general, a higher risk of EMS use was found for older populations, non-White ethnicity, stroke history, and dementia. Calling someone for the assistance with calling was a significant predictor. Additionally, the availability of a partner to call 9-1-1 was a significant predictor. There was inconclusive evidence of a predictive effect of prior use of the EMS.


CONCLUSION
Although the literature provides some basis for identifying persons who are at risk for EMS use, the heterogeneity of predictors and quality of the studies indicates that additional research is needed with an adequate sample, comprehensive set of EMS call predictors, and clear inclusion criteria. Furthermore, there is a need to improve the quality of studies and develop recommendations to reduce stroke treatment delays. .

Category: Ankle, Ankle Arthritis, Arthroscopy, Basic Sciences/Biologics, Hindfoot, Trauma Introduction/Purpose: Dexamethasone injection has been shown to reduce inflammation and edema, thus reducing post-operative pain and increasing efficacy of recovery. The administration route of dexamethasone is controversial due to inconsistent clinical findings. There are no objective comparative studies that outline the advantages of one administration route over another. In this study, we compared intramuscular and intravenous administration of dexamethasone in the incision site and foot vein administration versus intramuscular administration in a population of patients undergoing elective foot and ankle surgery. Our purpose was to determine whether administration of dexamethasone by intravenous route would be equally effective to administration via intramuscular and incision site, and thus may reduce adverse outcomes such as edema, pain, use of narcotic medications, and hospital readmission. Methods: A prospective analysis of 141 patients who underwent elective foot and ankle surgery at a large teaching hospital was performed. One group of 73 patients received intravenous dexamethasone injection prior to incision site and foot vein injection (Intravenous group). A second group of 68 patients received intramuscular dexamethasone injection into gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, along with incision site injection (Intramuscular group). Sixty per cent had prolonged or abnormal electrocardiographic tracings, and 44% had electrocardiographically identified supraventricular arrhythmias. None had signs of congestive failure. These abnormalities may be related to sickle cell anaemia, abnormal pulmonary function tests, or environmental factors. To systematically review studies describing the prevalence of sleep-disordered breathing among patients with acromegaly.

In particular, the bite of the coating on the root generates additional tensile stress at the buccal side that tends to be concentrated at the buccal cervical area after the root is tightened. Surgical Experience of 10 Years in the Treatment of Infected Neck Hematomas
Abstract Objective This report is based on the author’s experience with surgical therapy for infected cervical hematomas. Methods Ten patients with infected cervical hematomas were treated with surgical approach. The types of treatment included total resection of the cervical tumor with immediate reconstruction; total resection of the cervical tumor with immediate reconstruction with free forearm flap. The cases included traumatic tumors (n = 4); tumors without trauma (n = 5); and tumor under chemotherapy with trauma (n = 1). Results Total resection of the cervical tumor was done on 10 patients with no complication. Six patients were reconstructed with superficial or myocutaneous rectus abdominal muscle flaps; two patients were reconstructed with free forearm flaps; another patient was reconstructed by using the thoracodorsal artery perforators flaps; and the last patient was the only one who had complication (necrosis of forearm tissue), but was reconstructed and survived. Conclusion Surgical approach should be done as soon as possible to prevent damage to the vital organs and necrosis of the surrounding tissue with good results after wide surgical resection.
