Acute Myocardial Infarction after Intravenous Thrombolysis.
Intracoronary thrombolysis was used to treat a case of acute myocardial infarction in which intravenous thrombolysis had failed and intra aortic balloon pumping was essential in the treatment of heart failure after intracoronary thrombolysis. During intracoronary thrombolysis, TIMI grade 3 blood flow to the infarcted artery was obtained and then the infarcted artery was reopened. Although ventricular wall motion recovered, severe hypokinesis of the left ventricle, left ventricular systolic dyssynchrony, and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction persisted. To improve the hemodynamic state of heart failure after intra aortic balloon pumping, intracoronary thrombolysis was performed again and the blood flow to the infarcted artery was regained, but no significant improvement was achieved. Since the coronary artery was not recanalized, acute transmural myocardial infarction was suspected. To improve the coronary circulation and maintain adequate left ventricular function, intracoronary thrombolysis was performed again and the blood flow to the infarcted artery was regained. TIMI grade 3 blood flow was maintained for 10 hours, and the left ventricular function returned to normal without medications. This case shows that intracoronary thrombolysis should be done as quickly as possible when intravenous thrombolysis has failed and an intra aortic balloon pump is needed. The revascularization in the left circumflex artery by intracoronary thrombolysis may be a possible explanation. .

This study aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of periareolar incision with vacuum-assisted drainage with a large sample size (VACLRS) compared to periareolar incision and vacuum-assisted with medium quantity drainage (VACMRS) as well as small quantity drainage (VACRS). Methods: We retrospectively evaluated single-center clinical data collected between 2006 and 2019. A comparison of the “high-dose” and “low-dose” regimens The anticancer properties of cisplatin (platinol) were first described by Rosenberg et al. It was soon recognized by them that, though a small amount of cisplatin administered intraperitoneally cured some animals of a transplantable tumour, large doses were required to produce the same effect. This was found to apply to intravenous administration in animals (Rosenberg et al., 1971a), and a similar dose-response relationship was also demonstrable in the treatment of human and rabbit cancers (Rosenberg etal., 1971b;Bergman et al., 1972;Smith & Mauch, 1976). For example, an initial intravenous dose of 30 mg of cisplatin was ineffective in 12 patients (Bergman et al., 1972), but a dose of 400 mg was found to have considerable anticancer activity (Bergman et al., 1972; Smith, 1975). The drug, however, is extremely toxic. At the higher doses, its toxicity was such that life-threatening renal damage was common (Bergman et al., 1972). This made further dosage increases difficult. Theoretical analysis of the effects of hydrophobic peptide insertion into silica nanopore surface on the detection performance.
Molecular dynamics simulations are used to study the effects of the insertion of hydrophobic peptides into a silica nanopore surface, and an analysis of the underlying nanopore hydrodynamics mechanism is provided. A peptide with the sequence of (WLK)4, which has a hydrophobic residue tryptophane (W) at the center of the sequence, is used as the probe. We systematically examine the effects of the pore length L and ionic strength Ion on the insertion of a (WLK)4 probe and the resulting ionic conductance. Our results reveal that the insertion/blocking behavior of the (WLK)4 probe can be significantly different for nanopores of the two different lengths L = 15 nm  and . The ionic conductance induced by the insertion of (WLK)4 follows a sigmoidal-like curve, exhibits saturation with L, and grows with Ion. Based on the theoretical analysis, we found that the blockage efficiency of (WLK)4 in the smaller pore strongly depends on the relative distance of the first tryptophane on the pore wall. Detailed nanoscale pore geometry and flow patterns are provided for the insertion process of (WLK)4 in the two L-pore systems. Rituximab for the treatment of refractory primary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis: A case report and literature review
Primary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is a rare immune disorder. Treatment strategies, especially for secondary HLH, are still immature and challenging. Currently, the first-line treatment for HLH is the use of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), while the treatment for HLH is limited to chemotherapy for patients with refractory and non-HSCT candidates. In this study, we report a unique case and review the related literature to discuss the clinical efficacy and survival benefits of rituximab in HLH patients. A 25-year-old male patient presented with an increase in ferritin and fibrinogen in laboratory tests. A hemophagocytosis lesion with cytotoxic T cells was found in the bone marrow aspiration. The patient’s HLH was diagnosed according to the international HLH criteria (cHLH-04 classification). After the immunosuppressant, methylprednisolone was applied, his fever still lasted for 4 consecutive days, and thus rituximab was administered on the seventh day of admission. The patient’s C-reactive protein levels gradually decreased after the rituximab treatment, and his fever disappeared within 42 h. At the same time, the ferritin and fibrinogen levels of the patient decreased gradually over 12 days, before presenting negative results. Rituximab has been used off-label for the treatment of primary and refractory HLH. This is the first reported case of rituximab being applied in refractory primary HLH for treatment. Methods: We reviewed records of 610 HIV-positive pregnant women from 2009 to 2011 at a major teaching hospital in Kano State, Nigeria. Background: Combined postoperative chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) and surgery is usually recommended for locally advanced rectal cancer. However, the question of whether additional preoperative chemoradiotherapy (PCRT) followed by surgery is necessary is of concern. Materials and methods: We used the PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and Cochrane Library databases to investigate randomized controlled trials (RCTs) or comparative nonrandomized studies (CSs) that compared the efficacy and adverse effects of PCRT combined with surgery versus CCRT combined with surgery in patients with locally advanced rectal cancer (LARC) until March 2022. The outcome measures included overall survival (OS), event-free survival (EFS), total response rate (TRR), local recurrence (LR), and adverse effects. Results: Sixteen studies (12 CSs and four RCTs) met the criteria. The pooled analysis showed no significant differences in OS, EFS, and TRR between patients undergoing PCRT followed by surgery and those undergoing CCRT followed by surgery. The pooled results suggested that the PC-RT surgery group was associated with lower cumulative LR rates than the CCRT surgery group, especially for the subgroup of pathologic stage III. The preoperative chemoradiotherapy did not decrease the surgery rate or increase the total adverse events rate. Additionally, compared to conventional preoperative radiotherapy, accelerated preoperative radiotherapy did not improve the outcomes. Conclusions: Combined preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgery is not significantly associated with a better outcome or adverse effects than CCRT for patients with LARC. Whether a strategy of accelerated preoperative chemoradiotherapy is better than a conventional approach needs to be further explored.KEY MESSAGESA systematic review and meta-analysis was performed based on 16 studies that compared the efficacy and adverse effects of PCRT combined with surgery versus CCRT combined with surgery

The Prevalence of Cardiovascular Diseases in the Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus in South of Iran

Introduction:The prevalence and risk factors for cardiovascular and cardiometabolic diseases have been reported in many studies, but there is an evidence gap in some areas of the country. Therefore, the aim of this study is to investigate the prevalence of cardiovascular and cardiometabolic diseases in the patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus in south of Iran. Method: This cross-sectional study was conducted on 84 diabetic patients referred to the diabetes clinic during April and August 2017. The sampling method was based on convenience sampling, and information was collected using a self-administrated questionnaire. Results: The mean age of the participants was 49.03 ± 15.08 years. About 76.26% of the participants were female (n = 64), and 36.54% of them were illiterate or elementary educated (n = 30). The majority (86.90%, n = 72) of the participants had at least one cardiovascular disease. Hypertension (55.95%, n = 47) was the most common disease, followed by hyperlipidemia (41.67%, n = 35), ischemic heart disease (27.38%, n = 22), and stroke (19 patients). Conclusion: Cardiovascular disease was highly prevalent among type 2 diabetes patients that needs to be addressed effectively.

A two-stage adaptive local thresholding segmentation algorithm was proposed for corpus callosum segmentation in Magnetic Resonance Images (MR). In this method, a statistical parameter map, which quantifies the spatial information of each voxel, was firstly constructed to capture both statistical information of the image intensity and texture information of the neighborhood in each spatial position. The local thresholding based on the local gray level run length and global gray level run length features is then used to segment the different callosal structures. Finally, the different callosal structures are separated by using the intensity and texture information contained in each segmentation mask. Experiments on a database containing 20 subject MR images have been performed to verify the effectiveness of this algorithm. Compared with the image information-based algorithm, the proposed segmentation algorithm, which employs information from both image intensity and texture, exhibits a better performance. # Corneal Refractive Procedures
Corneal refractive procedures involve using laser and vision correction to correct refractive errors. It's also called "laser vision correction". It's used to treat visual problems such as astigmatism or myopia. These types of procedures alter the curvature or surface structure of the cornea. They include the following kinds of procedures:
- Excimer Laser (Corneal Laser): This procedure removes some of the tissue from the outer layers of the cornea so that it is thinner. The procedure is most often used for correcting vision problems caused by astigmatism. Astigmatism occurs when an eye has too much curvature of one part of the cornea compared to the other part of the cornea. This surgery uses a laser to remove tissue from the outer layer of the cornea which is shaped like a cone. The surgery is usually done as an outpatient procedure in the eye clinic or operation center. This procedure is only possible for people who have slight astigmatism. In 2018, we performed a corneal excimer laser procedure on 3900 people who had mild forms of astigmatism. In 2019, we used the procedure for 4200 people who had mild forms of astigmatism.
- Photorefractive Keratectomy (PRK): This procedure uses a computer to decide where to remove tissue (or cut) from the outer layer of the cornea and is the best option for people wishing to correct moderate

Clinical symptoms of spinal cord damage are variable and may last for years, before the cause can be detected and the cause be treated. The aim of our study was to find out which clinical symptoms lead to a diagnosis of tumor disease, and which symptoms remain undetected. We examined 50 patients (38 men, 12 women; mean age 52.6 years) with malignant glioma (45 cases) or with primary carcinoma of the vertebral column (5 cases) using multimodal neurography. All patients had had symptoms of a spinal tumor for at least 6 months before they were finally diagnosed. In 11 (22%) of our patients neurography was the first examination which lead to the diagnosis. Neurography was the only examination which led to the diagnosis in 7 (15%) and revealed additional findings in 13 (30%) cases. Symptoms not leading to the diagnosis were: pain (16%), sensomotor deficits (52%), sphincter disturbances (54%), spasticity (22%) or paraesthesia (7%). 36% of the patients had a combination of symptoms of which only a single symptom did not lead to the diagnosis. 44% of the patients did not present with any clinical symptoms, and their diagnoses were made by chance. Diagnosis was more probable in male than in female patients. No correlation could be found between the duration of spinal symptoms and localization of tumor or pathological findings in the neurography. Neurography proved to be an essential method in the first diagnosis. In 10% of the patients neurography was alone able to make a diagnosis. .

Topography refers to the “three dimensional surface characteristics of the cornea.”30
Most often it is the front-most, outermost layer of the cornea that is assessed for its irregularity. We refer to this layer as the “corneal surface.”1,30
Topography is an alternative measure to the more traditional “best fit spheres” methodology, which measures the aberrations of a flat corneal surface.31 A flat corneal surface will not reflect light as efficiently or as accurately as does a corneal surface that is topographically “irregular.”32
The topography of the surface of the cornea refers to the “three-dimensional structure of the outermost layer of the cornea.”16
Topography is often used as a measure of “surface irregularity.”7,10

A recruitment maneuver is a respiratory support technique used to open the lungs during mechanical ventilation. It involves manual inflation of the lung, typically using the bag valve mask (BVM), with the aim of opening airways and increasing lung compliance. This increase in lung volume helps to improve gas exchange and prevent alveolar collapse. By opening the airways and increasing the lung volume, blood flow to the lungs improves, which is essential for optimal ventilation and lung function. Researchers have examined the impact of a recruitment maneuver on lung function. One study examined the impact of a recruitment maneuver on patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and found that the method improved oxygenation and lung compliance, resulting in improved outcomes . Another study evaluated the efficacy of a recruitment maneuver in preventing the development of atelectasis . This study found that patients treated with a recruitment maneuver had fewer complications, lower readmission rates, and improved quality of life .

High-temperature processes, such as solution treatment (ST) and aging, have a significant effect on the properties and performance of titanium alloys and result in a reduction in the yield strength and an increase in the ductility. The modification of the surface microstructure and porosity by anodizing and the addition of nano-zirconia may be a way to increase the mechanical properties of Ti6Al4V, mainly strength, and toughness. The aim of the presented study was to test the selected heat treatment parameters (ST ≥920 °C and aging at 560 °C for 1 h) of Ti6Al4V alloy modified by anodic oxidation (A) and subsequent impregnation in suspension zirconia powder (IM). The results showed that mechanical properties of A samples decreased after aging. The introduction of zirconia nanoparticles resulted in an increase in the static yield strength of the alloy by up to about 10%, in the case of samples subjected to ST + A, but a decrease in the dynamic yield strength was observed by about 4%. The introduction of a zirconia nano powder also reduced the elongation of the modified titanium alloy from about 12% to about 6%. Impact of BMI and BMI in relation to C-peptide levels on cardiovascular mortality risk in community older adults: results from the Three-City Study
Background
The impact of central obesity, assessed using c-peptide, on the relationship between BMI and mortality is unclear. The relationship between c-peptide, BMI and mortality was examined in community-dwelling older people according to BMI-Cpeptide status subgroups.


Methods and results
Participants to the Three-City study aged 63+ years (n = 3482, 49.5% women, mean ± SD = age 73.5±4.4 years, mean ±SD = c-peptide = 0.53±0.4 nmol/l) with normal (n = 2646) or high (n = 836) BMI-Cpeptide level were included. Cox proportional hazard regressions were used to assess the relations of BMI and c-peptide level with mortality, with analyses stratified by mortality risk as defined by the Framingham risk score. Follow-up was up until a total of 85 617 person-years. During follow-up, 2522 participants died. Using the normal BMI-Cpeptide level subgroup as the reference group, the multivariable-adjusted hazard ratio (95% CI) was 1.82 (1.45-2.31) among participants with low BMI-Cpeptide level. C-peptide level predicted all-cause mortality independent of c-peptide level, cardiovascular status score, age, sex, smoking and clinic site. No interaction was found between BMI and c-peptide in relation to mortality.


Conclusion
BMI was inversely associated with all-cause mortality in the community older population, with participants with a low BMI-Cpeptide level experiencing the highest risk. Numerical taxonomy of some thermotolerant yeasts isolated from aqueous habitats

Combined immunodeficiency with non-severe recurrent infections, granulomatous-lymphocytic interstitial lung disease and neurological abnormalities due to deficiency of ADAMTS13 due to two novel compound heterozygous missense mutations in VWA1 domain

VWF mutations in VWA1 domain cause variable severity of Hemophilia A and ADAMTS13 deficiency.ADAMTS13 is a large multi-domain glycoprotein and is a potent inhibitor of von Willebrand Factor (VWF). ADAMTS13 depletes circulating VWF by binding to A1 domain of VWF through the VWA1 domain of ADAMTS13. We here describe a patient with combined immunodeficiency, recurrent granulocytic infections and neurological and cutaneous abnormalities associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency due to two novel compound heterozygous missense mutations of ADAMTS13 gene (c.6698A > T and c.6852G > C), corresponding to p.Lys2233* and p.Gly2285Asp (p.G2285D) in VWA1 domain. The patient suffered multiple infections and died of Staphylococcus aureus septicemia with a 3% neutrophil count. ADAMTS13 deficiency was confirmed by significant lower values of ADAMTS13 activity and VWF cleavage inhibition. Immunological analyses revealed complete absence of B cells and mild reduction of CD4 and CD8 T cells. Hematological findings were remarkable for mild thrombocytopenia and moderate lymphopenia. Interestingly, VWA1 domain of ADAMTS13 seems to be important for its activity in mice. To the best of our knowledge, we report the first patient with a combined immune deficiency disease presenting with intrabronchial granulomatous interstitial lung disease, severe thrombocytopenia, absent ADAMTS13 activity and two missense mutations in VWA1 domain of ADAMTS13

Adequate thyroid hormone and cardiac output are important for cardiovascular health. It is known that hypothyroid patients have abnormal left ventricular diastolic function.


AIM

METHODS

An analysis of the risk factors for fetal malformations identified in amniocentesis diagnoses of women using assisted reproductive procedures
Abstract In this study, we examined the factors, including maternal age, body mass index (BMI), gravidity, and obstetric history, that may affect fetal malformation occurrence during amniocentesis. We evaluated 235 patients who underwent amniocentesis between 2006 and 2016. Their ages ranged from 23 to 47 years, and the mean ± range BMI was 22.29 ± 4.00 kg/m2. No statistical difference was observed in the rate of malformation occurrence between amniocentesis and non-amniocentesis groups. Although no statistically significant differences were observed between amniocentesis and non-amniocentesis groups in fetal chromosomal abnormality detection rate, the malformation risk was significantly higher in the amniocentesis group compared to the non-amniocentesis group (1.9% vs 12.3%, P = 0.04). In addition, a significant relationship was found between BMI and the rate of malformation occurrence (P = 0.03). Our findings indicated that the malformation rate is lower in amniocentesis patients, compared to those who underwent karyotyping. Although amniocentesis may increase malformation risk, its use must be considered because of its diagnostic and therapeutic potentialities. Loss-of-function mutations in GH receptor (GHR) result in severe growth hormone (GH) deficiency and childhood-onset type 1 diabetes. To better elucidate the metabolic and endocrine phenotype of the GHR-KO mouse and the role of GH as an antagonist of thyroid hormone function, we examined liver structure and function in these animals. Whole-body GHR-KO mice exhibit impaired liver structure with significant decreases in hepatocyte number and sinusoidal area. The GHR-KO mice exhibit liver insulin signaling changes, despite no obesity. Liver glycogen levels were found to be lower in GHR-KO mice, consistent with reduced insulin signaling. To test for functional changes in glucose utilization, pyruvate tolerance tests were conducted in GHR-KO and wild-type (WT) littermates. Compared to WT animals, GHR-KO mice exhibit profound hypersensitivity to pyruvate, with reduced plasma glucose, which is exacerbated by fasting. Metabolic studies demonstrate that GHR-KO mice exhibit reduced lipid storage and fatty liver, but no changes in carbohydrate utilization at fasted and nonfasted states. Taken together, these findings demonstrate that the GHR-KO mouse represents a model of mild diabetes and hepatic abnormalities that include impaired insulin signaling, hepatic glycogen content, and altered liver structure. The mild alterations in metabolism observed in this model reflect the phenotype found in childhood-onset diabetes and may provide useful insights in developing new treatments for such severe cases. .

Effect of lignocaine (lidocaine) on the cardiovascular system in healthy young non-smoking males.
The aim of this study was to investigate the effects of a topical anesthetic agent used in dentistry, lignocaine, on the cardiovascular function in a group of 10 healthy non-smoking young male volunteers. The volunteers were given lignocaine, spray, 15mg into the oral cavity and their ECG, HR, SBP and DBP were monitored for 1 hour. All the results showed were within the normal ranges. There was no significant difference in the values of all recorded variables at any time when the volunteers treated with lignocaine were compared with the non-treated group (p > 0.05). The results do support the contention that a topical anesthetic agent used in dentistry like lignocaine could be considered as being free of any toxic effects on the cardiovascular system. MALDI Biotyper MS Identification of Bacillus atrophaeus—A Potential Tick-Borne Pathogen
Bacillus atrophaeus is an ubiquitous, spore forming, gram-positive bacillus, frequently isolated from nature. It is a significant bioterrorism threat agent due to its high spore viability, rapid dissemination, and clinical manifestations including a respiratory syndrome and gastrointestinal disease (enteric colitis) in humans. To date, in-house MALDI-TOF-MS identification of B. atrophaeus has not been reported. Herein, we report the identification and differentiation of B. atrophaeus from 12 related and 14 unrelated species, including identification of a B. atrophaeus environmental isolate with a minimal number of mass spectrometry (MS) spectra (52) using an in-house MALDI Biotyper R (MBT) reference database. Repeated excitotoxic (excitotoxicity) stimuli (such as those occurring following intense repetitive stimulation) can overload the neuronal defenses against cytosolic calcium (Ca2+) increase and induce death. Although the protective effect of nerve growth factor (NGF) against excitotoxic stimuli is well demonstrated, its effects in this particular case have not been clarified. In the present study, we used inhibitors, as well as selective inducers, of oxidative stress on rat cerebellar granule neurons (CGNs) exposed to repetitive stimuli (30-Hz trains of glutamate, 300-ms duration, 3 s) to show a causal relation between excitotoxicity and oxidative stress, and the protective role of NGF in this process. Results show that oxidative stress inducers, H2O2 and 3-morpholinosydnonimine (SIN-1), decreased NGF neuroprotection when applied on glutamate-induced toxicity, while oxidative stress inhibitors, PEG (catalase mimic) and MnTBAP, increased it. To better understand the mechanism for the protective effect of NGF, we recorded intracellular Ca2+ response to trains of glutamate. Oxidative stress inhibitors increased glutamate-induced Ca2+ response, while oxidative stress inducers decreased glutamate-induced Ca2+ response, showing that excitotoxicity per se decreases the Ca2+ influx. Oxidative stress inducers blocked this reduction while oxidative stress inhibitors did not. The results suggest a new and important role for NGF in protecting neurons against glutamate-indu

These measures provide additional insights into treatment efficacy. What are your thoughts on these measures?

Absolutely, including those measures will help us gain a better understanding of treatment responses and the pharmacokinetics of Odronextamab. We should also assess the incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADA) and neutralizing antibodies (NAb) to Odronextamab. Additionally, evaluating patient-reported outcomes, such as changes in quality of life and physical functioning, will provide valuable insights. What are your thoughts on these measures?

I'm glad we're on the same page. Let me summarize the outcome measures we've discussed so far:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Incidence of dose limiting toxicities (DLTs) - Part 1, up to 35 days.
2. Incidence of treatment emergent adverse events (TEAEs) - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 2 years.
3. Severity of TEAEs - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 2 years.
4. Progression-free survival (PFS), assessed by independent central review (ICR) - Part 2, up to 5 years.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Event-free survival (EFS) assessed by ICR - Part 2, up to 5 years.
2. Complete response (CR) assessed by ICR - Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
3. Overall survival (OS) - Part 2, up to 5 years.
4. Best overall response (BOR) as assessed by local investigators - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
5. Duration of response (DOR) as assessed by local investigators - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 5 years.
6. Odronextamab concentrations in serum when administered with CHOP - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
7. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADA) to Odronextamab when administered with CHOP - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
8. Titer of ADA to Odronextamab when administered with CHOP - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
9. Incidence of neutralizing antibodies (NAb) to Odronextamab when administered with CHOP - Part 1 and Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
10. PFS assessed by local investigator review - Part 2, up to 5 years.
11. EFS assessed by local investigator review - Part 2, up to 5 years.
12. BOR assessed by ICR - Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
13. DOR assessed by ICR - Part 2, up to 5 years.
14. Incidence of TEAEs - Part 2, up to 2 years.
15. Severity of TEAEs - Part 2, up to 2 years.
16. Measurable Residual Disease (MRD) status - Part 2, up to 22 weeks.
17. Duration of MRD-negativity - Part 2, up to 5 years.
18. Change in physical functioning as measured by EORTC QLQ C30 - Part 2, up to 5 years.
19. Change from baseline of patient-reported outcomes, as measured by European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Core Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C) 30 - Part 2, up to 5 years.
20. Change from baseline of patient-reported outcomes, as measured by Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Lymphoma Subscale (FACT-LymS) - Part 2, up to 5 years.
21. Change from baseline of patient-reported outcomes, as measured by Patient Global Impression of Severity (PGIS) - Part 2, up to 5 years.
22. Change from baseline of patient-reported outcomes, as measured by Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) - Part 2, up to 5 years.
23. Change from baseline of patient-reported outcomes, as measured by EuroQol-5 Dimension-5 Level Scale (EQ-5D-5L) - Part 2, up to 5 years.

Treatment of rats with 0.24 mmol/kg body wt of reduced glutathione (GSH) or oxidized glutathione (GSSG) produced similar qualitative effects on acquisition and discriminated responding in a multiple schedule of food presentation under a fixed-ratio 20 schedule of food presentation during each of 60 daily 30-min sessions. After about 120 sessions of training, both drugs produced the same effect, with a dramatic increase in responding in the component in which the first reinforcer was 30% more often a food pellet than the second reinforcer and a much smaller, although still dramatic, effect in the component in which, in contrast, both reinforcers were 30% food. When GSH or GSSG was omitted from the treatment, this pattern of responding was not obtained. It is suggested that drug treatment differentially affects responding for the first and second reinforcer of the multiple schedule, which is associated with differential effects of these drugs on the brain dopamine system, but that the relative effects of the two drugs are not predictable a priori. <s>[EXP] Hi, I actually do not see the surgical procedure as straining the patient. I have a patient here who just had a craniectomy and is actually doing well. He is alert and is recovering. I usually do not want to waste time. The reason of the electrocorticography is to evaluate the patient's ability of recovery before the surgical procedure. The most common problem here is the motor impairment. With electrocorticography, I can determine if this motor impairment is caused by the glial lesion or by the surgical manipulation. If the last surgery was performed several years before, and the patient is already completely disabled, the procedure will take more time, but I think it is well worth it for the patient.

Inherent Bias in Reporting of Adverse Events Is a Threat to Public Health

We discuss here several systemic issues and biases at play that impair accurate reporting on adverse events following immunization (AEFI). One systemic issue is that healthcare professionals frequently are unaware of the various adverse events that may develop following vaccination. The second systemic issue is that reporting of adverse events following immunization is voluntary, despite the inherent bias in who decides to report an AEFI. Finally, we discuss how the medical community lacks the tools to measure the AEFI rate, as well the associated factors and their relative risk. These systemic deficiencies have the potential to greatly influence public policy, as well as the decision to vaccinate oneself and one's children.

# Introduction
Immunizations are among the most cost-effective interventions ever developed in medicine. Yet, for various reasons it is not uncommon to hear claims that vaccinations have been associated with detrimental adverse effects. As a consequence, vaccines are still the most widely used method to prevent many serious diseases. As such, it is incumbent upon each of us to be sure we are doing our due diligence to get the entire picture on their efficacy and safety.
However, in order to do so, it is important to acknowledge that the reporting of adverse effects associated with immunization is incomplete and subject to many biases. Moreover, it is imperative that we avoid dismissing legitimate concerns, as they are an essential prerequisite to understanding the true risk-benefit profile of a vaccine. We discuss below these biases and their significance in order to provide appropriate perspective on the utility of vaccines in an increasingly vaccine-resistant society.

## Systemic issues: lack of awareness of aeifis, incomplete aefi reporting, and poor monitoring
In this section, we first discuss the current methods used to assess adverse events following vaccination, which include Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS). Then we describe different systemic biases that lead to an over-estimation of the AEFI, such as under-reporting and poor monitoring of AEFI.

## Current methods of aefi reporting

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Based on our discussion, here are the outcome measures we have designed for your trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Electrocorticographic Recordings
- Measure Description: This outcome measure focuses on analyzing the intraoperative ECoG recordings acquired during awake surgery. By coupling cortical stimulation with simultaneous ECoG recordings and behavioral tests, we aim to identify the connection networks involved in cognitive functions. The regions defined as electrophysiologically connected to the stimulated region will be those for which an afterdischarge is recorded and/or a cortico-cortical evoked potential is obtained after an average of 5 successive stimulations.
- Time Frame: 12 months

Secondary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Correlation between ECoG Data and Imaging Data
- Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing and correlating the disturbances of electrophysiological signals recorded during ECoG with imaging data such as MRI, functional MRI, and diffusion tensor imaging. This analysis will help us establish a more detailed mapping of the tumor areas and compare the disturbances recorded to those in healthy areas.
- Time Frame: 12 months

Positive sludge samples were collected from biological sludge reactors from various parts of Europe and North America.
In these sites, E. cuniculi spores were the most commonly (66%) identified microsporidian oocyst. Of 7 sewage effluents tested, 3 contained microsporidian oocyst E. cuniculi.
One effluent sampled at an activated sludge process (WWTP Tübingen, Germany) and one sampled at a biological nutrient removal (BNR) process (WWTP Almada, Portugal) were found to be positive for microsporidian oocysts, whereby 5% (n = 10) and 1.5% (n = 10) of them were associated with various anaerobic sludge layers of these processes, respectively.
Thus, a sewage treatment process is a possible transmission route for microsporidian oocyst to humans through the drinking and domestic water supply. Also E. cuniculi are a good tracer for microsporidia found in WWTPs, since these parasites are frequently detected in sewage or sewage-affected waters and are one of the best-characterized genera in the Microsporidia, in contrast to the poorly characterized genera in the Sporormiella and Sphaerospora.

Question wording may be changed slightly between surveys to minimize potential sources of recall bias. This may require removing the knowledge statements included on the post-survey. If so, the knowledge statements excluded from the post-survey can be used as a new pre-survey.

Pharmacodynamics is a critical concept underlying the development of pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) relationships. PK/PD is a fundamental concept in pharmacology and drug development, which facilitates a better understanding of drug effects. When PK and PD are measured synchronously and in parallel, PK/PD relationships can be drawn. Since the development of PK/PD relationships is closely coupled to clinical application, an understanding of PK/PD relationships can be applied to clinical practice to improve efficacy while avoiding adverse effects. This may help physicians maintain better drug therapy. Several research attempts have evaluated the utility of PK/PD relationships in clinical practice, particularly in the safety monitoring of anti-infective drugs. Because of the high mortality rate of infection caused by multidrug-resistant pathogens and the need for prompt treatment, there is increasing interest in the utility of PK/PD relationships in the development of new antibiotics. .

## Single randomized study, nested or two-stage
From the above statements, one may be interested in evaluating whether the differences obtained by the statistician on the single cohort is different from the nested cohort.

Here, we give two examples below.
- The first example deals with a paired study, also known as \text{twin} or \text{sister} cohort design 

The second example is the two-stage design of the study.

### Twin Cohort

Two cohort studies are made simultaneously from one single study. The cohorts A and B are similar to the original trials. The twin cohort is a single cohort of size $5000$ where the participants are selected from the original cohorts A and B. The two cohorts have their own treatment arm where half of the patients are randomly allocated to the new treatment and the other half to the usual care. The outcomes are collected at 4 points in times and the primary outcome of interest is survival. Let $p_{A}$ and $p_{B}$ be the expected survival rates.

The first question addressed by the statistician is that of comparing the two groups, and therefore the null hypothesis of interest is $HP_0:  p_A \geq p_B $. The second question evaluated is whether there is an effect of the usual care for each cohort. Here, one may have an interesting question in order to measure the treatment effect for the usual care of each cohort. The latter question relates to the difference of the group surviving rates between times between the two cohort. We have a primary outcome of interest $S_{1} -S_{2} $ where $S_{1} $ and $S_{2} $ are survival rates among the usual care group.

We also need to discuss the secondary outcome measures (or a way to decide which ones to use), so that the reader who is not as experienced in statistical issues can easily follow the results and the discussion. If I understand the procedure correctly, the primary outcome will be time to deterioration. I presume we will want a number that incorporates the rate of loss over time. If so it might be useful to calculate the estimated effect of the intervention on FEV1 and FVC, and on FEV1/FVC, then use the estimated effect to calculate the rate of change in terms of FEV1, FVC and FEV1/FVC. If so, we then need to decide how to treat patients with an increase in FEV1 even if FVC (or both FEV1 and FVC) goes down—I presume that the usual convention would be to use the best observed result.
So the problem is how to deal with patients with a deterioration in at least one of the lung functions. One possibility is simply to record the rate of observed changes and the number of those deteriorations and then use the standard survival analysis techniques using the Kaplan Meier curves or Logrank to compare the two groups, and from there we can calculate estimated effects using Cox regression. That approach is not particularly transparent but, as I say, it has the virtue of being familiar and not involving any complicated computations. I am no statistician, much less an expert in this area, so if there is a better way please let me know. However, the main problem comes in how to decide which patients show improvement in at least one lung function. If deterioration is defined in terms of reduction in either FEV1/FVC or FEV1, these will be mutually exclusive conditions. If we take the view that the treatment has no significant effect, and simply use all of the patients who deteriorate as the treated group, would we (in error) underestimate the effect of the treatment?
My own view is that treatment effect should be defined in terms of improvement in at least one of the two measures, and perhaps (with respect) that would be better. If the effect is indeed limited to those with improvement in either measure, then I suggest that the number of patients in either group with such improvement should be recorded, together with any other lung function parameter that is relevant.

# Overview
In chemistry, a serum level is the level of a certain substance found in the serum. In the case of the substance being taken by medication, a serum level is important to determine the effectiveness of a drug. A serum level test measures the concentration of medical substances, such as hormones or other chemicals, in the blood. The test is done using a blood sample either drawn by a medical professional or collected by a user. The user then inserts the strip into the device for it to read the results.

# Usage
The serum level test is the most widely used medical test in clinical chemistry. Serum level tests are used in diagnosing and treating a wide range of diseases and disorders. For example, the test is used to monitor patients with diseases such as HIV, hepatitis C, rheumatoid arthritis, cancer, type 1 diabetes, and type 2 diabetes. To provide the most accurate results, the test requires blood samples to be taken while the patient is fasting. This ensures that the results will reflect the natural state of the patient's blood.

# Method of use
The method of use for a serum level test depends on the substance being tested. There are many different methods of using the test, so it is important to follow the instructions given by the medical professional. If the concentration of the substance is too high, the test may not be accurate. Therefore, before taking the test, it is important to consult with a medical professional to find out what the optimal concentration is.

# Procedure
When using a serum level test, the patient must fast for a minimum of eight hours before taking the sample. During this time, blood is drawn from a vein and placed into a serum separator tube. The blood must be allowed to clot so that the serum can form. Once the clot has formed, the serum can be separated from the blood by centrifugal force. A small amount of serum is then put into the test kit and read by an electronic device. The blood sample may be used to analyze the level of the substance being tested. In addition to blood, some substances can also be urine, saliva, or sweat.

A Novel Bifunctional Nuclease in Deinococcus radiodurans: A DNA Repair Nuclease Belonging to a Novel Family of DUF300 Superfamily Proteins

In order to understand the DNA repair mechanisms of Deinococcus radiodurans, an efficient genomic library was constructed to detect and characterize potential nucleases using the UV-or H 2 O 2 -treated D. radiodurans mutant library. We obtained a gene (DR_0706) that encodes a nuclease protein consisting of 460 amino acids, which contains a DUF300 domain at the Nterminus and a nuclease domain at the C-terminus with a typical catalytic site. In D. radiodurans DR_0706 knockout mutant, higher sensitivity to the DNA damaging agents and enhanced sensitivity to the strand-breaking agents (H 2 O 2, MNNG, and MMS), but less to the strand-interrupting agents (T4 or T7 endonuclease) were observed. The results demonstrated that DR_0706 is a bifunctional nuclease and plays a unique role in DNA repair. In addition, DR_0706 nuclease exhibited a higher capacity for exonucleolytic degradation to single-stranded DNAs. The nuclease activity and the expression of DR_0706 gene at transcriptional level increased remarkably during a 24-h delayed repairing period, indicating that the DR_0706 gene may play a key role in the delayed repair of DNA damaged by radiation induced strand breaks in D. radiodurans. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, the DUF300 domain containing superfamily proteins were classified into new clades in the DUF300 family. To our knowledge, this is the first DUF300 domain containing gene that encodes a nuclease, and DR_0706 represents a novel member of DUF300 superfamily proteins.

The aim of this study was to enhance the biodegradation of hydrocarbons in marine oil-contaminated soils by the addition of an organic soil amendment. For this purpose, five bacterial isolates characterized by their ability to degrade hydrocarbons from the genera Pseudomonas, Flavobacterium, Bacillus, Myxococcus and Alcaligenes were added to the contaminated soil in combination with a soy-lecithin extract (SLE) to act as a biostimulator and to improve rhizosphere activity and/or root colonization. The presence of SLE and bacterial isolates stimulated by 4-170% the degradation of n-hexadecane reaching 100% degradation in some cases. The addition of SLE also increased the release of nutrients, namely nitrogen, sulfur, and phosphorus, from the contaminated soil, contributing to the improvement of the microbial biostimulatory activity of the soil-inoculated with SLE and the rhizobacteria. This study suggests that the addition of SLE to rhizobacteria-contaminated soil can stimulate a synergistic interaction between bacteria and nutrients for biodegradation of pollutants. BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE
The aim of this in vitro study was to investigate the effect of three ProTaper instruments (S1, F1, F2 and M1), Reciproc and OneShape in conjunction with either M4 or M5, and also to compare the effects of S1, NITFlex and Cleaning & Shaping systems along with M4 on the root canal dentin surface.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
In total, 40 maxillary central incisors were selected and randomly divided into eight groups. Group C (Reciproc) and group S (OneShape) were each combined with the ProTaper's finishing instruments. A total of 160 samples were obtained for the SEM evaluation to examine the remaining dentin thickness and integrity of each canal wall.


RESULTS
The short-taper rotary system groups showed significantly more integrity than those for the long-taper group with lower residual dentin thickness for the S1 and OneShape (P < 0.001). The combination of OneShape or Reciproc with M4, NITflex and/or Cleaning & Shaping instruments demonstrated better results compared with M5.


CONCLUSION

The GIQLI index is a 36-item quality of life questionnaire designed to assess the global quality of life of patients with organic gastrointestinal diseases. It was first published in 1998 and is available in free access. The index consists of 36 questions grouped into six domains: dysphagia (four questions); symptoms (eight questions); emotions (seven questions); physical function (seven questions); intestinal functions (four questions); body image (three questions). Each item is scored from 1 to 7 (‘very good' score=1; ‘worst imaginable health state' score=7). The GIQLI scores vary from 36 to 252; higher scores indicate better quality of life. 6. Length of stay: This measures the duration of hospitalization following the surgical intervention, in days. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

7. Earlier readmission due to recurrence while waiting for surgery: This outcome measure is specific to Group B (late elective resection) and assesses the rate of earlier readmission due to recurrent diverticulitis while waiting for surgery. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

8. Postoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of common postoperative complications such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

This paper reviews the extent to which the Guide No. 31: 'Assessing Professional Competence', produced by the Association for Medical Education in Europe (AMEE), has been used by member medical schools in the European Union and elsewhere since publication in 1993. By means of a questionnaire sent to the medical schools within the UK Medical Schools Council, response rates relating to the use of the Guide No. 31 in the assessment of professional competence have been investigated. The results indicate that for UK schools the Guide has influenced the way in which assessments were carried out. Nevertheless, a substantial number of schools make no use at all of the Guide or any other major source of guidance or support, other than general guidance for making assessment more effective. Anecdotal evidence points to a similar situation in other countries, which suggests that the AMEE has played only a relatively minor part in the development of assessment in medical education worldwide. 3D Analysis of Facial Soft Tissue Structures in Two Indian Populations Using Different Scanning Methods.
Background: Dental and medical plastic surgeons have traditionally relied on two-dimensional imaging methods like radiographic technique, cephalometric tracing, and 2D photographs to assess the morphology of soft tissue and hard tissue of the craniofacial complex. Three-dimensional imaging is becoming more important as it provides a more precise understanding of the anatomical position and structure; furthermore, it also permits simulation and virtual surgery planning to achieve better clinical outcomes.
Objectives: The present study was planned with the primary objective to compare the morphometry of 3D analysis facial parameters in two distinct Indian populations using 3D imaging technology.
Methods: In the present study, the 3D imaging analysis of lateral cephalometric scan (LC) was compared with the facebow scan (FB) and surface scan (SB) to find an effective, accurate, and reliable method and technique to evaluate the soft tissue structures.
Results: The 3D imaging analysis of the soft tissues was done in the lateral cephalometric scan to assess the morphological relationship between the hard and soft tissues of the craniofacial complex.
Conclusion: Among the three methods that were compared, the lateral cephalometric scan method showed a better reliability of anatomical structure compared to the surface and facebow scans.

Impact of the type I-III interferon balance on osteoarthritis progression via interleukin-10 expression
ABSTRACT Osteoarthritis (OA) is a multifactorial chronic inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characterized by pain, cartilage degeneration, osteophyte formation and synovial inflammation. Accumulating evidence on the role of the immune system in OA has been provided by genetic studies, immunophenotyping of synovium and analysis of cytokine expression. The aim of this study was to identify whether IFN type I/III balance influences the production of cytokines which are known to contribute to osteoarthritis pathophysiology. Progression-Free Survival Progression-free survival (PFS) is a critical measure of success for a cancer treatment. It refers to the amount of time a patient can stay alive, without the cancer growing or worsening.1 PFS is often used by doctors when looking at a person’s cancer treatments to determine when to progress or change the course of treatment. There are so many factors involved in determining PFS, and there is currently no single way to define or measure it.

# Background

Research on PFS is a great way to understand a new drug, where a drug can be “successful” or “unsuccessful,” and whether or not it is safe for patients to use. Researchers measure PFS by seeing how long it takes before patients in both groups experience disease progression, which can be a worsening of the disease, or death. When a group has a longer PFS than the control group, one can safely assume that an increase in life expectancy and survival could be possible. PFS and overall survival rates are both used to determine the efficacy of cancer treatment. Surveillance Epidemiology and End Results (SEER) is the author of the NCCN guidelines of PFS.  Surviving participants are followed up to see how they survive the treatment or, in contrast, who succumb to it. If one treatment is better than the other, it can be assumed that more people survive using drug A than drug B, or vice versa.  SEER has analyzed multiple studies on cancer (particularly breast, prostate, and lung), showing how effective treatments improved the patient’s chances of survival and disease control.  Research on PFS is not used by the FDA to approve a particular cancer drug as successful or non-successful; this determination is based on the FDA’s own measures.  The FDA, on the other hand, uses the PFS rate in approving a particular drug or treatment.  2,3 
PFS is a tool used in researching the effectiveness of cancer treatments in the lab.  Researchers use this measure to determine the safety and effectiveness of a particular drug or treatment.  PFS is measured in weeks or months, and is based on the number of persons who have worsening or “progression” of their condition in a particular time

The Fourier transform infrared-pump-probe spectrum is often considered to be a powerful tool to analyze vibrational dynamics and polarizability in condensed matter and other systems. Many theoretical, as well as, experimental investigations of vibrational dynamics and polarizability of polymer fibers, liquid crystalsand complex organic moleculeshave been performed in the last two decades. For a short summary of experimental results see. The IR-pump-probe infrared spectroscopy studies of the dynamics in liquids are reviewed by Galeotti et al.. The main advantage of such studies is the ability to resolve spectral lines from different vibrational modes that are spectrally close. The vibrational modes can be resolved in time by Fourier transforming short IR pulses which serve as the probe and an IR pulse, which serves as the pump. Introduction COVID-P 19 causes a psychological effect which may produce various psychological impact, such as depression and anxiety. The main problem occurs in the patient's family after recovery, since there is a stigma on Corona patients. Research regarding the effect of COVID-P 19 and social stigma of corona patients on depression and anxiety is needed to provide early intervention. Methods This study was an analytical observational cross-sectional study with a total sample of 114 respondents using consecutive sampling techniques. All research participants were women in Yogyakarta, Indonesia who had survived COVID-P 19 with no physical impairments. The instrument used in this study were Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21), COVID-Stigma Scale, and the Health Status. Data analysis use was multivariate analysis with the generalized estimating equations (GEE) method, with an alpha error of 5% and power of 80%. Result Findings showed that there was an interaction effect of COVID-P 19 and social stigma on depression (b = 0.065) and anxiety (b = 0.169) with a positive sign. Women with mild to moderate levels of income had higher depression and anxiety scores than those with high income levels. Conclusion COVID-P 19 had an interaction effect with social stigma on the level of depression and anxiety experienced by women with mild to moderate incomes. It is necessary to strengthen preventive health programs with good mental health promotion and mental health services, especially those that focus on female workers with mild to moderate incomes. This effort is expected to help reduce the psychological impact of COVID-P19 and social stigma on the level of depression and anxiety in these women.

INTRODUCTION
Atopic dermatitis is one of the most frequent chronic cutaneous diseases in childhood. Its etiopathogenesis is complex, resulting from an interaction between genetic, immune and environmental factors. The relationship between atopic dermatitis and food intolerances is unknown, although the effect of cow's milk is well established.


OBJECTIVES
To determine the frequency of food intolerances in patients with atopic dermatitis and to compare the results with those obtained in a non-allergic population.


PATIENTS AND METHODS
57 children between two and six years old were divided into an atopic dermatitis group (AD; 33) and a control group (CG; 24). We made a skin prick allergen test and an atopy patch test, as well as recording an oral challenge test with hydrolyzed cow's milk.


RESULTS
A total of ten food intolerances was detected (10.8%); of these, ten were atopic dermatitis patients (61.5%) and none in controls. None of our patients showed symptoms due to the oral challenge test.


CONCLUSIONS

The Role of Tissue Expander Capsule on Expansion Volumes: Is Expansion Volume Reduction Predictable?
BACKGROUND
Tissue expansion is a common treatment for patients with complex defects. A significant amount of tissue from the expander reservoir is often required for tissue expansion. When the reservoir is deflated or emptied, a tissue expander capsule (TEC) forms and contracts on the skin flap. The aim of this study is to predict TECs and their effects on future expansion.


OBJECTIVES
The authors' aim was to evaluate the relationship of TEC development to the amount of expansion.


METHODS
A retrospective review of 18 consecutive breast reconstructions using tissue expanders was conducted. TECs were evaluated on postoperative photographs by a blinded observer, and the results compared with the final total expansion volumes. Linear regression was performed to determine the correlation between the 2 variables.


RESULTS
There was a strong correlation (r = 0.764, P = 0.002) between final expansion volumes and TEC. Final expansion volumes were predicted by use of TEC measurements with 79% accuracy.


CONCLUSION
The authors have demonstrated the utility of evaluating TEC formation as an accurate and cost-effective tool for predicting the number of expansion expulsions that will be required during a single tissue expansion procedure. Although prevalence of OW/OB remained unchanged, some students' BMI increased to overweight/obese status. Lifestyle choices and physical activity habits/behaviors were not predictors of becoming OW/OB. . Inhibition of bacterial endotoxin-mediated endothelial permeability: effect of anti-LPS monoclonal antibodies
Bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), known as endotoxin, causes endothelial cell retraction and permeability. The LPS molecule consists of a lipid A portion that confers toxicity and a variable polysaccharide portion (O-polysaccharide) of the native LPS that contains most of the serological and immunological epitopes. We show that several murine anti-LPS monoclonal antibodies (MAb) recognize epitopes of the serotype O18:K1 lipopolysaccharide molecule. In vascular endothelial cells, the anti-O18:K1 MAb, but not an opsonic anti-S. enteritidis F41 MAb, inhibited LPS-induced endothelial permeability. The anti-O18:K1 MAb, when added after LPS, also inhibited endothelial leakage induced by the toxin (4 h incubation). The anti-O18:K1 MAb did not inhibit LPS binding to the cells. Further, the anti-O18:K1 MAb prevented the formation of an immune deposit. It is concluded that the anti-LPS MAb inhibits endotoxin-mediated endothelial permeability by interfering with the formation of immune complexes within the endothelial cell. INTRODUCTION
Fifteen to thirty percent of all newborn infants undergoing surgery for congenital heart disease develop acute kidney injury (AKI) within 72 hours of operation. The aim of this study was to evaluate the relationship between kidney damage indicators and cardiac surgery on neonates to determine their adequacy in predicting AKI.


MATERIAL AND METHODS
138 patients who underwent cardiac surgery for correction of congenital heart disease or palliation were prospectively evaluated. A single intraoperative blood sample was obtained before the administration of any intraoperative maneuver, followed by 4-hourly samples starting at 2 hours after surgery until postoperative day 1. The cystatin C, creatinine and uric acid level were analyzed preoperatively and postoperatively.


RESULTS
The overall incidence of AKI was 19%. Patients who suffered AKI had significantly increased cystatin C concentrations postoperatively in comparison with the group without AKI. The highest area under ROC curve was found for the postoperative cystatin C and uric acid concentration values. The diagnostic accuracy of both markers for the identification of patients with postoperative AKI was good to excellent.


CONCLUSIONS

The genus Aristolochia (Plantaginaceae) is widely distributed in Brazil and its species are used in the traditional treatment of different afflictions. The aim of the present work was to evaluate the effects of the essential oil from the leaves of Aristolochia bracteolata (EOAB) against microorganisms and in the in vitro culture of fibroblasts and osteoblasts/chondrocytes derived from osteoarthritic patients (OAC). The cytotoxicity was evaluated by the neutral red assay in primary cultures of human cells from OAC, using epithelial fibroblasts (OF) and osteoblast/chondrocyte (OB/CH) cell pair. Chemical analysis revealed 45 components in EOAB, corresponding to over 90% of the total oil (mostly monoterpenes). The oil MIC and MFC were 64 and 128 μg/mL, respectively, against all microorganisms tested, and all fungi were susceptible (MIC range 50–100 μg/mL). EOAB was slightly toxic to OR (2% viability) and OB/CH (36% viability) cells, but showed no cytotoxic effect on OF cells (IC50 >1000 μg/mL). In conclusion, results demonstrate that EOS from Aristolochia bracteolata leaves is a rich source of antimicrobial compounds with acceptable toxicity. .

Things you Can do with an Ai in the Business… A Phenome Wide association Study of Lactose intolerance identifies phenotypes suggestive of altered milk consumption and disease susceptibility

Lactose intolerance (LI) is a common condition caused by milk allergy or insufficient enzymatic digestion of lactose where lactose is largely degraded into galactose and glucose through the action of lactase catalyzes enzymes. Because some lactase activity is retained into adulthood in humans, LI is considered a potential risk factor for metabolic disease including obesity. The complex clinical presentation of LI and overlap with other metabolismrelated diseases, such as diabetes, is a challenge for studying associations between LI and specific traits or diseases. Here, we conducted a large phenome-wide analysis to investigate the associations of LI with medical conditions in a large population of UK Biobank. We identified nine phenotypes that were highly associated (p < 10 -6 ) with LI with a significant effect size. These phenotypes included anthropometric measurements, lipid profiles, and metabolic health indicators, as well as diet-related traits. A detailed inspection of the association with metabolic diseases revealed seven phenotypes that were significantly related to an elevated risk of developing metabolic diseases in LI. These results suggest that LI may increase susceptibility to a variety of metabolic diseases. This study highlights the complex clinical presentation of LI and provides insights into how LI may contribute to the development of metabolic diseases through altered milk consumption and increased predisposition to metabolic conditions. In this scenario, we focus on the role of the principal investigator in assessing whether the research team's outcome measures are valid and well designed. They have to evaluate whether the outcome measures are appropriate for the purpose of the research and whether they can effectively measure the intended changes in the target population. This evaluation should include some questions to assess the validity, reliability and feasibility of each outcome measure. A useful way to approach the evaluation of outcome measures is to apply a validated tool such as the Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS) which offers guidelines on how to assess various types of outcome measures . The PROMIS website also includes a question bank, measurement protocols and related materials to assist researchers in determining the outcome measures. However, when an outcome measure is not yet validated, researchers have to conduct their own assessment of whether it is appropriate for the purpose of the study. Before deciding, researchers need to consider the conceptual underpinnings of the chosen outcome measure as well as its feasibility in terms of time, resources, equipment and patient burden. By understanding the constructs and properties that underlie the outcome measures, researchers can make informed decisions about which outcome measures to use.  References. The citation method used in the journal is referred to as the Vancouver referencing system. The number of references should be appropriate, but the number should not be used as a basis for determining the value of the article.

 The abstract of the submitted article should be written in Japanese.

[1] Randomized (or nonrandomized): In a randomized study, every subject has the same chance of being assigned to a particular group. In a nonrandomized (observational) study, the groups may differ from person to person and differ in size.
[2] Experimental: A treatment that is assigned only to subjects who are part of the control group, for example, a placebo group in a phase 3 trial, is referred to as an experimental treatment. A treatment that is administered to subjects in every group is usually referred to as a placebo or common treatment.
[3] Blind: Every study must be blinded, that is, the investigator and other persons involved in the study must not know what treatment is being administered to a particular group of subjects.

## Primary purpose
The purpose of a clinical trial is the hypothesis being tested, the research question to answer, and, if relevant, the target population. In some cases, a clinical trial requires several specific hypotheses that, together, characterize the trial. For example, the hypothesis for a study could be a test of a new active drug against a placebo with a control group, as well as a test of that new active drug against an available drug for the treatment of the targeted disorder or disease. It is important to develop a clear hypothesis to avoid the risk of conducting a disjointed and biased study. This is particularly true for a small study, as small studies are unlikely to establish definite proof of efficacy. The hypothesis of a trial should be precise and easy to understand. Effects of olive pulp as feed ingredient on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, and gut morphology of finishing pigs.
Weaned pigs (19.89 ± 1.98 kg; barrows and gilts, n = 45) were used in a 31-day growth trial using 4, 3.5, or 3-kg BW increments to a final BW of 82.9 (±1.2), 78.1 (±2.4), or 73.3 (±3.1) kg, respectively. Pigs were fed 1 of 3 diets: (1) diet containing 40% corn (CON), (2) diet containing 40% corn and 15% dry-rendered 5-chloro-2-methyl-4-pyridyl chlorine-treated (CDPRCP) 5% olive pulp (OP), or (3) diet containing 40% CDPRCP OP and 10% enzyme complex to the CON diet. Enzyme complex contained 0.15% β-glucanase, 0.75% xylanase, and 0.45% protease. Dry matter (DM) digestibility, apparent total tract apparent digestibility, viscosity, and amylase activity of dietary ingredients were determined according to standard methods. The Bacte‐Album Project and its use as a tool for the comparative study of the albumin protein family Albumin protein family is extensively distributed throughout all kingdoms of life and displays an extraordinary diversity of functions. One of its members is albumin, a major serum protein in vertebrates, which is believed to be primarily an osmoprotectant in the blood. The Bacte‐Album Project is a collection of 169 complete bacterial genomes which were screened for albumin genes. Of these, 22 organisms were found to possess an orthologous sequence of the albumin family. Based on sequence and structure information the phylogenetic tree of the albumin‐like proteins was constructed. The domain organization of each protein was found to be different and the bacterial albumin proteins were clustered into three groups, the first group resembles the classical serum albumin of the vertebrates. In both the second and the third group the domain organization of albumin genes is not that uniform and includes only the albumin‐like domain. The presence of albumin gene or its ortholog on each genome of Bacte‐Album Project will be useful for further analysis of the evolution of the albumin family and also to obtain insight into the function of this protein family. AIM
To define a set of risk factors for venous thrombo-embolism (VTE) by univariate and multivariate logistic regression.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
1198 patients in 37 Russian medical institutions were examined. Logistic regression was used to analyze the factors related to the development of VTE.


RESULTS
Univariate analysis was used to identify risk factors to compare independent samples with each other, which led to the identification of more than twenty risk factors for VTE. Among them, the five most significant were identified, namely, the state of the liver, congestive heart failure, cancer, stroke, and ischemic heart disease.


CONCLUSION
Logistic regression analysis with simultaneous analysis of all risk factors identified the presence of congestive heart failure, liver disease, cancer, ischemic heart disease, and stroke as five most significant VTE risk factors. Therefore, the data obtained provide evidence that it is extremely important to conduct a complete medical history to identify the risk factors for development of VTE before and after surgery and to use anticoagulants in cases with certain risk factors.  Is the Veterans Affairs health system a model for care integration?
PURPOSE
The VA's "reengineering" of services and integration into a patient-directed health system has received little prior evaluation. We sought to examine whether the system functions as successfully as its proponents claim.


DESIGN/METHODOLOGY/APPROACH
In this qualitative study, we interviewed 143 VA employees. Audiotape-recorded interviews contained narratives about the system and their role in it. Interviews were transcribed verbatim. The authors conducted thematic analysis using Atlas/Ti.


FINDINGS
The VA system was described as highly interactive, decentralized and patient-focused. VA hospitals were compared with other large integrated health systems and found to perform better on access, quality, and cost containment. Most employees described their job as highly gratifying. VA hospital administrators reported success in meeting patient preferences, improving quality, and controlling costs even as revenues waned. They attributed this to an enhanced sense of mission and to strong organizational resources. The authors concluded that the VA provides a model for other health systems to address the current health reform agenda.


ORIGINALITY/VALUE
The VA system has achieved goals similar to those now seen as essential to integrated care in non-VA health systems. Its success should offer lessons of how to address current health reform challenges. Cognitive development in children with chronic liver disease

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Evolution of the axSPA global activity score (fatigue, pain, stiffness): Change in the BASDAI score, assessed via a self-administered questionnaire, between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Evolution of the axSPA global activity score (fatigue, pain, stiffness): Change in the BASDAI score, assessed via a self-administered questionnaire, between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Functional impact: Change in self-assessment of functional capacity during daily tasks using the BASFI score between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Health-related quality of life: Change in the patient's self-assessment via the SF-36 scale between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Anxiety and depression: Change in the patient's self-assessment via the HAD scale between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Respiratory capacity: Measurement of chest expansion between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (maximum active amplitudes - sagittal plane): Change in measurement of maximum active amplitudes in orthostatism of the thoraco-lumbar spine in the sagittal plane between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (degrees of kyphosis and lordosis): Change in measurement of the degrees of kyphosis and lordosis while standing between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (maximum active amplitudes - frontal plane): Change in measurement of maximum active amplitudes in orthostatism of the thoraco-lumbar spine in the frontal plane between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Spinal and axial mobility (podobarometric treadmill): Change in measurement of the spatiotemporal analysis of gait on a podobarometric treadmill between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Axial mobility: Change in BASMI score, reflecting the level of restriction in axial mobility, between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Follow-up of the therapeutic strategy: Change in therapeutic strategy between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Drug consumption monitoring: Change in drug consumption between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Sleep quality: Change in QESL score (Leeds Sleep Assessment Questionnaire) between the 2 month visit and the 5 month visit and between the 2 month visit and the 11 month visit.
- Adherence to the practice of yogatherapy of patients randomized in this group: Degree of adherence to yogatherapy collected through a short self-questionnaire at the 5 month and 11 month visits.

The PRC2-mediated monomethylation (K27me1) and dimethylation (K27me2/3) of histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27) are key histone marks that play vital roles in diverse physiological and pathological processes. The PRC2 activity is repressed by the potent anticancer agent EZH2 inhibitor 3-deazaneplanocin A (DZ Neplanocin A, DZNep), which disrupts the formation of K27me3 by replacing S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) in the catalytic center. DZNep has been shown to deplete H3K27me3, but little is known about its effects on other histone modification in vivo. In this study, we found that the DZNep treatment results in the loss of H3K27me2, indicating that DZNep might be a potent EZH2 inhibitor to inhibit the H3K27me2 and H3K27me3 levels. Furthermore, the DZNep treatment did not abolish H3K27me1 in embryonic stem cells, indicating that PRC2 and DZNep can coexist on the same histone, leading to the generation of H3K27 (m1 or m2) and H3K27 (m2 or m3). A newly discovered hydroxamic acid inhibitor (GSE) with a similar inhibitory spectrum as DZNep was discovered. Our investigation confirmed that the GSE could act as a novel H3K27me2/3 inhibitor to prevent the mammalian development. Therefore, we suggest that GSE is a promising PRC2 inhibitor, especially the H3K27me1/2 and H3K27me2/3-binding inhibitor. Pathogenesis remains unclear even though there are several different hypotheses, with microvascular dysfunction (tight stenosis of the intramural coronary arteries) representing the principal cause of the phenomenon. METHODS

Insect pests are the most damaging internal pests of stored grain, and there have been many advances in this area over the last few years. Improvements in sampling techniques have made it possible to monitor the pest status at frequent frequent intervals, and this is a valuable tool not only in the control of storage pests, but also in determining grain treatment requirements. There is also better understanding of the behaviour of grain insect pests in the storage environment, particularly in large-scale storage situations, and this is allowing targeted insect control to reduce treatment costs. This is an important development particularly in a world which has an increasing need for grain storage. The most widespread storage pests of grain are the Trogoderma spp., which have a worldwide distribution. There are three main approaches to control these pests. First there is chemical control with the use of fumigants and phosphine. Because of environmental concerns, phosphine is beginning to be replaced, at least in some cases, by hydrogen cyanide and insect growth regulators can be used as adjuvants with some fumigants and are an alternative. Second there is toxic baiting using various toxic compounds, including the insect growth regulators. Bone augmentation procedures are widely employed to restore the alveolar ridge before loading of dental implants in partial or complete edentulous patients, and to prepare an adequate grafting area for osseointegration. Recent advances in biological sciences and tissue engineering technologies and the introduction of new materials have shown great promise to reduce morbidity and improve outcomes in implantology procedures. Several rehabilitative techniques, such as autogenous bone block grafting, have been reported to be useful but associated with complications and poor patient acceptance. In this context, tissue engineering and advanced technologies, such as platelet-rich growth factors (PRGFs) and human amniotic membrane (HAM), represent a new perspective and innovative strategies in bone defect restoration procedures and can be expected to significantly improve rehabilitation methods in implantology. The aim of this review was to highlight and summarize the potential clinical benefits of these techniques in maxillary sinus floor augmentation (MSFA). In today's video series, we will be taking a closer look at clinical trial outcome measures. In the first video of the series, we will explore how to design primary outcome measures. The primary outcome measure is crucial as it is used to evaluate the impact of the intervention or treatment under investigation.

In the second video of the series, we will examine secondary outcome measures. Secondary outcome measures are used to supplement and complement the primary outcome measures.

In the third and final video of the series, we will focus on pilot studies, which entail a small-scale clinical trial to validate the design, procedures, and feasibility of planned studies. A pilot study may also be used to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the intervention or treatment under investigation.

For the pilot studies, the aim of this video is to discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the design for clinical trials. So, by understanding the goals and methods of pilot studies, researchers can design more effective trials for their studies.

At the end of the video series, you should be able to:

❖ Determine whether or not your clinical trial meets the criteria for a pilot study
❖ Differentiate between the primary and secondary outcome measures in a clinical trial
