Colorectal cancer (CRC) is one of the leading causes of cancer morbidity and mortality worldwide. Increasingly, research has shown that genomic amplification of certain oncogenes is a frequent molecular abnormality of CRC. Although the frequency for gene amplification in CRC has been investigated in previous study, most of the studies ignored the gain of functional copy number variation of genes. In this study, we tried to investigate whether there is a gain of functional copy number variation in any specific KRAS and PTEN on chromosome 12 and 10 in more CRC samples. Using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) with probes specific for KRAS, PTEN and ACTB, we analyzed the functional relationship between these genes and tumorigenesis of CRC and its genetic mechanism. FISH analysis and quantitative fluorescence microscopy with 103 sporadic CRC samples proved that KRAS amplification occurred significantly in human CRC specimens. Our present study demonstrates that amplification of KRAS on chromosome 12p is a frequent molecular aberration in sporadic CRC and thus may be an oncogenic lesion in human CRC tumorigenesis. The purpose of this study was to investigate the expression of sperm proteins in patients with obstructive azoospermia (OA) and the possible molecular mechanism of sperm production failure. The study involved 18 OA patients and 20 healthy sperm donors. The sperm proteins were separated by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, and differentially expressed proteins were detected by mass spectrometry. Differentially expressed proteins were identified by their m/z values and fragmentation patterns from mass spectra. The potential functions of differentially expressed proteins were annotated with Gene Ontology (GO), Swiss-Prot, and UniProt annotations and analysed with Kyoto Encyclopaedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) and InterPro annotations. Finally, a protein-protein interaction (PPI) network was constructed for analysing the interactions between sperm proteins and their functions. There were 9 differentially expressed proteins identified with sperm from OA patients. These proteins were mainly involved in oxidation-reduction and the ribisco pathway. Four (ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase large chain, alpha-amylase, alpha-enolase, and pyruvate kinase M1) of these proteins have functions involving the regulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The results of this study indicate that obstructive azoospermia may decrease the antioxidant capacity of sperm via disrupting the regulation of these important antioxidant proteins. It is necessary to further assess these proteins, which may serve as targets for the treatment of OA and for improving pregnancy rates in patients with nonobstructive azoospermia. Purpose
The clinical trial aims to determine the safety and efficacy of Medtronic’s Endurant™ stent graft with the Medtronic CoreValve™ stent for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in China patients.
Patients will be eligible who are at least 18 years of age at the time of screening, have the presence of an infrarenal AAA with a maximum diameter > 50 mm, and who have a normal left ventricular systolic function and do not have concomitant iliac aneurysms.
In addition, screening will occur within 7 days, and implantation will be performed via open surgery or endovascular approach, within one year or less of the screening date.
There are several reasons a patient could be excluded from the clinical trial. One of those reasons is poor cardiac function, where the Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction should be ≤ 40%. Another reason a patient may be excluded is an increase in the aortic aneurysms to ≥ 70 mm as measured by computed tomography angiography (CTA), when the first measurement is between 55 and 70 mm; there can only be one increase of maximum aneurysm diameter during the follow-up.
There are also several exclusion criteria when it comes to the Endurant IIs or 48mm grafts. One of the reasons a patient could be excluded would be a thoracic aorta < 15 mm or iliac diameter < 15 mm. Others include major cardiovascular procedures within 12 months of screening, which include cardiac transplant, open aortic valve replacement, valve repair, open surgical correction of the aorta, graft or vascular stenting, or graft replacement. Another criterion to be excluded would be prior graft thrombectomy, prior open surgical repair of the aortic arch aneurysm, coronary bypass grafting, endovascular repair of the thoracic aorta, or endovascular repair of the aortic arch aneurysm.

The objective of the present study was to investigate the effects of the anesthesia during cardiac surgery on the circulation of the individual with Dandy-Walker syndrome and severe FAS. An 11-year-old female (weight 12.6 kg) with FAS and Dandy-Walker syndrome (posterior cleft of the foramen magnum, partial agenesis of the cerebellum) was transferred to our pediatric intensive care unit. In the cardiac surgery, anesthesia was induced with intravenous piritramide followed by propofol, and maintained with isoflurane. Anesthesia was uneventful, and the heart was surgically repaired. Blood pressure, heart rate and electrocardiogram were continuously monitored. Blood pressure on admission was lower than normal (63/38 mmHg). Postoperative systolic blood pressure was between 118 and 142 mmHg, and she was kept in the ICU for 5 days. The patient did not develop any side effects of the cardiac operations despite presenting as anesthesia-challenged. We report here on a process for exsolving nanoparticles by mechanical force through phonon excitation. We show through X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies that when subject to a strong enough acoustic force, Cu2ZnSnS4 (CZTS) rods will exsolve ZnS nanoparticles into their surface structure, and the amount of nanoparticle exsolution is found to be proportional to the strength of the acoustic force. Nanopattern surface structures were fabricated without using external templates or etching agents by directly exsolving ZnS nanoparticles, allowing the synthesis of uniform nanostructures across large-scale areas. This study shows that it may be possible to selectively exclude nanoparticles from nanorods based on changes to the electronic/ion structures of the nanorods. In this scheme, the CZTS host crystal lattice is distorted, allowing for Zn2+ ions to diffuse to the rod surface and form ZnS particles by bonding with S and other Zn2+ ions not involved in the original structure. The ionic charges are compensated by electrostatic charge accumulation of the diffusing Zn2+ and the surrounding charges. This mechanism is fundamentally different from the well-studied ion–ion interaction mechanism where ionic exchange only occurs between neighboring bonding sites. RNA posttranscriptional regulation is an extremely complex process where the heterogeneous nuclear riboproteins (hnRNPs) and microRNAs (miRNAs) have a significant role. MiRNAs are single-stranded sequences of RNA that regulate the translation of certain mRNA sequences and their expression varies in each cell type. Heterogeneous nuclear riboproteins are also a diverse set of RNA-binding proteins (RBPs), which are present in the nucleus and are also found distributed in the cytoplasm. Through RBP-RNA interactions, hnRNPs facilitate the transcription, RNA processing, and transport of various classes of RNAs, regulating their level of expression in the cells. After an overview of the literature, we report on a case of a patient with the diagnosis of a peritoneal mesothelioma. The symptoms were pain, dyspnoea, dry cough and a progressive and slowly increasing abdominal swelling. Histology was carried out on two biopsies. Both specimens showed diffuse papillary endothelial thickening with lymphocitic infiltration. We describe our difficulties in diagnosing this rare tumor. A high level of suspicion is therefore needed if only a few symptoms such as abdominal swellings, and pleural effusions, are present. Imaging procedures such as ultrasound can be of great help for the diagnosis, although definitive diagnosis can only be made with histological documentation. Evidence for Extrastriatal Dopaminergic Dysfunction in the Rat Model of Parkinson's Disease
The 618-C51/306-C51 ligand is an α-methylated dopamine agonist that binds both to presynaptic dopamine autoreceptors and to striatal D 2 receptors. Accordingly, it can serve as an indicator not only of striatal transmitter release but also of dopaminergic dysfunction in the extrastriatal regions. In this study, we examined whether the 618-C51 ligand could detect changes in the dopaminergic system in an animal model of Parkinson's disease (PD). Rats were made unilaterally lesioned with 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) and given daily injections of haloperidol or vehicle. Using the raclopride method as a reference, we found a clear 50% reduction of striatal dopamine levels in lesioned rats chronically treated with haloperidol, which was accompanied by a significant decrease of the striatal D 2 receptor level. Extrastriatal dopamine availability was also affected, as indicated by a reduction in 618-C51 binding

Excellent! Wonderful! Here are the full outcome measures for the clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Surgical success (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Advanced Energy device(s) used): Defined by amount of blood loss, total operation time, length of stay in the hospital, and investigator opinion on device assistance. Assessed up to 24 months.
2. Fusion success (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, and/or Rods and Screws device(s) used): Assessed at 12 months using radiographic evidence.
3. Surgical performance (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Powered Systems, Instruments, and Imaging device(s) used): Rate at which the device directly assists in the completion of surgery. Assessed at the index surgery.
4. Device performance (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Robotics and Navigation device(s) used): Planned number of screws compared to screws device assisted with placement. Validation of screw placement for navigation devices. Assessed up to 24 months.
5. Deformity correction (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Spinal Tethers device(s) used): Defined by change of Cobb angle at 12 months and up to 24 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Rate of device-related adverse events (for any Medtronic eligible market-released Cranial & Spinal Technologies (CST) device(s) used): Aligned with ISO 14155 standards. Assessed up to 24 months.
2. Stabilization (for any Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the following product groups: Interbodies and Biologics, Other Spinal Hardware, Rods and Screws): Assessed up to 12 months through radiographic evidence.
3. Deformity correction (for specified Medtronic eligible market-released device(s) used from the Rods and Screws product group): Change of Cobb angle at the 12-month postoperative visit compared to baseline. Assessed up to 12 months.

Interventions A new technique of transvaginal insertion of progesterone implant (3-mm device implanon) with vaginal ultrasound guidance carried out during the third and fourth week of the luteal phase after COH. Main outcome measures Tolerability of the transvaginal insertion assessed at discharge, on the day of the implant's removal (10th day after implantation) and 3 days after its removal; the pregnancy rates according to 20 weeks' gestation and the steroid levels during the COH cycle, during oocyte maturation, fertilization, embryonic development and follicular growth, and on implantation day in the transvaginal insertion group. Results The tolerability was excellent; six cases of transient, mild vaginal pain were noted during the first 24-48 h from the implantation. No other side effects were reported. No difference in either the follicular maturation and oocyte fertilization indices or the pregnancy rates was found between the 2 groups (no significant difference with the results published in the literature). The steroid concentrations were always in adequate range. No statistical differences were found between the two groups except for the estradiol and progesterone levels on implantation day. Conclusions Although further studies are needed to confirm this result, we recommend this new technique

AIM
The aim of this study was to examine the attitudes towards research and nursing practice of nursing students in Turkey.


METHODS
Studies conducted with nursing students in Turkey and around the world were reviewed and the data extracted were evaluated. Research questions were formulated and the research was designed as a descriptive study. The sample consisted of 672 students who are taking the nursing department of university in Afyon (Turkey). 151 students were interviewed using the personal information form, the attitude to the practice of clinical research questionnaire and the attitude to the practice of nursing research questionnaire.


RESULTS
About 32.3% (N=96) of the interviewed students participated in a clinical study. Of them, 52.1% (N=51) were unaware that clinical studies were important contributions to nursing practice. About 27% of the students agreed to participate in a clinical study, while 56.5% were against it. In a similar study conducted in 1994, the students' attitudes were found to be more positive than those of our study.


CONCLUSIONS
It is necessary to carry out educational programs to change students' attitudes to research and to practice so that the nurses should act as researcher-practitioners. Evaluation of Different Wound Dressings on the Healing of Acute Cutaneous Wounds in Albino Mice (Balb/c).
INTRODUCTION
Wounds constitute a challenge to both health professionals and patients. With their increased incidence, their consequences have a great impact on the health system. Wound treatments can be very expensive and time consuming, and may not be accessible to many patients. Thus, researchers are developing new wound therapies to improve wound healing.


OBJECTIVE
The aim of the present study was to assess the viability of using three topical wound treatments (Sambucus ebulus extract, silver-impregnated polyurethane foam and chloramphenicol ointment) on the healing of acute cutaneous wounds in mice.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Six experimental groups were established: A: animals treated with chloramphenicol; B: animal treated with Sambucus ebulus extract; C: animal treated with silver-impregnated polyurethane foam; D: animals treated with Sambucus ebulus extract; E: animals treated with silver-impregnated polyurethane foam; F: controls. On day 0, the animals were subjected to excision wound surgery. On days 3, 7 and 14, the wounds were photographed and measured using a ruler and their tissue was sent for histopathologic examination.


RESULTS
The area of the wound was significantly lower in animal groups treated with chloramphenicol than in the control group at all time points. Similar results were observed between animal group F and group D, showing the absence of a statistically significant difference between them.


CONCLUSIONS
The results suggest that chloramphenicol ointment is an efficient therapy and Sambucus ebulus (S. Ebulus) and silver-impregnated polyurethane foam treatments may have been less efficient than the chloramphenicol ointment. Entrustment and Supervision Models of Professional Practice: A Review and Analysis
Abstract An examination of the literature regarding the supervision and entrustment of health professions students to perform a variety of professional functions within educational contexts is described. Research articles published between 1970 and 2014 were retrieved from 13 major scholarly databases. The search terms included supervision, supervise, supervisory, entrusted, entrust, entrustment, and entrusting. A total of 2225 articles were retrieved via the search methods. After removing duplicates and applying exclusion criteria, there was a final sample of 30 articles available for analysis. The majority of the literature examined supervisory relationship(s) of a student with a supervisor working in a health care profession, such as nursing, physiotherapy, or medicine. The concept of entrustment was used infrequently, with no definition provided to establish common ground. Consequently, a model of supervision was also developed based on the 30 reviewed articles. The supervision and entrustment models will be used to guide the development of practice-focused interprofessional learning opportunities for students from several professions. .

ChIP-seq and the molecular study of chromatin structure

Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel sequencing (ChIP-seq) experiments are in vivo methods of identifying protein-DNA interactions across genomic DNA. The methods have revolutionized the molecular investigation of chromatin structure, facilitating new discoveries and increasing the pace of research on transcription, DNA replication, recombination, and repair, and cellular differentiation. In this review, I will describe the biochemistry and application of ChIP-seq, and the impact of ChIP-seq in the study of chromatin biology.

# Introduction
Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) experiments have enabled the identification of a broad range of proteins that bind to chromatin and are important in regulating processes of DNA replication, transcription, recombination, and repair . These studies are carried out in cells treated with formaldehyde or other formaldehyde-based fixatives, since the reactivity of the aldehyde with proteins leads to cross-linking proteins and nucleic acids. Chromatin is purified in the nuclei (or cells) through successive steps of sonication, centrifugation, and ultracentrifugation. The genomic DNA fragments are then digested to an optimal size, followed by immunoprecipitation with anti-human, anti-mouse, or anti-rabbit specific antibodies. The cross-linked proteins are reversed under alkaline conditions, and the purified, linearized DNA fragments are finally subjected to quantitative PCR (qPCR) by measuring the abundance of nucleotide sequences flanked by the protein-DNA interaction site. If the focus of your study is on the development and implementation of a new therapy or diagnostic tool, then you should consider using ‘developing’ or ‘evaluating’ as verbs in the topic sentence. For example:
‘The aim of this article is to describe the design of the development of the IMPROVE-IT trial’.
‘The aim of this article is to describe the development of the NICE guideline on treatment for rheumatoid arthritis’
In contrast, the focus of this paper is on the trial protocol and therefore we are using ‘protocol’ as a noun. In this situation, you should not use a verb in the topic sentence:
‘The aim of this manuscript is to describe the protocol for the development of the IMPROVE-IT trial’.
‘The aim of this manuscript is to describe the protocol for the development of the NICE guideline on treatment for rheumatoid arthritis’.
However, if you are unsure whether your study focus is on the development, evaluation or ‘something else’ then you should always take advice from the publication. The instructions are tailored to your individual needs, and if you are unsure about where the best place to put ‘development’, ‘evaluate’ etc., then you should ask the editor for advice. 0 The human intestinal microbiota and its modulation — impact on and implications for the immune system
The intestine contains 1012 microorganisms, including bacteria, archaea, protozoa, fungi and viruses, colonizing the mucosa, lumen and feces. The intestinal microbiota is composed of ∼ 1000 bacterial species, which in aggregate occupy a surface area of 400 m2. The gut microbiota includes anaerobes and facultatives (Gram‐positive and Gram‐negative rods), and constitutes our largest microbial population, which provides protection from pathogens by competing with them for access to nutrients and adhesion sites. These microbes also colonize mucosal surfaces of the whole gastrointestinal tract beyond the large intestine and contribute to the establishment and maintenance of host immune homeostasis and tolerance. The gut microflora also influences the development of the immunological system by the induction of T reg cells, induction or suppression of cytokines, and the stimulation of specific pathways, thus affecting immunity to various pathogens and cancer. The intestinal microbial population plays a key role in the inflammatory response in the intestine leading to chronic inflammatory and autoimmune diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease and rheumatoid arthritis, and in the development of colorectal cancer. The intestinal microflora may also influence extraintestinal inflammatory and immune diseases affecting various organs . The dysbiosis index is a 5-scale index that measures the imbalance in gut microbiota composition. A DI above 2 indicates a microbiota profile that differs significantly from a normobiotic reference collection. Higher values on the index indicate more severe dysbiosis. Assessing the dysbiosis index at the 12-month mark after FMT would provide valuable insights into the impact of fecal microbiota transplantation on restoring a healthy gut microbiota composition in patients with IBS.

What Is an hs-cTnT Assay?
hs-cTnT uses a high-sensitivity sandwich immunoassay to detect cTnT concentrations in human serum. The test relies on the quantitative measurement of cTnT concentrations using a chemiluminescent immunoassay on the Beckman Coulter Access AccuTnI Plus assay analyzer. Unlike standard troponin assays, the hs-cTnT test detects extremely low cTnT levels.
The sensitivity of the hs-cTnT assay is much higher. This means that the test can measure minimal concentrations of the substance, so it is possible to identify patients in the very early stages of cardiac injury.
The hs-cTnT assay provides several benefits over conventional troponin tests. Because of its enhanced sensitivity, the test can detect cardiac damage shortly after it starts. Traditional troponin tests can only provide comparable data 24 hours after cardiac damage begins. Another benefit of the hs-cTnT assay is its high specificity. As a result, the test can exclude non-cardiac causes of troponin release more frequently and accurately than traditional cardiac troponin tests. For these reasons, more clinical studies are turning to the hs-cTnT test to improve their research.

We'll do this to provide early evaluation of the impact of colchicine on patients' cardiac health. Challenges associated with data integration for cardiovascular disease research and drug development

One of the most important factors affecting progress in the development of new cardiovascular (CV) drugs is the increasing amount of data available in the form of both structured and unstructured data that is widely dispersed across a range of information systems and technologies. To facilitate research and decision making, data must be integrated to produce a single, comprehensive, coherent and meaningful view; however, despite the importance of integrating disparate CV data, many challenges remain. This paper discusses these challenges and presents preliminary analysis of a range of potential approaches to address them. The current approaches provide limited or partial integration of the various data types and are complex and difficult to maintain. In this environment, it is imperative to establish better practices for data integration. The data integration solutions that emerge should be based on a common data model to facilitate future integration. A data warehouse (DW) offers an effective solution for data integration by providing a central data repository, but this solution has a number of drawbacks. One of these is the fact that the DW is built according to current needs and hence, as a result, not suited to change. To overcome these issues, a semantic model and reference data model are proposed. This can be utilized to create a common data model (CDM) and map data from disparate sources according to this CDM. As a result, we can develop the data models that are required to map data across the multiple information systems that are involved in the decision-making process. Moreover, this integration solution, provides a flexible environment and facilitates sustainable development for the cardiovascular decision support system (cDSS).The development of drugs requires substantial investment. The average cost of developing a drug from identification of a concept to market availability is estimated to be $2·1 billion (1), $420 million for preclinical research (2), whereas the cost of drug development between phases I and II was estimated to be $48·3 million (3). Cardiovascular (CV) disease (including cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease) has been described as an "epidemic", resulting in a growing global burden that is not shared equally (3). SETTING: Community‐based research laboratory and University Hospital. RESULTS Although women reported less pain in the year after surgery, significant pain was experienced by 49% to 77% of women (p < .01). Over three‐quarters of women reporting significant pain 2 weeks following surgery (27/33; 82%) continued to report significant pain 1 year after surgery. In the 1 year follow‐up, pain at 2 weeks was related to fatigue, quality of life, and health anxiety. CONCLUSION: Postmastectomy and lumpectomy pain is common and may be persistent. This study provides support for the development of pain‐focused interventions for patients recovering from breast cancer treatments. Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Major Adverse Cardiovascular Events: Assess the proportion of patients developing MACE, including acute coronary syndrome, new/worsening congestive heart failure, coronary revascularization, stroke, all-cause mortality, and cardiovascular death. Time frame: until the 30th postoperative day.
2. New Onset Atrial Fibrillation: Assess the proportion of patients developing new-onset atrial fibrillation. Time frame: from the beginning of surgery until the 30th postoperative day or discharge.
3. Postoperative high sensitive cardiac Troponin T concentrations: Compare postoperative hs-cTnT concentrations between study groups. Monitor until the fourth postoperative day.
4. Long-term cardiovascular outcome: Assess the proportion of patients developing MACE as a marker of long-term postoperative outcome. Time frame: until 1 year after surgery.

Diverse epigenetic regulators have been found to impact the development of the nervous system in mammals including humans, making epigenetic modifications an important mechanism in neural development. Unlike genes transcription in other cell types, a subset of genes must be repressed rapidly and precisely for neural cells to be specified during neurogenesis, and then reactivated before they differentiate into neurons, resulting in a precise developmental regulation of transcription. Chromatin remodeling has been identified as one of the key mechanisms in this complex epigenetic regulation in the neural development. Understanding neurodevelopment has been crucial to understanding neuropsychiatric disorders, of which, a large number have been found to be caused by gene dosage alteration. Chromatin remodeling plays a central role in the development of the brain, and chromatin structure has been found to cause alterations in gene dosage and expression, which in turn causes neurodevelopmental disorders. As a result, understanding chromatin rearrangement in the brain has become increasingly vital to understand neurodevelopmental disorders and discover future drugs. In this review, we discuss the mechanism behind the chromatin rearrangement in the neural development of diverse species, from lower to higher organisms, and discuss the current progress on neurodevelopmental disorders caused by chromatin remodeling. Finally, we discuss the potential role for future therapies in neurodevelopment disorders.

Excellent. Now, let's discuss the primary outcome measures for your study. Based on the information you've provided, there are several primary outcome measures. The first one is the AUC from timepoint 0 to infinity (AUCinf). This measure assesses the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to infinity. It will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Another primary outcome measure is the AUC from timepoint 0 to timepoint t (AUC0-t). This measure evaluates the non-adjusted and baseline-adjusted PK parameters for nicotine, including the area under the curve from timepoint 0 to a specific timepoint. Similar to the previous measure, it will be assessed at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Yes, there are a few more primary outcome measures we should consider. The AUC from timepoint 0 to 30 minutes (AUC0-30min) and AUC from timepoint 0 to 60 minutes (AUC0-60min) are important measures for assessing the early exposure and bioavailability of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Both Cmax and Tmax are important primary outcome measures. Cmax assesses the maximum plasma concentration of nicotine achieved after IP use, while Tmax measures the time it takes to reach the maximum plasma concentration. These measures provide insights into the rate of absorption and the peak exposure of nicotine. They will be evaluated at visits 2 to 4, with measurements taken pre-use and at various timepoints after IP use.

Certainly. The first secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted amount (mg/unit) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure helps evaluate the efficiency of nicotine delivery and the consistency of nicotine content in the pouches. It will be assessed at visits 2 to 4.

Another secondary outcome measure is the in vivo extracted fraction (%) of nicotine for each investigational product. This measure provides information on the bioavailability and release characteristics of nicotine from the pouches. It will also be evaluated at visits 2 to 4.

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures. We should assess the highest recorded increase (Emax) in pulse rate from baseline, which helps evaluate the acute physiological effects of nicotine on cardiovascular function. Additionally, we should measure the mean score for each palatability question 30 minutes after the start of IP use, which provides insights into taste, flavor, and overall user experience. We should also evaluate urge-to-use, product-liking, intent-to-use-again, and onset-of-effect after IP use to assess user satisfaction and behavioral responses. Finally, we should monitor the frequency, seriousness, and intensity of adverse events (AEs) to ensure participant safety throughout the study.

### 1.3 Overview
The intervention being evaluated by this protocol is behavioral nurse coaching, a type of intervention that aims to aid in the management of chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Behavioral nursing coaches use evidence-based tools such as motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy to help patients become self-directed to improve health outcomes. Behavioral nurses are specially trained to support patients in adopting and maintaining self-management tasks. Behavioral nurses work directly with individuals and their healthcare providers to deliver on-demand support and to create personalized health plans. Behavioral nursing coaches are often used in health plan and employer wellness programs and can be embedded or work as consultants with other medical teams to help them improve and track patients' clinical results, social determinants of health (SDOH), and quality of care. Behavioral nurse coaching typically involves a face-to-face session, but it can be conducted remotely if the patient and coach consent.

# 1.4 Purpose of guideline
The recommendations in this guideline are intended to aid in the clinical decision-making of patients with insomnia and obstructive sleep apnea. Clinicians may assess patients' current medical history and their health-related behavior (including any sleep apnea or insomnia diagnoses), medical tests such as polysomnogram or home sleep test results, medications, and use of behavioral interventions in designing or offering interventions for sleep apnea or insomnia. Clinicians may use this guideline, adapted for their patient population, to assist in determining the intensity and length of recommended behavioral nurses coaching interventions. They may also use this guideline as clinical support for shared decision making with their patients.

# 1. Overall Methodology
This clinical practice guideline makes use of an integrative approach to inform the literature review and development of recommendations. The integrative approach incorporates the best available evidence from peer-reviewed meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and systematic reviews (SR), patient-centered outcomes, and the expert opinion of content experts.

# Overview
In a randomized controlled trial, known as the Random Grouping Method, groups are randomly allocated to receive the intervention or waitlist control group. All participants are randomly assigned to one of two groups. While RCT may include a treatment group and a control group who receives standard care, not all RCT include a control group. If an RCT does not include a control group, statistical techniques may be used to account for the added variability.

# Intervention Groups vs Waitlisted Control Groups
When an RCT does include a control group, the control group is randomly either the treatment group (or intervention group), which receives the intervention; or randomly, not allocated to the intervention group (e.g., waitlist control).

# Structure of Random Groups
There are three intervention groups. In the first group, also referred to as the waitlist or standard care group, participants receive standard or routine care. The second group receives the intervention. The third group receives the intervention followed by the standard routine care.

# Method of Randomization
In randomly allocated, randomization is conducted in the following sequential steps: 
- Recruit subjects
- Randomly allocate the subjects to the three intervention groups
- Allocate a random sample from each trial group to assess short-term effects
- Allocate a random sample from each trial group to assess long-term effects. .

Talking About Death and Bereavement by Caregivers of Clients With Dementia in Day-Care Centers
Death talk by caregivers of clients with dementia was studied in four day-care centers in Sweden. The authors interviewed 18 staff and 10 clients, all of whom had experience of a bereavement. They found that 27% of all topics were about death, 22% concerned care of the body and funerals, 18% about life, 15% about sadness and sorrow, 12% life or death, 4% about the client's or person's dying. The results demonstrate that the clients' family members did not participate in the caregivers' talk and that they participated to a very small extent in the talk. The authors conclude that talk about death, the body, and funerals in centers for clients with dementia is not sufficiently attended to by staff who do not seem to think this talk is a problem. The authors recommend that staff should receive more education in how to provide this type of care and that care managers should provide this type of support in daily care work for people with dementia. This was one of my favorite topics in residency—and was often met with a similar response on rounds. For any given patient, there is an in-depth history available. In a variety of settings, we can choose to use that information, or ignore it, in order to make a diagnosis. By using a single diagnostic algorithm for all patients, we lose the richness of this tool—the differential and its associated variables.
It is rare for two patients with similar histories and presenting complaints to have underlying diagnoses that are identical. In clinical practice, this is one of the most important reasons to focus on both the history and physical exam: the history tells us what is important to consider, whereas the physical exam provides details of the disease process.
In a way, this reminds me of how the 1963 TWA 528 crash occurred. A pilot at a stopover noticed some unexplained problems with the aircraft and attempted to contact the base to alert them. Because he did not get a response, which was not unusual at the base given high volume of radio calls, he reportedly continued through the night. The next morning, a colleague became alarmed by the situation and called the base. He heard the response that ‘‘everything was okay,’’ but had not actually heard the response to the pilot’s report the previous evening. With this information in mind, the next day the pilot again attempted to contact the base by radio.
Unfortunately, his message went unanswered as well. And this cycle of trying to get a response without being able to make contact continued. As part of the pilot’s routine safety protocol, when he had not checked in with his base for 24 hours, he had a requirement to land to refuel. Instead of doing so, he went on a longer flight, which lasted nearly eight full days. At the end of that long flight, the plane ran out of fuel, and both engines suffered a complete failure. He did not have enough fuel to find a safe place to land, and then crashed into a residential area in St. Louis. The crash caused the death of 34 of the 62 occupants of the plane.

Enzymatically cross-linked hyaluronic acid: rheological aspects of new biomaterial injections for soft tissue augmentation.
OBJECTIVE
To assess the rheological properties of enzymatically glycosaminoglycan cross-linked hyaluronic acid (HA) gels for soft tissue augmentation.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Two enzymatically modified polysaccharide (EMP) HA gels with identical physical properties, but two different cross-link density were mixed with either calcium chloride to produce calcium-based HA gel, and with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) to produce saline-based gel. Viscosity analyses were tested using a controlled stress viscometer and a steady state rheometer. Flow characteristics were tested using a needle-syringe.


RESULTS
The viscosity of calcium HA gel in PBS was higher than that of phosphate HA gel in PBS. Viscosity was affected inversely by shear rate. Neither calcium-based nor saline-based gels showed thixotropic behavior. The flow properties of gels in PBS were influenced by the cross-link density of EMP HA gels. Higher cross-linked gels showed more shear-thinning behavior than lower cross-linked gels in PBS.


CONCLUSION

Apoptosis of Bone Marrow-Derived Endothelial Cells Promotes Angiogenesis In Vivo: A Role for Tumor Necrosis Factor α*

The mechanisms regulating endothelial apoptosis and angiogenesis are incompletely understood. Tumor necrosis factor ␣ (TNF-␣) is a potent inducer of angiogenesis in vitro, although this effect in vivo is unclear. We established a bone marrow transplant model in which bone marrow-derived endothelial cells (BMECs) were tracked by intravenously transplanting CFSE-labeled cells. BMECs accumulated in the bone marrow and spleen of mice, where all BMECs died within 6 h. We found that CFSE ؉ BMECs were detected in angiogenic sites 12 h after transplant, demonstrating that BMECs traffic to sites of angiogenesis. To assess their role in angiogenesis, we depleted cells undergoing apoptosis using an antagonist of the TNF receptor 1 (TNFR1). Inhibition of TNF-␣ binding to its receptors 1 and 2 attenuated apoptosis of endothelial cells in vitro, and depletion of apoptotic endothelial cells in vivo using a CD31 antibody or the use of anti-TNFR1 antibodies significantly enhanced angiogenesis in the retina in vivo and reduced the number of apoptotic endothelial cells in vitro. These findings demonstrate that apoptosis of BMECs in vivo contributes to angiogenesis at the early stages of angiogenesis.

Regarding question 2, about choosing a research framework, the review type we have in mind would be a qualitative review. Qualitative research is more focused on understanding participants' perspectives and experiences, while systematic reviews are more objective and focused on evaluating and synthesizing evidence. However, it's important to note that the decision to choose either a qualitative or a systematic review ultimately depends on the specific research question and the type of data being analyzed.
Regarding question 3, how would we choose between synthesis and meta-analysis? A systematic review would include a synthesis of evidence and also meta-analysis, which is often used to pool results from multiple studies. The synthesis of evidence usually involves a narrative (descriptive) review. This type of review is based on the ability to interpret the data. In the selection and assessment of the evidence, more important characteristics may be found. Finally, the methodological quality of the scientific works that were analyzed, or some criteria that can support the selection of the final articles, must be taken into account. The search for scientific work and subsequent extraction can be performed through a search engine or other website, but the results must be extracted and summarized and in many cases, tables will have to be used to describe it. Based on the goals of your study, one possible primary outcome measure could be the change in DMN connectivity on rs-fMRI following real-rTMS compared to sham-rTMS in APOE4 carriers. This measure assesses the mean functional connectivity of the default mode network (DMN) using resting-state functional MRI (rs-fMRI). Higher values denote greater functional connectivity, and a positive change at post rTMS compared to baseline represents an increase in resting-state functional connectivity. The time frame for this measure would be baseline and post rTMS (1 week). What do you think of this suggestion?

Great! Now, let's move on to the second outcome measure. Based on the goals of your study, a suitable second outcome measure could be the change in DMN connectivity on TMS-EEG following real-rTMS compared to sham-rTMS in APOE4 carriers. This measure involves applying single-pulse TMS with concurrent EEG to derive online measures of cortical excitability and connectivity within the DMN. The response in the natural frequency of the target area will index cortical excitability, and effective connectivity will be measured through amplitude and latency of TEPs. The time frame for this measure would also be baseline and post rTMS (1 week). What are your thoughts on this suggestion?

Primary Outcome Measure:

- Time Frame: Baseline, post rTMS (1 week)

Secondary Outcome Measure:
- Outcome Measure: Change in DMN connectivity on TMS-EEG following real-rTMS compared to sham-rTMS in APOE4 carriers
- Measure Description: Single pulse TMS will be applied with concurrent EEG to derive online measures of cortical excitability and connectivity. - Time Frame: Baseline, post rTMS (1 week)

(Thromb Haemost 2008; 99: 44–48), which the authors have cited, deals not with prothrombotic coagulation processes but with processes responsible for thrombus stabilisation and dissolution. Furthermore, this work shows that infusion of a small dose of a TAFIa inhibitor during the initial phase of thrombus growth enhances thrombus growth and that, in contrast to what the authors suggest, the same dose of inhibitor given during the second half of thrombus growth does not alter thrombus size. The authors fail to acknowledge that the TAFIa inhibition observed following infusion of the P16 may result from the plasma proteinase inhibitor activity. Secondary Outcome Measures Secondary outcome measures for pain trials are particularly difficult to implement (39). Trialists often choose an outcome of clinical importance (eg, quality of life), and when they do so, they generally fail to consider the important secondary construct that may be under study. In fact, most secondary outcomes tend to be clinically irrelevant (39). Secondary outcomes may include important measures that are often assessed in pain trials (eg, disability, sleep disturbance, and work productivity, along with adverse events), but these tend to be subjective (ie, the participants or study investigators are required to provide ratings based on their perceptions), and there is considerable heterogeneity when these outcomes are defined and measured (39). Secondary outcomes that are frequently used in trials but are questionable are length of pain persistence, number of days of absent work, and number of days of reduced activity after the intervention (40). Another secondary outcome measure that is infrequently described in published trials is economic burden, but it is actually an important outcome that encompasses both the individual and societal economic impact (41). The economic perspective should be included because most healthcare costs are borne by individuals and paid by their government insurance plan (41). Although economic cost is important to include as an outcome when evaluating healthcare interventions, it is rarely considered. For economic cost to be considered as an outcome, it is necessary to determine upfront what costs will be considered. However, cost-effectiveness analyses are frequently missing from trials, even despite the fact that economic analyses improve our understanding of the cost/ benefit tradeoff between 2 treatments. Health economic and quality of life trials are more frequently reported in journals that are devoted to pain research (41). Secondary outcomes can also be subjective, and they tend to be of poor quality in pain trials (41). These outcomes range from clinical and quality of life measures to economic and even qualitative measures. Trialists cannot use every measurement as a secondary outcome unless there is a good balance between clinical relevance and practicality. For example, economic cost needs to be considered as a secondary outcome, but it requires consideration and calculation for each participant (41). However, this may prove inadequate for large trials because it is resource intensive

Heart Rate Range: The heart rate range is the difference between maximum and minimum heart rates during the test exercise. The more the range is below normal, the weaker the person will be. The heart rate range value is used to evaluate whether the participant improves their exercise performance over the course of the program. Systolic Blood Pressure: The systolic blood pressure is the pressure measured when your heart beats or contracts. The lower the systolic blood pressure is, the healthier it is. If the participant’s value changes after completing the rehab program, that reflects a favorable outcome. Diastolic Blood Pressure: The diastolic blood pressure is the pressure maintained after the heart beats or contracts, and it falls when blood is transferred to your peripheral organs like your lungs, kidneys, and brain. The influence of 24-hour urine urea nitrogen and uric acid on the risk of metabolic syndrome in Japanese obese children and adolescents
This study aimed to clarify the association of 24-hour urine urea nitrogen (UN) and uric acid (UA) with the risk of metabolic syndrome (MS) in obese Japanese children and adolescents and to examine whether there are any differences between sex or age group. The subjects included 1038 children and adolescents (boys, 329; girls; 709) with a body mass index (BMI) ≥ 12 kg m−2 by the National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III (male, 12 years and older; female, 15 years and older). Urine collection and data analysis were performed according to the method of the American Heart Association guidelines. The cut-off values for 24-hour urine UN and UA were set at 11.5mg d−1 and 7.0mg d−1, respectively. An association between 24-hour urine UN/UA and the risk of MS was determined. The prevalence rate of MS was 29.0% in male children, 19.0% in female children, 24.2% in male adolescents, and 31.9% in female adolescents. 24-hour urine UN/UA levels significantly decreased with age. A logistic regression analysis revealed that the prevalence rate of MS increased alongside elevated urine UN, with a significant association between the prevalence rate of MS and urine UN found in male adolescents. The prevalence rate of MS was significantly elevated in those with urine UN and UA levels above the set value, in female adolescents. In females, there was no significant association between the prevalence rate of MS and 24-hour urine UN, but there was a significant association for UA. We demonstrated that male adolescents with low urine UN level, even with low body fat, were at risk of MS. .

Dysregulation of Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor‐1 Signaling in Patent ductus arteriosus With and Without Pulmonary Hypertension
Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with pulmonary hypertension (pulm‐PH) results in more fatalities than nontreated PDA or PDA with nonpulm‐PH. The mechanism underlying pulm‐PH in these patients remains mostly unknown. We examined the expression of vascular smooth muscle cell (vSMC) and cardiac fibroblast growth factor receptor‐1 (FGFR1) in an animal model in comparison with nontreated and PDA with nonpulm‐PH rats. PDA animals had greater systolic ductal blood flow, pulmonary vascular resistance, and pulmonary vascular wall thickness that were inhibited by the FGF receptor inhibitor (PD173074). Further, vSMC proliferation, collagen deposition, and fibrotic area in the pulmonary artery of PDA‐pulm‐PH increased significantly with downregulation of cardiac FGFR1 expression. The pulmonary and circulating levels of soluble FGFR1 were also upregulated, suggesting a compensatory mechanism to regulate the vSMC proliferation and collagen deposition by inhibiting FGFR1 in PDA‐pulm‐PH. Increased fibrotic area in the pulmonary artery of PDA‐pulm‐PH was reversed by adenovirus overexpression of FGFR1. We concluded that in the PDA‐pulm‐PH; (1) downregulation of cardiac FGFR1 expression is involved in pulmonary artery (PA) muscularization, (2) upregulation of circulating soluble FGFR1 is involved in inhibition of FGFR1 expression, and (3) proliferation of vSMCs induced FGFR1 downregulation, which further triggered fibrosis in PDA‐pulm‐PH. The FERONIA (FER) receptor‐like kinase encodes a leucine‐rich repeat receptor protein kinase and regulates cell‐cell communication and cell polarity in plants. The extracellular region of FER contains a type III immunoglobulin domain (IgIII) that is well conserved in the receptor‐like kinase family, while the kinase domain has a distinct sequence from that in other plant receptor‐like kinases. We have investigated the possible involvement of the IgIII domain in FER phosphorylation activity by mutational analyses of the protein. We showed that an immunophilin‐like fold exists at the N‐terminal half of IgIII, and predicted that FER is involved in protein–protein interaction via IgIII. In vitro binding assays, using recombinant FER proteins, demonstrated that the C‐terminal region of IgIII functions to bind a plant extracellular matrix protein, the cell wall pectin rhamnogalacturonan I (RG‐I), and the N‐terminal region of IgIII is necessary for full interaction with RG‐I. In vivo binding assays demonstrated the involvement of IgIII in FER membrane localization and association with membrane lipid raft via the intracellular plasma membrane targeting motif YXXΦ (Φ: phospholipid). Analysis of phosphorylation activity indicated that the extracellular region of FER proteins might be involved in the interaction with the receptor‐like protein CLAVATA1 (CLV1). The N‐terminal region of IgIII may be necessary for full phosphorylation of CLV1 in FER‐CLV1 protein complexes, suggesting that IgIII participates in the interaction with CLV1 via protein–protein interactions.  The Effect of Thermal Stimuli on Gait in Poststroke and Healthy Subjects
Thermal sensory stimuli may help to reduce postural sway and enhance balance control. The aim of this work was to study the effect of thermal stimuli on gait symmetry and temporal parameters in a clinical environment where patients with hemiplegia walk alongside healthy subjects. Participants walked barefoot and under different thermal stimuli: 44 °C and 44 °C plus wind (air stream) as well as 4 °C and 4 °C plus air stream in a gait laboratory with a walkway that consists of a 26 m indoor path. An air stream of 2 m/s was added, when needed, so as to minimize the thermal sensation difference between feet. The wind had a significant role in enhancing walking speed for patients with hemiplegia. When compared with healthy subjects, those suffering from hemiplegia walk with reduced walking speed and slower stride frequency but longer step length. # Introduction
The glycosaminoglycan (GAG) class of glycoproteins play a role in a variety of biological functions in most human tissues. Their physiological functions include the regulation of protein interactions, protein trafficking through epithelial or endothelial barriers, as well as modulation of proteins (e.g., enzymes) as they play many roles in the metabolism of the human body. Due to their structural and physiological diversity, GAGs are composed of several different species which present the same tissue of origin but have a distinctive GAG chemical composition and biochemical characteristics. The best way for molecular identification of GAGs remains a challenge because of the lack of a "gold standard" or reliable experimental approaches such as mass spectrometry. Therefore, protein glycosylation analysis methods to date present a few disadvantages including large sample size requirements and lack of automated approaches. GAGs are secreted as "proteoglycans" in the human body, thus, identification of their binding partners is essential for their function.

End User Comments Association of Serum Vascular Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 with Clinical Progression in Early and Advanced Stages of Carotid Artery Atherosclerosis
Carotid intima-media thickness is an important predictor of future cardiovascular events. Vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) levels have already been associated with atherosclerotic plaques and are thought to play an important role in atherogenesis. The aim of our study was to determine the clinical impact of soluble VCAM-1 in the early development and progression of atherosclerosis. We analysed data from 355 patients who underwent intimamedia thickness measurement. VCAM-1 levels were higher (p < 0.0001) in patients with atherosclerotic carotid disease (median concentration 1.06 ng/ml, range 0.4–6.2 ng/ml) than in patients with normal ultrasound carotid intima-media thickness studies (median concentration 0.84 ng/ml, range 0.4–3.2). A higher VCAM-1 concentration was found in the group with the most severe intima-media thickness (>0.9 mm) compared to the thinner group (>0.8 mm) (median 1.12 (range 0.39–6.21) vs. median 0.90 ng/ml, range 0.4–3.1), and also in the group with high-grade plaque (grade III) compared to group without atherosclerotic plaque or grade II plaque (median 2.40 ng/ml, range 0.4–6.2 vs. median 0.90 ng/ml, range 0.4–3.2). Thus, a higher VCAM-1 level is associated with a more severe carotid atherosclerotic process, and therefore may be related to plaque progression and the risk of stroke. Surgical treatment of primary pulmonary lymphoma in two cats.
Two clinically normal cats were presented for evaluation of a mass in the left hemithorax and a cranial mediastinal mass. Histological examination revealed a tumour in both cases. The left lung tumour was granulomatous in nature, and consisted of a number of large follicles, some with a central necrotic region. No bronchial or vascular invasion was seen. Tumour cells were CD3-positive, consistent with a classified T-cell. The mediastinal lesion was formed by lymphocytes with characteristic cerebriform nuclei, and contained germinal centres forming follicles. The tumour cells stained positively for CD79a. These two lesions appear to be primary pulmonary lymphomas, which to date has only been documented in domestic animals once before. .

It's time to ask ourselves “Who will fund this research?” Without sufficient funding, this study would not be possible. The government, for-profit hospitals, or health insurance companies might be willing to fund it, but the real source of funding in health research is not always obvious. The sponsor of a research project is typically the organization that holds the purse strings. This may be a government department, hospital, research institute, or pharmaceutical company, to name a few. If the research is being undertaken in an academic or public hospital, we can assume the hospital itself is its sponsor. The sponsor of an individual research project has control over aspects such as what is researched, when it is researched, and how it is funded. By controlling these elements, it is thought that the sponsor gains additional influence over the direction of health policy. One key concern, however, is that the funding body may have a financial interest in the outcome of the research. For example, if a pharmaceutical company is sponsoring the research and producing the drug/device being tested, we can deduce it is in the company’s interests to see the drug/device be successful. Thus, the company is incentivized to influence the direction of the research in such a way as to achieve a ‘positive’ outcome. To prevent biases such as these, the research protocol is often peer reviewed by experts in the field before it receives approval for commencement. At this point, we can assume that the study is underway and the research will start to be published in medical journals. Journals which host medical research are generally established by medical professionals (typically, hospital doctors) who want to make the research conducted by other medical professionals publicly available. Improved Outcomes With Enzalutamide in a Cohort of Older Patients With Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
Background/Aim: Treatments have been improved by the development of second-generation antineoplastic agents; however, there are some concerns about their use in elderly patients. Materials and Methods: A total of 34 patients who were 75 years or older and who received enzalutamide (MDV-3800) for metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer were enrolled from three institutions. Their characteristics were assessed and changes in androgen and testosterone levels and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) concentration were noted. Results: Enzalutamide had a positive effect on overall survival in terms of time to first use of hormonal therapy (P=0.047); PSA, testosterone and androstenedione levels also improved. The median survival was 16.1 months overall, and 30.5 months in the subset of patients who had not been previously treated with docetaxel. Furthermore, 87.5% of the patients reported minimal quality of life deteriorations or better, without any serious adverse events. Conclusion: These findings suggest a high level of clinical efficacy for enzalutamide without major toxicity. For some time we were convinced that an effect of drugs on the tumour cell could be accomplished by reaching the cell at the site of the tumour implant. If the drugs were applied systemically, they would be diluted by the blood flow, which would then wash out the active principle . It was soon obvious that the systemic infusion into the blood of the dog of a dose of chlorambucil which was ineffective when inoculated into the tumour itself (Table 1) would produce a complete regression of tumour implants which remained untouched outside the bloodstream. Similarly, an intratumoural injection had no effect when tried by mouth. These findings seemed to prove that the systemic dose of chlorambucil was ineffective because the active substance was not retained at the site of the cancer cells to produce a local cytotoxic reaction. The idea of an active intralymphatic drug (A.I.D.) was formulated by the demonstration that the lymph carries a fluid that is essential to the growth of the tumour. A study of the lymph and of the lymph nodes of the rabbit's hind leg revealed that within this duct there was a liquid (Bernays 1962) which, as far as we were aware, had two properties: first, it contained cholesterol, an indispensable substance necessary to growth and multiplication of tumour cells; and, second, it enhanced the growth of such cells. We thus felt that this substance might act as a nutritional substrate for the tumour and thus constitute a fertilising liquid, the presence of which might be necessary for the development of the tumour. - Primary haemorrhage: Number of patients with primary haemorrhage within 24 hours post-operatively.
- Secondary haemorrhage: Number of patients with secondary haemorrhage from day 1 to day 30 post-operatively.
- LOS: Length of stay in hospital within 30 days post-operatively.

- Secondary return to theatre: Number of patients requiring return to operating room from day 1 to day 30 post-operatively.

You can set up outcome measures as part of a flow (see [Setting up flows](/v2/admin/guides/settings/setting-up-flows)).

An outcome measure is a way of automatically checking and monitoring the state of an entity — a list item or a record. For example, an outcome measure can make sure that a list item is assigned to a member, or that a record has at least one tag.

## Defining an outcome measure

To create an outcome measure, you must provide (or create) a [custom condition](/v2/admin/guides/administer-custom-conditions/creating-custom-conditions).

1. Open the **flow** screen of the flow that includes list items or records you need to monitor.

A prospective study of depressed moods and serum estradiol in women of reproductive age.
CONTEXT
Few studies have examined relationships between moods reported longitudinally and physiologic measures during the follicular phase.


OBJECTIVE
Our objective was to assess the associations between day-to-day fluctuation in depressed moods and serum estradiol levels during the follicular phase.


DESIGNS
This was an ancillary study to a natural family-planning study where serum samples were collected throughout the follicular phase.


SETTING
The study took place at the University Faculty of Medicine in Thailand. Participants were married Thai women. Intervention was natural conception.


PARTICIPANTS
One hundred eighty-six women ages 18 to 40 were evaluated, with 44 women being excluded because either they had a suboptimal end of their menses (ovulation did not occur during the 4th or 5th day), they had a history of medical diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, chronic hypertension, and cardiac diseases), or they were using hormone preparations.


MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES
The main outcomes measured include daily self-reported mood and salivary cortisol changes related to mood. A logistic stepwise regression model (P < .1) to identify variables in association with estradiol change was formulated.


RESULTS
One hundred forty-two women contributed 726 mood reports. Daily changes in depressed moods were not related to serum estradiol levels while controlling for duration of mood and age (P=.40). There were significant differences between those women with a higher change in estradiol and those with a lower change in estradiol. Specifically, more depressed moods were reported within the day before more than a 10 mg/dL increase in the estradiol concentrations (P = .001), and on the following day before more than a 15 mg/dL increase in estradiol concentrations (P = .01). The last of our three posts on the outcome measures you should track and analyze when you are conducting an impact evaluation. We’ve already introduced the most common ways of looking at impact (means vs. differences) and the variety of “output or process” measures you could use to assess feasibility and fidelity. This final post examines the two ways of assessing the effectiveness of your intervention. The first, and the one recommended by most impact evaluation methodologists, is the classic “before-after” evaluation, also sometimes referred to as a prepost evaluation. The second type of evaluation involves collecting pre and post measures to construct a difference-in-difference analysis.
Before-After Design
Although most evaluators use this traditional method of impact evaluation, as discussed in our previous post, this approach has some notable limitations. One reason the prepost method remains popular is because it is inexpensive to run. The approach simply requires measurement of the same variables at two time points, the pretreatment evaluation (baseline), and (hopefully) a follow-up evaluation. If you only collect demographic information at baseline, you can keep your prepost sample size small.
In the case of HERO House, for example, it is less costly, both in terms of time and money, to collect data at just two distinct time points than to have follow-up surveys distributed and collected periodically over a long time period. The additional benefits of using the before-after design include more accurate assessment of the program’s impact and a greater likelihood of detecting small effects as well as large effects. Of course, the down side of before-after evaluations is that they can’t be used to show how well a program is working and are thus limited to showing only the degree to which the program achieves one or more program goals.
The basic data analysis technique for a before-after analysis is to compare changes between the prepost measures of your outcome variables using appropriate statistical analyses. Depending on the type of variables that you measured, these analyses also could involve calculating the correlation between the two measures of the same variables. Of course, you will want to verify that your pre-survey and post-survey measures are comparable. When you use the same questionnaires, your prepost analyses will be based on correlation coefficients. The purpose of this case report is to show problems, which may appear to be solved only to be brought back into existence. A 50-year-old man had received an implantation of a titanium cemented femoral prosthesis. Three years later the prosthesis had to be revised because of a periprosthetic fracture. The periprosthetic fracture did not heal and 8 months later the femur had to be amputated 15 cm proximal to the knee. One year after the operation an aseptic loosening had occurred of the cemented components. Because of a good bony integration of the femur at the remaining stump, the revision was carried out by insertion of a stem which was threaded and cemented into the remaining femur. During the operation osteolysis was suspected, however, a biopsy did not prove osteolysis. One year later a recurrence of the aseptic loosening with an instability of the hip joint occurred. Despite the recurrence, the femur had fused with the proximal end of the prosthesis which caused that the revision could not be carried out. Tendon reflexes are one of the few clinical parameters that can be used to assess peripheral and central nervous system involvement in polyneuropathies. They reflect the integrity of the sensory (fibers) and motor (axons) fibers and a disturbance of the spinal autonomic reflex arches. The tendon reflexes are examined separately, they may also be quantified. Involvement of the reflexes in the proximal and distal parts of the body have little in common. Proximal arechon reflexes are less easily obtained than distal flexor and extensor ones. The latency of the tendon reflexes reflects the number of functioning nerves and also the conduction distances. They become abnormal at the same time as motor nerve conduction velocities drop. # Introduction
Snakebite is an important public health concern globally, and the World Health Organization's (WHO) latest report confirmed that at least 5 million people are bitten worldwide annually. Most of the deaths (81,000) are reported in tropical and subtropical regions-mainly Latin America, Africa (Central and East), West Africa, and Southeast Asia. Almost all snake species reported to bite or envenomate humans are included in a taxonomic group comprised of 3560 species distributed in 14 families. However, the species with the highest incidence of snakebites are included in the families Viperidae, Elapidae, and Colubridae.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

You don't need to be a doctor or a nurse to provide full outcome measures of a clinical trial. You might remember from the case study that there are 5 outcome measures that we will evaluate. These are:
1. Progression-free survival
2. Overall survival
3. Maximum tumour shrinkage
4. Clinical benefit rate
5. Time to deterioration in performance status
Let's take a look at what each of these outcomes means in more practical terms.
Progression-free survival
The progression-free survival measures the period of time where there has been no evidence of cancer progression. In the original clinical trial discussed, the cancer was treated with the new therapy, and this period of time was measured in months.
Overall survival
The overall survival measures the period of time where the patient is still alive from the start of the trial.
Maximum tumour shrinkage
The maximum tumour shrinkage is the biggest reduction in size that the tumour experiences. This is usually measured against the pre-treatment size of the tumour.
Clinical benefit rate
The clinical benefit rate captures the number of participants who experienced full treatment response (partial or complete response). The overall response to the medication is measured against the pre-treatment size of the patient. This outcome can only be assessed by the doctors and not by the patients.
Time to deterioration in performance status
The time to deterioration in performance status is a measure of how quickly a participant experiences a drop in their overall health. This outcome captures deterioration in patient's general ability to care for themselves or carry out daily activities.
The clinical trials that will evaluate these outcomes will have different treatment groups to compare them. The different treatment groups are listed below.
Control group
The control group is simply the control or comparison drug. In the case study of the PHOGS-1 trial, carboplatin was the designated control drug. The participants in this group will also experience all the same protocols including the length of time taken from first treatment to the final treatment. All clinical information on this group will be collected in the same way and at the same time as of the new therapy (QL1706H).

For the secondary outcome measure, it's crucial to assess the safety and tolerability of QL1706H. We can do this by evaluating the rate of treatment-related adverse events using NCI CTCAE v5.0. To account for the complexity of the medical management of patients with neuroendocrine tumors, I suggest that in addition to the severe neutropenia incidence, the following secondary outcome measures be considered for assessment: Efforts to Reduce Surgical Waiting Times and Stratify Priorities in an Academic Department for Pediatric Plastic Surgery
Introduction: Although priorities within the field of pediatric plastic surgery can be highly variable, patients with craniofacial surgical conditions requiring short- or long-term treatment and interventions often take priority over elective and nontime-sensitive interventions. Our goal was to create an algorithm assigning priorities to patients seeking surgical intervention. We also aimed to reduce surgical waiting times for patients with more complex conditions to be able to provide the best available care when needed. Methods: At our institution, a multidisciplinary surgery planning meeting was created in order to optimize prioritization. After the meeting, an algorithm was created based on consensus recommendations to guide scheduling of time-sensitive interventions. A retrospective review of the electronic medical record of pediatric patients scheduled for plastic surgery over a 6-month period (April 2022 to September 2022) was performed. Patients were categorized based on the priority assigned as seen on the electronic scheduling record. Wait times are reported as the duration between the date of scheduling in months and the date of surgery in days. Results: Of the 115 patients scheduled during the study period, 100 met inclusion criteria and had data available for analysis. The average waiting time before surgery for time-sensitive intervention is 64.1 ± 32.3 days. The average waiting time for nontime-sensitive interventions was 149.4 ± 72.4 days . Conclusion: We developed a patient flow management protocol to facilitate time-sensitive surgery in our pediatric plastic surgery center. Our algorithm provides a helpful tool to guide our staff to prioritize patients with complex surgical conditions. The work deals with the results of studies of the effect of a wide spectrum of antimicrobial drugs (gentamicin, ampicillin, amoxicillin and 3rd generation cephalosporins) on the viability of plague agents both cultivated in liquid media and free living in natural foci. The results of investigations revealed that gentamicin has a bactericidal effect on cultured and viable Y. pestis. The spirochetocidal effect of gentamicin was shown to be dose dependent. The highest effect on plague agents was observed in a complex treatment with this drug and norepinephrine. The results indicate that the bacteriostatic activity of cephalosporins, ampicillin and amoxicillin is negligible on viable Y. pestis present in natural foci. The research data also suggest that the bactericidal activity of antibacterial drugs toward cultured plague agents is manifested to a much lesser degree in free living bacteria. Chlamydia infection by genital hygiene and menstrual cycle in African-American female and male.
Previously, studies with African-American populations did not detect a relationship between genital hygiene, menstrual cycle and Chlamydia trachomatis infection. We performed a case-control study using female and male subjects, and measured genital cleanliness by the vaginal index, urine nitrite by dipslides and menstrual cycle with progestin levels. The study revealed an increase in Chlamydia trachomatis infection in female subjects with a high vaginal index by 37, and a decrease of infection in males with a high vaginal index by 44 percent (P < 0.02). Among subjects with a high vaginal index, urine nitrite levels were less than 200 parts per billion in 56 percent of male non-infected and in 88 percent of male infected subjects; these levels were 400 parts per billion in 5 percent of non-infected subjects and 34 percent of all infected subjects. Among female subjects, urine nitrite levels were higher, and there were no differences in levels between infected and non-infected subjects. We conclude that infection may be initiated or inoculated during coitus by vaginal cleansing. This study indicates that menstrual cycle is not a major risk factor for Chlamydia infection, and that nitrite testing may not be an adequate indicator of risk

Considering the nature of the trial and the potential side effects, I suggest including the following secondary outcome measures: neutropenia incidence (all grades), febrile neutropenia incidence, frequency of unexpected emergency department visits and length of stay, overall survival, progression-free survival, and predictive biomarkers for treatment response analysis. These measures will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on neutropenia, patient outcomes, and treatment response.

Certainly! Here are the descriptions and time frames for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Neutropenia incidence (all grades): This measure captures the occurrence of all grades of neutropenia, not just severe cases. It helps us understand the overall impact of Tripegfilgrastim on neutropenia. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

2. Febrile neutropenia incidence: This measure focuses specifically on the occurrence of febrile neutropenia, which is a serious complication. It helps assess the efficacy of Tripegfilgrastim in preventing this severe complication. The time frame for this measure is also "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

3. Frequency of unexpected emergency department visits and length of stay: This measure evaluates the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on healthcare utilization and patient outcomes. It assesses the frequency of emergency department visits and the length of stay for patients. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

4. Overall survival: This measure reflects the ultimate goal of prolonging patient survival. It helps determine the impact of Tripegfilgrastim on overall patient outcomes and prognosis. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

5. Progression-free survival: This measure assesses the effectiveness of Tripegfilgrastim in delaying disease progression. It provides insights into tumor control and disease stability. The time frame for this measure is "through study completion, an average of 1 year".

6. Predictive biomarkers for treatment response analysis: This measure focuses on analyzing biomarkers to identify patients who are likely to benefit from Tripegfilgrastim. It helps personalize therapy and optimize patient care. The time frame for this measure is also "through study completion, an average of 1 year".
